IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal requests funds to purchase hardware to meet the high-performance computing needs of users of the Structural Biology Core Facility at UT Health San Antonio. The requested GPU-equipped high-performance computing cluster will enable investigators to leverage state-of-the art software for all three major branches of structural biology including cryo-EM, X-ray crystallography, and NMR as well as artificial intelligence-based approaches to in silico modeling of multiprotein complex structures. Access to this equipment would otherwise be cost prohibitive and will accelerate the research efforts of a large number of NIH-funded investigators studying a wide range of biomedically-relevant problems with the goal of improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related declines in muscle mass and function are key contributors to frailty, which is a major public health problem that significantly reduces mobility, increases disability, hampers independence, and raises the risk of falls and injuries among the elderly. The lack of understanding of mechanisms of muscle wasting and weakness represents a critical barrier to progress toward the development of successful interventions for ameliorating physical frailty and thereby improving quality of life in old age. Through the elucidation of mechanisms that allow muscle motor units to expand their size to rescue muscle fibers destined to be lost due to denervation, this project will provide insights into processes and pathways that may be targeted for the development of rehabilitation interventions that exploit existing compensatory protective mechanisms to preserve muscle, prolong healthspan, and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose to develop, evaluate and disseminate a health information technology (IT)-enabled, multilevel, stepped care intervention grounded in primary care, PREDICT (Personalized Risk-based Follow-up of Cervical Cancer Screening in Practice), to improve timely and appropriate care for cervical cancer screening and management (CCSM). PREDICT components include: 1) system redesign to deliver CCSM recommendations at a population level, 2) support for individual patient and clinician engagement, and 3) enhanced team coordination through an efficient “stepped care” approach. The effectiveness and implementation of PREDICT will be evaluated (vs. standard care) by conducting a 3-arm cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) of individuals in 4 primary care networks, coupled with a rigorous implementation evaluation, to achieve the sustainability and dissemination of this intervention.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Narrative High resolution in vivo micro-computed tomography (microCT) has become a “gold standard” for imaging and analysis of bone and other tissues (fat, muscle, contrast-enhanced vasculature) in longitudinal studies, but our institution currently lacks such an instrument. Augusta University has many NIH-supported projects that would benefit from this high resolution tool, which would enhance the precision, rigor, and reproducibility of our investigators’ funded and preliminary studies. The Functional Outcomes Core at AU has extensive scientific, technical, and administrative experience with in vivo and ex vivo imaging technology, including microCT, and the institution is in full support of this application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Narrative Statement The vagus nerve, the main interoceptive connection between the brain and body, represents a novel target for treatment of alcohol use disorders (AUD), the third leading cause of preventable death in the U.S. This preclinical translational study will be the first of its kind to use a combination of behavioral, electrophysiological, molecular, histological and viral transgenic techniques to investigate the mechanisms by which vagus nerve disruptions, particularly loss of gastric vagal control over central hypothalamic signaling, promotes increased alcohol preference in rodent models. Findings from these studies will fill critical gaps in our current knowledge of vagally mediated alterations in alcohol-related behaviors that could be used to develop novel strategies for AUD treatments.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We request funding to purchase a new nanoScan SPECT-CT scanner. This proposed micro-scanner will restore the preclinical SPECT-CT capability in the region since failure of our last system before the pandemic and will provide basic science SPECT-CT radionuclide imaging for 20 major users spanning a broad range research programs including: the development of novel theranostic agents aimed towards personalized medicine, exciting and highly impactful immunotherapy strategies, as well as novel research in cancer, cystic fibrosis, digestive diseases, inflammation and infection, and tissue repair and regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A modern Bruker ELEXSYS-II E500 X-band CW (continuous wave) EPR (electron paramagnetic resonance) spectrometer system is requested to replace an outdated and frequently malfunctioning version in the National Biomedical EPR Center at MCW. The enhanced sensitivity and reliability of the new instrument will significantly improve our ability to study critical biological phenomena including protein structure and functional dynamics, mechanisms of novel redox and cancer therapeutic agents, and aid in the design of safer and more effective drugs against a broad spectrum of diseases. This state-of-the-art instrument will ensure the continued success of our NIH-funded research programs while also facilitating new scientific collaborations.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The requested equipment will provide a much-improved means of creating thin sections from tissues containing bone, teeth and various biomaterials for examination in microscopes and other analytic instruments. Current methods for creating these sections have significant limitations, curbing scientific advances. Scientists using this equipment will develop improved understanding of diseases such as osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and osteodystrophy of chronic kidney disease. The equipment will also help to improve our understanding of biological processes underlying bone healing and tissue engineering. This knowledge will be important to improving public health.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative As the third-largest private medical school in the nation, the Medical College of Wisconsin is committed to building a regional resource to support biomedical research in infectious diseases, cancer, diabetes, brain disorders, cardiovascular disease, and drug discovery. The Advanced Cell Imaging Core is a crucial part of this effort. Enhancing the access to the cutting-edge super-resolution imaging system requested in this application will contribute to the research programs funded by NIH and directly impact the missions of medical education and research in the College and its partner institutions in southeast Wisconsin.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Intravital multiphoton microscopy has become a fundamental approach to investigate the single-cell interactions of the immune system in living tissues and living animals during steady-state conditions of normal health or during infection, transplantation, autoimmunity, cancer, and therapeutic approaches for these conditions. The requested multiphoton instrument will allow University of Minnesota Center for Immunology investigators to continue ongoing NIH-funded research unimpeded and allow them to significantly expand imaging-based research for the rational design of novel therapies in cancer, transplantation, autoimmunity, host/pathogen interactions, vaccines and infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Signaling and coordination among organ systems provides functional balance in young, healthy adults. Such interorgan communication is disrupted in the process of aging and contributes to complex, multiorgan loss-of- function. This proposal studies how changes in the communication between the kidney, adrenal gland and heart contributes to age-associated renal and cardiac decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall objective of the proposed research is to elucidate molecular mechanisms regulating the circadian expression of ion channel transcripts and proteins that impact arrhythmia susceptibility. To do this we will apply contemporary genomic, biochemical, and molecular tools to interrogate the circadian regulation of myocardial ion channel transcription and translation in cardiomyocytes. We will complement these studies by using electrophysiology approaches that allow us to determine whether feeding behavior can be manipulated as a chronotherapeutic strategy to ameliorate the risk for cardiac arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because autoimmune and inflammatory kidney diseases are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in affected patients. Standard immunosuppressive drugs are not effective in many patients, and the drugs themselves are associated with significant side effects. The concepts tested in these experiments should offer an important new approach to treating these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This study will refine and test automated quality coding of exposure therapy, a highly effective treatment for anxiety across the lifespan, using data from 6 existing clinical trials for youth and adults, across both research and community settings. Specific aims are designed to validate automated coding with Natural Language Processing (NLP; a type of artificial intelligence) against human coders, test predictive utility, and incorporate stakeholder feedback to facilitate near-term usability of findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This project will apply a novel in vivo gene editing approach to reveal key mechanistic drivers that perturb blood cell function with age and directly test the relevance of mutations that arise in cells of the blood system and can drive the expansion of individual blood cell clones to age-related dysfunctions in the cardiovascular, neurologic and skeletal muscle systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a major cause of permanent neuronal damage in thousands of infants in the United States every year and causes significant disease and death in individuals with weakened immune systems, including transplant recipients and some cancer patients. Cytokines are cellular signaling molecules that induce an anti-viral state to limit viral infection. Our proposal focuses on two opposing sides of the anti- viral state that could determine infectious outcomes: one, elucidating how cytokines reprogram metabolism to limit viral infection; and two, identifying the mechanisms through which the HCMV antagonizes anti-viral signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although mammalian species display significant variation in the rate of embryonic development, the mechanisms that define species-specific developmental rates remain unknown. The proposed research program will leverage in vitro models of mouse and human development to define the role of mitochondrial metabolism in regulating developmental speed. Elucidating the mechanisms that control developmental rate will enable its direct manipulation, making possible the acceleration of human induced pluripotent stem cell differentiation for disease modeling and cell-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol consumption stimulates the release of endogenously-produced opioid peptides that influence the rewarding effects of this drug. With continued consumption and over time, the ability to stimulate the same level of response changes fundamentally, although it is not known if such changes include the production of novel peptides from the same family. Here we will apply the use of advanced analytical platforms and animal models of addiction towards the study of a novel peptide that we believe may be influencing cognitive impairments in individuals with Alcohol Use Disorder.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Two decades-old transmission electron microscopes at Vanderbilt University, that have been used extensively and essential to identifying optimal specimens for high-resolution structural determination by electron cryo-microscopy (cryo-EM), are no longer repairable. To replace these instruments with a modern technology, we propose to acquire the ThermoScientific Talos L120C at our cryo-EM facility. Structural determination of biological macromolecules and cellular ultrastructure at high-resolution by cryo-EM is central to elucidating the physiological and disease mechanisms at the molecular level, and thus acquisition of the proposed instrument is expected to support the continued progress and acceleration of NIH funded research projects of investigators at Vanderbilt University that are highly relevant to improving human health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Our prior studies demonstrated efficacy of adjunctive azithromycin to further reduce maternal infections by 50% and remarkable cost-savings in unscheduled cesareans (CDs), leading ACOG to recommend its routine use in unscheduled CDs. Given additional promising preliminary data, we propose a large randomized trial (N=8000) within the MFMU Network to evaluate the benefits of adjunctive azithromycin in scheduled/pre-labor CDs and further assess the safety of this innovative antibiotic prophylaxis strategy to reduce the incidence of infection, one of the top 3 causes of pregnancy-related death and illness in the US. The trial will likely lead to a rapid policy change to extend this promising intervention to scheduled CDs, with significant health and cost benefits.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application seeks funds for a state-of-the art, hybrid quadrupole-Orbitrap (IQ-X) high resolution mass spectrometer to be housed within an existing core facility at the University of South Florida (USF). The instrument will be dedicated to establishing a Nucleic Acid Adductomics capability as a campus-wide shared resource to support multiple NIH-funded projects across USF and Moffitt Comprehensive Cancer Center. This will provide a unique approach to characterizing the widest possible range of nucleic acid modifications, and hence advancing our knowledge of their role in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Poor neurocognitive outcome in survivors of subarachnoid hemorrhage is an important problem affecting over 30,000 Americans each year. Dr. Chung's proposal has great potential to advance the understanding of poor neurocognitive outcome in this patient population through understanding how subarachnoid hemorrhage alters resting state functional brain connectivity. Furthermore, Dr. Chung seeks to develop a brain stimulation paradigm to restore cognitive function after brain injury.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Acquisition and installation of a Waters UPC2-MS instrument will enable scientists to characterize diverse new molecules derived from innovative synthetic methodology efforts at UW-Madison. The research targets medicinally relevant building blocks and complex molecules with increased structural diversity and stereochemical density. The requested instrument has state-of-the art resolving powers for chiral and achiral molecules, coupled to robust optical and mass detectors to support rapid assays needed to support high- throughput synthesis and screening. The research supported by this instrument will elucidate new ways to probe bacterial cell-cell signaling, discover novel disease therapies, and develop new catalytic methods for pharmaceutical synthesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Through the creation of an interactive, dynamic, and evidence-based repository, the National Coordinating Center for Advancing Gender Inclusive Excellence (AGIE) at Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) will dramatically improve access to resources, tools, technologies, expertise, and strategies that address challenges in overcoming systemic gender-based inequities impacting the biosciences academic and research workforce. Using a multi-pronged dissemination strategy along with a Pilot and Feasibility Program, the VCU AGIE will leverage the extensive network of the leadership team in collaboration with the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to promote and expand this repository across the national stage to have a broad impact on the success of gender equity programs in the science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and medicine (STEMM) academic and research workforce. In collaboration with the NIH, the VCU AGIE will operate as a centralized hub for optimizing the success of gender equity programs, setting a national standard of excellence for advancing diverse women faculty into leadership positions across the STEMM fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The individual and financial burden of bone loss and deterioration during normal or premature drug-induced aging is immense, especially for women. Our team is creating new ways to therapeutically target bone loss after discovering that the homoeostatic control center of the brain makes and secretes a circulatory anabolic factor in mice that preserves bone density and strength during aging.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: We present an urgent request for funding to purchase a new EchoMRI to replace the existing outdated analyzer which is obsolete in both hardware and software and suffers from frequent and unpredictable malfunctions that cause frustrating disruptions, delays and data loss to OHSU investigators engaged in NIH-funded studies.The new device will solve the current study disruption/delay issues and provide a reliable source of important technical services to ensure smooth progress of NIH-funded studies at OHSU to which body composition data are of critical importance. With advanced technology, enhanced capabilities, and improved accuracy, the new analyzer will revolutionize our research capabilities by offering expanded measurement capabilities, broader test modalities, and increased accuracy. This significant upgrade will unlock new dimensions and research areas that were previously unattainable due to limitations imposed by the outdated analyzer, enabling us to explore new frontier s and make groundbreaking discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will develop and evaluate a novel, personalized therapeutic approach for the management of dyspnea, one of the most common and distressing symptoms in hospitalized patients with cancer. In this patient-centered clinical study, we will take advantage of the acute nature of dyspnea to conduct a series of time-limited trials that will determine the optimal dyspnea treatment modalities for each patient. This research program is relevant to the mission of the National Institutes of Health because effective management of dyspnea will ultimately help to improve quality of life for patients suffering from this devastating symptom.

PHR: Narrative The Translational Pathology Shared Resource (TPSR) Facility at the SKCC of TJU is one of the 8 NCI-supported Core Facilities dedicated to developing cutting edge research in histopathology technical support and service as well as molecular pathology and digital pathology services. The current autostainer is remarkably slow and lacks capabilities such as Multiplexed Immunohistochemistry/Immunofluorescence, In Situ Hybridization and TUNEL assays. We request fund to acquire a new DISCOVERY ULTRA automatic autostainer to overcome these limitations to help our NCI-funded Cancer Center to achieve its mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our studies of the elimination of morphologically complex cells will provide important fundamental insights on programmed cell death and clearance, which are essential facets of proper development and homeostasis. These studies are relevant to public health in several respects: our findings may help devise targeted therapies against both tumor formation and immune dysfunction as well as in understanding brain development, injury and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Heterochronic or age disparate organ transplantation is a standard clinical practice with the potential of transferring rejuvenation (when transplanting young organs) or accelerated aging (when transplanting old organs), as well as with the potential for age reduction of donor organs in younger recipients. We have accumulated data on changes in biological age and compromised physical and cognitive capacities in experimental models supporting the concepts of organ rejuvenation and accelerated aging. A unique set of tools in transplantation models of translational relevance will delineate mechanisms of inter-organ communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  One early marker for cardiovascular disease is the process called “arterial stiffness”. However, the mechanisms of Western diet (high in fat and refined carbohydrates) and activation of the renin angiotensin– aldosterone system on arterial stiffness are poorly understood. Understanding the biochemical pathways leading to arterial stiffness should lead to specific interventional strategies, including new drugs and dietary interventions to prevent cardiovascular events in obese individuals.

PHR: Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly all patients with BRCA-mutated or Homologous Recombination Deficient ovarian cancer respond to frontline chemotherapy with PARP inhibitor maintenance; however, disease recurrence and therapy resistance almost inevitably develop. Targeting Wnt signaling and RNA splicing are therapeutic strategies that could overcome therapy resistance and provide further therapeutic options to advance the care options for our patients. The proposed clinical trial and basic science research will evaluate a novel combination strategy for platinum resistant ovarian cancer patients and elucidate the suspected mechanism(s) of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In some individuals, B cells produce autoantibodies and promote chronic autoimmune disorders with no cure. High affinity self-reactive B cells develop and stay in the bone marrow tissue, but can enter the circulation in autoimmune patients. Our studies aim to establish the role of a chemoattractant cell receptor and of cell adhesion receptors in the bone marrow retention and release of these self-reactive B cells.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cognitive dysfunction, psychiatric symptoms, functional impairment, and disability following COVID-19 negatively impact Veterans’ community functioning and quality of life, contribute to significant human suffering, and are costly to VHA. Rehabilitation is a critical priority for Veterans with long COVID. One promising treatment to improve functioning in Veterans with post-COVID-19 cognitive symptoms is Compensatory Cognitive Training (CCT). Previous studies have found that CCT is feasible, acceptable, and efficacious in Veteran populations with multiple sources of cognitive dysfunction. This randomized controlled trial aims to address important RR&D priorities by examining feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of a COVID- 19-specific rehabilitation intervention, CCT for long COVID (CCT-C) compared to a robust control condition. The proposed study has the potential to improve cognitive function, functional independence, and quality of life for Veterans with late or delayed effects of secondary conditions related to COVID-19 infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Center for Quantitative Biology: A focus on "omics", from organisms to single cells PROJECT NARRATIVE Phase 2 established a Center for Quantitative Biology (CQB) that nucleated and grew the fusion of wet-bench “- omics” research with bioinformatics at Dartmouth. The center nurtured and mentored new projects that sought to understand changes in cells and tissue biopsies, including the detail of single-cell dynamics, using high- throughput methods and integration of diverse ‘-omic’ data that are now being applied widely to multiple systems, diseases, cell types, and organisms to improve our understanding of healthy tissues and disease processes. Phase 2 will continue to build and grow the COBRE Center for Quantitative Biology that provides unique resources to investigators at Dartmouth and our IDeA partners, enhancing research productivity and funding competitiveness across the region.

The proposed supplemental activities are within the scope of the parent grant, no changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Komor – Project Narrative – “Development and Application of New Genome Editing Tools for the Functional Investigation of Genetic Variants of Uncertain Significance” Our inability to interpret the clinical consequences of genetic variants discovered by sequencing remains a critical obstacle to the progress of precision medicine: out of the 4.6 million missense variants identified in the Genome Aggregation Database, over half are admitted to be variants of uncertain significance (VUS). New methods capable of interpreting VUS would not only enhance the efficacy of current therapies by better informing patient selection strategies, but also accelerate the development of new approaches to combat diseases with a genetic component. Here we propose the development of new genome editing tools and platforms that will allow researchers to functionally interrogate thousands of VUS individually, in combination, and in aggregate, to produce clinically-relevant information on how genetic variations cause human disease.

PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Application of New Genome Editing Tools for the Functional Investigation of Genetic Variants of Uncertain Significance

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) disrupts romantic relationships and other aspects of psychosocial functioning, which can worsen Veterans' PTSD symptomatology and interfere with their long-term recovery. The proposed four-year study aims to reduce PTSD symptoms and improve relationship functioning among Veterans with PTSD. Dr. Morland (PI) and Dr. Sippel (PI) propose to examine the effects of couples' therapy for PTSD augmented with intranasal oxytocin, a neurohormone that affects mechanisms of trauma recovery and social behavior, on Veterans' PTSD and psychosocial functioning, and both Veterans' and partners' relationship satisfaction. The study will also explore the impact of intranasal oxytocin on potential mechanisms of action. Brief Cognitive-Behavioral Conjoint Therapy will be combined with intranasal oxytocin or placebo condition to determine the efficacy of the oxytocin augmentation, thereby advancing knowledge of strategies for improving Veterans' psychosocial functioning by improving their personal relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reliable, timely surveillance data on the prevalence and incidence of diabetes among youth in the U.S. is needed to identify current and future healthcare and public health priorities. Ongoing estimates are critical to determine the needs and monitor the effects of treatment to reduce complications and design effective prevention activities. It is of critical importance to identify groups or populations that might have increased burden or special health care needs related to diabetes.

PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-001 Surveillance of Diabetes in Children and Adolescents between 0-17 Years of Age (DiCAYA) - Component A

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Oregon Healthy Workforce Center provides outreach and education to OSHA Region 10 (Oregon, Washington, Alaska, and Idaho) and has broader national and international research dissemination impacts. Our research projects contribute to our theme of TWH intervention effectiveness and translation to advance safe and healthy work design. These projects all employ organizational and individual change strategies linked to outreach, education and dissemination, and translation strategies to produce health, safety, and well-being changes that can be scaled and shared broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Results from recent TCGA and pathological studies imply the oncogenic role for B7- H4 in breast tumor evasion and progression, although the underlying molecular mechanisms by which dysregulation of B7-H4 contributes to breast tumor evasion, progression and metastasis remain unknown. This proposal will determine the impact of interplay between glycosylation and ubiquitylation of B7-H4 in breast carcinogenesis and anti-breast cancer therapy, and further seek for new therapeutic strategy to enhance chemotherapy agent (such as doxorubicin)-induced immunogenic cell death through blockade of B7-H4 blockade for anti-breast cancer treatment, especially for triple negative type breast cancers. Completion of this project will uncover the tumor immune suppression role of B7-H4 in breast carcinogenesis, and could provide a new strategy for breast cancer therapy by targeting B7-H4 glycosylation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a Louisiana Natural Experiment Center (LNEC) to examine the impact of Zero-Dollar Copayment (ZDC) for select medications as part of disease management services to improve medication adherence for patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus in Louisiana where the prevalence of diabetes and mortality from cardiovascular disease are among the highest across all the regions of the United States. The intended outcome of the ZDC program to address cost-related non-adherence as part of the social determinants of health (SDH) is to inform, engage, and empower patients to achieve better health outcomes. The proposed LNEC will generate urgently needed data on effective, practical, and sustainable population-targeted strategies aimed at addressing SDH, eliminating health disparities, and reducing diabetes-related disease burden in the United States.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-002, Louisiana Experiment to Address Diabetes: Zero-Dollar Copayment (LEAD-ZDC) for Improving Disease Management

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative We aim to improve quality of life and well-being among breast and prostate cancer survivors by simultaneously targeting anti-racism training in clinical settings and using universal social determinants of health screening and referral to address such needs. Community health workers utilizing health information exchange in DC will be central to improving community-clinical linkages and decreasing social isolation among cancer survivors. Our long-term goal is to decrease cancer outcome disparities in the Washington DC region.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-003 Scaling Social Determinants of Health Screening, Social Support and Anti-Racism Training to Reduce Inequities in Minority Cancer Survivor Health and Wellbeing in Washington, DC

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: The Center for Health, Work & Environment will have high public health impact by meeting Region 8 and national needs for healthy and safe worksites and workers through its program of research, r2p, education/training, partnerships and other dissemination activities. It will advance scientific knowledge by establishing new, innovative worksite programs to benefit both workers and employers, test relevant theoretical models, and emphasize helping those working in small enterprises, and in other high-risk industries, including education and agriculture, among other sectors with high need.

PROJECT_TITLE: Center for Health, Work and Environment

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: HARVARD CENTER FOR WORK, HEALTH AND WELL-BEING: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE The Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health Center for Work, Health, and Well-being aims to improve the health, safety, and well-being of working populations by conducting research to identify working conditions that influence worker health outcomes; testing intervention methods to improve these outcomes; and translating this research into best practice and policies. The Center additionally seeks to understand and characterize disparities in workers’ exposures and health outcomes in relation to socioeconomic position, race/ethnicity, and age, in order to guide recommendations to address those disparities. The Center will respond to the need for an evidence base that will inform development and implementation of effective workplace and public policies in promoting and protecting worker safety, health, and well-being.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health Center for Work, Health and Wellbeing

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE (OVERALL CENTER) The Utah Center for Promotion of Work Equity Research (U-POWER) envisions work and workplaces that are safe, healthy, and equitable, and has the mission of U-POWER is to create a sustainable community of practice that changes the conditions of work and advances Total Worker Health® (TWH) through research and outreach. The integrating theme of U-POWER is the role of power in defining work conditions that create and sustain inequity and ill health among workers. U-POWER will facilitate a community of practice that shares the concern of changing the conditions of work and advancing TWH and advance TWH through innovative research and outreach, guided by the translational research process and community engagement.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Utah Center for Promotion of Work Equity (U-POWER)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  New intervention technology to reduce the transmission of airborne diseases is vital to improve public health, and is especially needed within healthcare environments where workers are substantially more at risk of becoming ill. Irradiation with far-UVC wavelengths, specifically from 200-230 nm, is a promising solution which we have previously shown to be effective at inactivating airborne viruses and, unlike conventional UV irradiation, has shown promise as being safe for human exposure. This work will test the biological effects of far-UVC radiation upon the eyes and skin of mice; these results are necessary to evaluate health hazards from exposure to these wavelengths and are critical for the adoption of this new technology.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Testing health hazards from implementation of far-UVC irradiation as an intervention technology to reduce airborne disease transmission
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Narrative Currently there are 4.6 million young adults (18 to 44 years of age) with diabetes in the US and the incidence and prevalence estimates in this age group have been increasing. However, due to limitations of traditional surveillance strategies, it remains unknown whether these increases are in type 1 or type 2 diabetes. The proposed research will coordinate, develop, implement, and validate electronic-record based surveillance of diabetes in young adults, by subtype, to inform type-specific public health responses, assess disease burden, and identify priorities for type-specific health services.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-001 Electronic Health Record-based Surveillance of Diabetes by Type in Young Adults in Pennsylvania

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative – California Labor Laboratory The goal of our Total Worker Health Center, the California Labor Laboratory, is to describe, understand the causes of, and prevent or mitigate the health impacts of emergent working conditions, with a special emphasis on those vulnerable to those conditions, including members of racial and ethnic minorities; women; immigrants; low wage workers; persons with disabilities; and younger and older workers, especially those with existing chronic diseases. California not only has the largest population of any state, at just under 40 million, but it is among the most diverse in its racial and ethnic composition and in the mix of its industries and it has also been a trend-setter in work organization, with large proportion of the workforce not having a full-time, full-year job at a single workplace and not being directly hired by the firm for which the work is done. The proposed Center has a comprehensive research program of five projects focused on the health impacts of changes in working conditions and a comprehensive outreach program consisting of interdisciplinary training for health professionals and the public, development of a cadre of researchers devoted to understanding the health impacts of emerging work through a pilot grants program, consulting to groups of workers and firms on best practices for healthy employment, and development of a public policy agenda and engagement with policymakers to address the adverse impacts of working conditions through law and regulation.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: California Labor Laboratory (CALL)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UIC Center for Healthy Work’s mission is to remove barriers that impact the health of low wage workers in the increasingly contingent workforce. We aim to identify and promote employment programs, practices, and policies that will improve worker and community health locally, across the state, and throughout the nation. Our vision is a future of work that promotes inclusive and equitable opportunities for healthy work and healthy work is recognized as a social and structural determinant of health and a human right, a pathway to advancing systemic change and racial justice, and a significant contributor to workforce well-being.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: UIC Center for Healthy Work

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Results from recent TCGA and pathological studies imply the oncogenic role for CD73 in breast tumor evasion and progression, although the underlying molecular mechanisms by which dysregulation of CD73 by ubiquitin-proteasome pathway contributes to breast tumor evasion, progression and metastasis remain unknown. This proposal will determine the impact of CD74 proteolytic regulation by TRIM21 in breast carcinogenesis, and further determine the clinical relevance of modulation of CD73 turnover regulation in anti-breast cancer treatment, especially for triple negative type breast cancers. Completion of this project will uncover the molecular underling of CD73 ubiquitination by TRIM21 in breast carcinogenesis and tumor microenvironment, and could provide a new strategy for breast cancer therapy by targeting TRIM21-CD73 axis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the proposed Johns Hopkins P.O.E. Total Worker Health Center in Mental Health (POE Center) is to promote worker mental health and well-being through research, education, outreach and evaluation activities that integrate the psychosocial, organizational, and environmental contexts of worker health. Given the rapid evolution of who works, how they work, and where they work—changes that have accelerated given employer and governmental response to the COVID-19 pandemic—there is a need to identify and empower resilient systems for health protection and health promotion to maintain workforce functions, health, and well-being before, during and after crises, work the POE Center will address through research, education, evaluation, communication and dissemination activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Inhibition of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase 1 (PARP1) has emerged as a promising therapeutic treatment for multiple cancer; however there is an urgent clinical need for improving the specificity of PARP1 and lowering the off-target effects and toxicity. This study proposes to screen and validate small molecule compounds that specifically inhibit the Sam68-stimulated PARP1 activation. Findings from our study may aid rational development of a new class of PARP1 inhibitors for cancer treatment.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the Carolina Center for Total Worker Health (TWH) and Well-Being is to generate new knowledge and to improve worker health and well-being in North Carolina, the southeast region, and the nation. Center research activities to achieve this goal include launching pilot projects that focus on risks for adverse mental health, safety, and well-being outcomes using a TWH framework; emerging issues that can increase health safety risks for workers; and that prioritize research that is intended to protect essential workers. Other activities of the Center will build the TWH workforce capacity by mentoring a cadre of researchers in the application of the TWH framework, through education and outreach activities, and engaging workers and other key stakeholders in these efforts to ensure the work of the Center is relevant, and that findings can be translated into, and sustained, in practice arenas.

PROJECT_TITLE: Carolina Center for Healthy Work Design and Worker Well-Being

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes data and surveillance studies among children and adolescents are significantly limited in the United State, especially in the south-east region, where diabetes was found to be the most prevalent. This proposed study will build a surveillance system in Florida to monitor the prevalence and incidence of diabetes among children and adolescents in an accurate, cost-effective, and timely fashion. This study will generate important data to study the social and behavioral determinants of health among many other potential contributing factors that results in ethnic-racial and geographic disparities of the diabetes among children and adolescents, at both individual (e.g., individual health behaviors) and contextual levels (e.g., area-level access to metabolic control programs).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative: The goal of this proposal is to address the unmet need for a safe and efficacious version of L-asparaginase, an enzyme drug used to treat acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The clinical use of today’s FDA-approved L-asparaginases is complicated by life-threatening toxicities that result from the immunogenicity of these bacterial enzyme drugs and their L-glutaminase co-activity. Toxicity often severely limits their use in adult patients, whose cure rate is therefore significantly lower. Here we will perform IND-enabling studies of a novel L-asparaginase that is of mammalian origin (thereby reducing the immunogenicity of the drug) and that is totally devoid of the L-glutaminase co-activity (thereby reducing toxicity that arises from glutamine depletion). The safer L-asparaginase developed by this work will not only impact ALL treatment, but in addition will provide a new therapeutic and much needed option to additional hematological cancers (e.g. AML) and solid tumors (e.g. pancreatic) for which efficacy of this drug is expected based on pre-clinical studies.

This application seeks to develop new treatment options in an area of unmet need by using relevant laboratory models and treated patient samples, with the goal of identifying new drug targets that can be combined to elicit deep and durable responses, and consequently extend their lives.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We know that IUDs are highly effective to prevent pregnancy when used for emergency contraception (following unprotected intercourse in the last 3 days), but lack data for those who desire an etonogestrel (ENG) contraceptive implant in this situation. This proposal will identify the most effective way to start an implant for emergency contraception using a randomized controlled trial comparing pregnancy risk between those receiving the implant vs. the implant plus oral emergency contraception. Data from this project will inform clinical practice and add another option, the implant, for those desiring a long acting, highly effective contraceptive method when they present for emergency contraception.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Food insecurity is associated with maladaptive outcomes in every domain of child development, with long- lasting life and health consequences, but how it undermines child development is unknown. By using ecological momentary assessment to determine the directionality and timing between food insecurity and parent and child well-being, this research will identify how food insecurity works within a family to disrupt child development. Gaining insight into these processes will help shape the most promising set of solutions for this highly significant public health threat to millions of children’s immediate and longer-term health and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Streptavidin and biotin are used in many medical and research applications, but endogenous biotin interference and streptavidin’s immunogenicity attenuates its effectiveness. Biotin orthogonal streptavidin system (BOSS) is a streptavidin system that has no endogenous biotin interference and low immunogenicity. BOSS could potentially improve cancer treatment, disease diagnostics and scientific assays.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Ischemic stroke is a devastating neurological disease affecting millions of Veterans. There is now an urgent need to understand the underlying mechanisms of stroke brain injury and to develop therapeutics against stroke brain injury. Stroke leads to brain ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI). Currently, there are no neuroprotective or anti-IRI drugs available for Veterans who suffer from stroke. This proposal will use a state-of-the-art animal model to study the underlying mechanisms of stroke brain injury and to study a potential therapy for minimizing post-stroke damage. If successful, this anti-stroke drug discovery program can be applied to fulfill the VA’s mission in alleviating Veterans’ suffering from the sequelae of stroke.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) have a 4-fold higher risk of developing colorectal cancer than those without IBD. While current practice advises follow-up examinations at fixed intervals for early detection of cancer, this “one-size-fits-all” approach is not appropriate for all patients with IBD. Moreover, it is not supported by our modern knowledge of how cancer evolves from normal colon tissue. Unnecessary colonoscopies performed in patients with IBD at low-risk of developing cancer are costly (>$5million spent per year) and invasive, while patients at high-risk of cancer are not seen frequently enough. Mathematical models of cancer evolution incorporating patient-specific clinical and genomic data will revolutionize clinical prediction of colorectal cancer development in patients with IBD. These models will enable personalized care for each Veteran to effectively prevent cancer and improve patient lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dopamine signaling is thought to promote movement by differentially modulating the activity of different neuron types in the striatum, a process that goes awry in movement disorders such as Parkinson’s disease. However, the exact relationship between dopamine release, neuronal activity and movement are not fully understood. We have discovered that motor learning differentiates how the striatum’s different neurons encode movement and will elucidate the involvement of striatal dopamine signaling and synaptic plasticity in this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative New treatment recommendations for premenopausal women with high or intermediate risk hormone receptor breast cancer now include ovarian function suppression, to induce early menopause combined with anti-estrogen therapy resulting in near-complete estrogen deprivation. This abrupt menopause induction together with anti-estrogen therapy improves survival from cancer yet also places these women at risk of organ damage, including heart toxicity. Our pilot study suggests that asymptomatic declines in heart perfusion are observed over several months on this therapy. In this work we will study women with serial heart imaging to more fully understand the impact of this treatment on small and large heart vessels, as well as to study if there are patient characteristics, blood biomarkers or electrocardiogram changes which can predict who is at greatest risk for heart damage from near-complete estrogen deprivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is a debilitating disease, affecting ~5% of the US population, ranking third as a cause of mortality, with the commonest cause being chronic cigarette smoke exposure. This exposure leads to malfunction of cilia, hair-like projections lining the airway tract that beat in coordinated fashion to sweep inhaled pollutants and pathogens away from the lungs, as well as generation of reactive oxygen species that lead to mitochondrial dysfunction and eventually cell death. In this application, we are proposing to use a small molecule to enhance cilia function and utilize lung-targeting peptides to rescue mitochondria, thereby targeting the underlying pathophysiology of a disease that has not seen any new drug development in over two decades.

PHR: Pancreatic cancer (PC) is one of the most difficult human cancers to treat due to the inability to detect disease at an early stage and the lack of effective therapies. This proposal aims to study the role of ZIP4 and ZEB1, potential new markers and therapeutic targets in pancreatic cancer, in the biology of these tumors. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial biofilms exhibit multicellular behaviors that allow them to tolerate antibiotics and thrive in low nutrient environments. The goal of this proposal is to uncover how these collective behaviors emerge from single-cell-level properties and cell-to-cell interactions. This work is relevant to the NIH mission because it will lay foundations for new ways to target emergent behaviors that make biofilms extremely resilient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of accessible therapies amenable for application in the home setting is a major obstacle for treating patients who suffer from lower-extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD). The goal in this proposal is to evaluate the benefits of home-based, leg heat therapy (HT) on lower-extremity functioning and quality of life in patients with PAD. Since this intervention is non-invasive, non-pharmacological and widely accessible, there is high potential for this work to rapidly translate into clinical practice and result in significant improvements in patients’ lives. Bruno Roseguini, Ph.D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy is a common neurological disorder afflicting nearly 3 million Americans. Given that loss or reduction of inhibitory synaptic transmission in hippocampus is one potential mechanism resulting in emergence of epilepsy, a method to generate new hippocampal interneurons could have direct therapeutic consequences. Using porcine embryonic neural progenitor cells and rodent model of temporal lobe epilepsy or epilepsy-autism disorder we propose to develop a novel interneuron-based cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Cleft palate is a common structural birth defect and accounts for ~33% of all cases of orofacial clefts (OFCs). Cleft palate is highly heritable, suggesting it can be caused by genetic factors. However, in contrast to other types of OFCs (e.g., cleft lip and cleft lip with cleft palate), genetic studies of cleft palate have been sparse and much of the genetic risk is still unknown. The goal of the current study is to comprehensively identify genetic risk variants for cleft palate using whole genome sequencing of CP trios and transcriptome data from human palate tissue.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bedrest, deep sedation, and delirium are common in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) and can have long-lasting negative effects for children and their families. Early mobility and exercise in the intensive care unit can improve outcomes for adult patients, but the effects in children are unknown. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the potential benefits of a team-based strategy to improve sedation practices and prevent delirium with the goal of increasing early mobility in the PICU.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Program Narrative  Despite many recent advances in treatment of prostate cancer, it remains a major cause of cancer-related death in American men. The investigators in our multi-disciplinary team will apply their complementary expertise to investigate fundamental mechanisms of prostate cancer progression, metastasis, and treatment resistance in order to provide new insights into molecular pathways and targets for improved therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Our proposed studies of the tumor microenvironment in prostate cancer are based on accumulating evidence that immune cells and stromal cells surrounding the tumor provide important signals that can accelerate progression of the disease. Furthermore, the primary treatment for advanced prostate cancer (hormone therapy) affects these immune and stromal cells in addition to the tumor cells, and we have limited insight into how these unintended treatments effects influence clinical outcome. The work in this Project will provide greater clarity on how the tumor microenvironment enhances tumor growth and help pave the way to better treatments, including improved use of hormone therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Over 200 million contact sport athletes and military personnel are at risk of developing chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), a neurodegenerative disease associated with exposure to repetitive head trauma with no current diagnostic or therapeutic strategies. This proposal will examine a promising potential mechanism of disease, microglial lysosomal dysfunction, to better understand its contribution to CTE pathology onset and progression. The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because it will contribute to our understanding of how repetitive head trauma can lead to CTE and follows the NIH mission to develop novel diagnostic biomarkers and therapies to lessen the morbidity and mortality of neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As one of the leading causes of death world-wide, diabetes cases are steadily rising each year contributing to an increasing concern and need to understand the mechanisms of diabetes disease progression. This study aims to unravel the mechanisms of arginine transport that contribute to pancreatic islet α-cell proliferation and glucagon secretion which contributes to hyperglycemia in diabetes. In addition to possibly identifying new targets to combat diabetes, support from this diversity fellowship will provide invaluable training to support my development as a future independent diabetes research scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The primary site of prostate cancer metastasis is bone, which is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Our studies employ novel in vivo models and molecular approaches to elucidate tumor cell intrinsic and tumor cell extrinsic mechanisms underlying bone metastasis. Our studies aimed at understanding the molecular causes of bone metastasis may provide new insights for early detection and new opportunities for treatment that may ultimately improve the outcome of patients with bone metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Our proposed studies are highly significant at the translational level since neuroendocrine differentiation represents a common mechanism of treatment resistance for castration-resistant prostate cancer. We will pursue a comprehensive analysis of neuroendocrine differentiation in both development and cancer to provide a unique perspective for delineating the molecular mechanisms of treatment-induced transdifferentiation in prostate tumors. Our analyses should identify molecular targets that are specific for neuroendocrine prostate cancer, which can be utilized to block the emergence of this highly lethal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While obesity pharmacotherapies are promising adjuncts to lifestyle modification therapy for the treatment of pediatric severe obesity (defined as body mass index ≥1.2 times the 95th percentile or BMI ≥35 kg/m2; the fasting growing obesity category), there is substantial variability in their individual-level effectiveness. This proposal will assess person-specific characteristics associated with weight loss response to and affecting dosing of obesity pharmacotherapies using techniques that can be employed in precision medicine approaches: electronic health record-enabled clinical discovery, genetic risk scores (estimates of genetic propensity), and pharmacometrics (studies of drug dose-exposure-response relationships). We will apply these techniques to topiramate as an example pharmacotherapy given this medication’s ubiquity of use and significant variability in individual-level effectiveness in youth with severe obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research project is aimed at elucidating the role of RNA and RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) in regulating histone deacetylase (HDAC) recruitment to gene targets. This molecular understanding has the potential to identify highly precise therapeutic targets for inhibition of HDACs in cancers where HDACs are overrepresented. Thus, the proposed work is relevant to the NIH mission of health as it could lead to improved cancer treatments with fewer side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) have transformed cancer treatment, but may cause cardiac inflammation (or myocarditis) which may lead be serious and even fatal. We propose to study the underlying mechanisms of ICI-associated heart damage, specifically studying the role that specific immune cell populations play in driving this fulminant complication. This study will provide significant insights into the biological basis of ICI- cardiovascular toxicities and enable more effective screening and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will investigate existing knowledge gaps related to the development of drug resistance to common medications for HIV among a large, well-characterized cohort of children and adolescents living with HIV in western Kenya. The proposed research is highly relevant to public health since it will fill knowledge gaps in the scientific literature, which will lead to better interpretation of drug resistance tests in this population, improve clinical management and reduce HIV-related sickness and death. The long-term goal of this research is to provide evidence to improve clinical guidelines and disease management for children and adolescents living with HIV in resource-limited settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The Pathobiology Core A will provide all Program investigators multiple pathology services. Core A is essential for the success of all projects via the expertise provided in pathological characterization of mouse and annotated human tissue. Further, Core A will provide expertise in generation and use of 3-dimensional organotypic and organoid models, performing scRNASeq experiments in highly annotated human tissue and sophisticated imaging for in situ localization of antibodies and genes discovered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We need to understand how differences in our genomes, coupled with environmental factors, translate into changes in specific biological processes to explain the vastly different outcomes among individuals when faced with an infection or in terms of their disease risk for having autoimmune conditions or cancer. However, human genome is complex even when studied as a linear DNA sequence and its three-dimensional folding, which itself is impacted by differences in this sequence, adds another layer of complexity to interpreting how cells utilize over a million different control switches to orchestrate a specific gene expression program that is precise yet flexible. This project uses human immune cells to study how differences in genome sequence lead to changes in genome function, and in turn disease risk and outcome, through calibrating genome’s three-dimensional organization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromatin - the physiological form of our genomes - is composed of histone proteins and DNA. Chemical modifications of histones and the factors that do so play essential roles in the cell. This project focuses on how chromatin adaptor proteins help decode this chemical language and how they regulate gene expression. These studies will improve our understanding of how protein complexes assemble on chromatin and how disruption of these basic mechanisms lead to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will determine the importance of hybrid peptide specific T cells for the breakdown of immunological tolerance and initiation of autoimmune type 1 diabetes. The goals of this proposal are to determine if HP-specific CD4+ T cells initiate T1D and if targeting them can lead to tolerance as a prevention or cure for T1D. The second goal of the grant is to develop a gene signature from known pathogenic cells in NOD mice and identify the same subset in human T1D patients. Completion of this project could lead to better biomarkers to predict T1D risk and disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Much of human perception and behavior is governed by functioning brain networks. This project will develop a method for generating human cortico-striatal organoids from stem cells and demonstrate that these organoids can be used to model the development of human cortico-striatal networks. The ability to create patient-specific cortico-striatal organoids for use in a variety of laboratory analyses will provide a new approach to enable patient-specific diagnostics and treatments associated with disorders of cortico-striatal connectivity, including autism, schizophrenia, epilepsy, and mood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Influenza A virus (IAV) is one of the major causes of seasonal influenza, being responsible for an average of 36,000 deaths in the US each year. Despite the fact that variation in glycosylation is a major mechanism whereby the virus escapes immune surveillance, there has been no systematic effort to correlate site-specific IAV glycosylation with viral immunogenicity. In this proposal we will use state-of-the-art mass spectrometry, antigenic cartography, and computer modeling of glycosylated surface antigens from multiple strains of IAV to elucidate this understanding, with the expectation that it will facilitate the development of more effective vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some patients with Crohn Disease have a yeast called Debaryomyces hansenii present within their ulcers, and mouse models of intestinal injury show that this yeast impairs intestinal healing. The research described here will help understand the mechanisms through which this yeast persists within the intestine and how it blocks injury repair. This project will increase our understanding of how microbes that are associated with Crohn Disease can affect disease course, with the goal of identifying new targets for future therapeutic development to benefit Crohn Disease patients with D. hansenii infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human T cells that have been engineered with receptors called CARs have been very effective in leukemia and lymphoma, but frequently cause severe side effects called cytokine release syndrome and neurologic symptoms. We aim to prevent these side effects by giving a drug called anakinra, which blocks an immune cell product called interleukin-1, because we think that the interleukin-1 drives a lot of the side effects but is not necessary for the anti-tumor effects of the CAR T cells. In this proposal, we will analyze the data from our clinical trial to see the anakinra worked to decrease the side effects, and we will measure the levels of molecules related to interleukin-1 in the blood and the spinal fluid around the brain; these measurements will enable us to map the relationships among immune cells and understandt what drives the side effects of CAR T cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Application Identifier: 364510 Application Project Title: Advancing KNX100 for the treatment of opioid withdrawal: preclinical efficacy and toxicology, and a phase 1 clinical program. Project Narrative The proposed research program will provide a major advance in public health by delivering a novel treatment for opioid withdrawal symptoms. Opioid addiction currently causes more deaths than car crashes, firearms, or breast cancer in the USA and is a public health issue that must be addressed with the greatest of urgency. Effective management of withdrawal symptoms in patients with opioid use disorders is a key barrier in the successful rehabilitation of such patients and the current research program will accelerate the development of a revolutionary new treatment for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This renewal will expand our investigations of the developmental regulators Pax2 and the related gene Pax8 into adult kidneys, using novel genetic mutations and biochemical methods to define their functions in the inner and outer medulla where regulation of urine concentration occurs. An essential role for Pax genes and proteins in activating and maintaining the expression of urea, water, and ion channels in the collecting ducts of adult kidneys will be examined. Furthermore, cell type specific mutations and single cell analyses will examine how Pax genes contribute to the regeneration of proximal tubule epithelia after acute kidney injury and to promote recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative With this research we hope to untangle the complexities and challenges that have been encountered when trying to correlate the vast number of new mutations in discovered in calcium channel genes in individuals with diverse and overlapping neurological and neuropsychiatric symptoms so we can develop treatments. We will take advantage of a new discovery we have made that these genes produce not one, but two distinct proteins, the calcium channel protein and a new protein called a transcription factor. We will determine how the two proteins function together, how, with different mutations, this cooperation breaks down, and how to develop therapies by correcting the breakdown in integration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual minority women (SMW) are at increased risk of engaging in hazardous drinking compared to heterosexual women because of their disproportionate risk of psychosocial stressors, including violence exposure (eg, sexual assault) and sexual orientation-specific minority stressors (eg, homophobic discrimination). Despite the public health necessity of developing effective alcohol treatments for SMW, current alcohol treatment models do not consider unique mental health needs or psychosocial stressors facing this racially diverse, at-risk population. This proposed research aims to use epidemiologic, lab-based, and multi- method longitudinal approaches to develop and test a biopsychosocial model that can both identify SMW subgroups such as SMW of color for targeted prevention efforts and inform effective alcohol interventions for diverse victimized SMW at greatest risk for alcohol use disorders (eg, those engaging in hazardous drinking).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The heart's fibrotic response rapidly progresses heart disease to failure, yet to date effective antifibrotic therapies to manage or reverse fibrosis are lacking. This proposal will investigate the cellular and molecular determinants of the heart's fibrotic responsiveness and define the dynamic processes of key phenotype transitions at the cellular level, which could be leveraged for targeted therapeutic interventions for slowing or reversing fibrosis in the heart and other tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the fastest growing cause of cancer-related death in the United States and innovative strategies for detection, prevention, and treatment will depend heavily on mouse models. The current HCC models are inadequate because they do not take into account the biology of their cells of origin, a problem which we will address using lineage tracing and genetic manipulation experiments in a large panel of CreER mice we developed to label a broad range of specific hepatocyte subpopulations. Success in this project will provide the community with a large panel of important tools and allow the field to focus on important subpopulations that contribute to HCC biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking is a leading public health problem, especially for adults living with HIV (ALHIV), who have higher rates of smoking and more cardiovascular disease than the general population. Poor sleep is more prevalent among ALHIV, more prevalent among smokers, can be caused by smoking cessation attempts, predicts relapse to former smoking patterns, and is linked to multiple comorbidities including cardiovascular disease. This study will prospectively test a novel sleep health intervention in ALHIV smokers to determine if it improves sleep health and enhances quit rates, and whether improvements in cognition and affect mediate the relationship between sleep health and smoking cessation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy (FLIM) is a type of fluorescence imaging technologies that is gaining popularity in biomedicine because it delivers the most direct insight into the molecular conformation and the biological environment of a fluorophore. This project will address the key imaging speed challenge that limits FLIM’s widespread application by reducing the instrument response function and increasing the maximum photon counting rate. In addition, two-photon excitation will be utilized to reduce the phototoxicity and machine learning framework will be developed to accelerate the FLIM data analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Teams with diverse perspectives outperform those with more limited perspective. Programs that promote a diverse scientific workforce are the essential to continue the tradition of scientific excellence in the United States. This proposal seeks funding for an undergraduate research program that enables students from underrepresented backgrounds to carry out research and participate in academic and professional development events during their junior and senior years. These activities will prepare students to gain entry into and excel in PhD and MD/PhD programs nationwide, empowering the United States to remain the world-wide leaders in scientific research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthcare provided in intensive care units often fails to meet the needs of patients who are near the end of life, their families, and their clinicians. This study will investigate a new model of care for patients with respiratory failure called a time-limited trial, which includes a trial of life support, clear milestones, and a timeline to help evaluate whether the patient is recovering. The knowledge generated in this proposal will be used to ensure medical decisions for patients with respiratory failure reflect their individual goals, values, and priorities, and can be extended to patient populations with other serious illnesses in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Nearly half of human cancers overexpress long interspersed element-1 (LINE-1) transposable element. We have found that this expression creates unique molecular requirements for cell growth. Here, we will test the hypothesis that these pathways are required to eliminate LINE-1 retrotransposition intermediates and prevent collisions between these intermediates and DNA replication forks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatocellular carcinoma is third most common cause of cancer-related death worldwide. Recurrence after curative surgery is influenced by interactions with white blood cells in the immune system. The proposed research will explore the impact of a novel immune-based systemic therapy given before surgery. We will obtain patient tissue and blood to define the mechanism of this novel treatment combination, and identify factors associated with response or resistance that can be used in future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative DTCs may lie dormant for years prior to becoming activated to generate a lethal metastatic disease. This project aims to understand the molecular mechanisms which regulate dormancy. This knowledge will be used to develop a rationale for therapeutic targets focused on dormancy signaling to either prevent relapse or specifically activate tumor growth in an adjuvant setting so that conventional chemotherapeutic agents targeting proliferating cells may be used as adjuvant therapy to eradicate DTCs in marrow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases are characterized by the untimely degradation of proteins by the 26S proteasome. Insights into the molecular mechanisms by which cells regulate the 26S proteasome can be used to devise new therapies. This research will aid efforts to develop drugs to treat cancers relying on the proteasome for survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative It is proposed that cells in the bone marrow known as ‘tumor associated macrophages’ engulf dead and dying cancer cells and in return produce factors that further support tumor growth. This project will identify the critical steps in this process, determine the impact of a specific cell surface signal in the support of tumor growth in the bone marrow, and identify targetable strategies to inhibit the process and provide resolution. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs) are heterogeneous genetic diseases with defects in neuron function, but molecular mechanisms underlying these pathologies remain poorly understood. The goal of this study is to elucidate the mechanism by which high-confidence NDD risk gene ZNF462 promotes epigenetic silencing of non-neural genes to ensure neural cell identity. Our studies will provide important insights into the precise regulation of facultative heterochromatin-mediated gene repression, and will identify strategic paths toward novel therapies for NDDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most frequently mutated gene in cancer is TP53; however, it has been difficult to directly target this gene with drugs. We have discovered that a distinct family of phosphoinositide kinases encoded by the genes PIP4K2A and PIP4K2B create a synthetic lethality when deleted in the context of TP53 mutant tissues in mice or in human breast cancer cell lines. This work will define how this liability can be exploited in order to identify opportunities for therapeutic intervention for patients with TP53 mutations, especially in triple negative breast cancer where targeted therapies have not been effective.
