IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Although artificial intelligence (AI) based computer aided diagnosis systems have been shown to be useful in lung cancer screening and diagnosis, current radiology practice still suffers from (1) high rates of missed tumors and (2) imprecise lung nodule characterization (malignant vs. benign). The goal of this proposal is to create novel AI algorithms, called radiologist-centered AI, which tightly integrate in real time the radiologist's reading pattern and AI via an eye-tracking device and to demonstrate their improved efficacy via lung cancer screening experiments using low-dose CT scans. The outcome of this research will be a virtual cognitive assistant (VCA) for radiologists, truly actively collaborating with them instead of passively acting as second opinion tools or replacing them, and ultimately further reducing lung cancer-related deaths.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic insufficient sleep during the school week is an ever present concern for children and adolescents with consequences particularly for attention and impulsivity. We currently lack an ability to mechanistically detect which child will be most vulnerable to insuffient sleep. To address this need, we propose an at-home sleep restriction experiment mirroring a school week, with neuroimaging, performance testing, and assays of neural arousal and circadian timing to untangle factors altering children with severe attention and impulsivity experience the consequences of sleep loss.

PHR: Project Narrative This cluster randomized trial is relevant to public health because it is the first implementation science study to develop and evaluate community-level working groups that aim to reduce household burning of plastic waste, a common exposure in rural low-income communities globally. Findings will be used to develop impactful community-driven public health actions in socially- and environmentally-disadvantaged communities in rural Guatemala. The project is relevant to the NIEHS mission because it fosters collaboration between research and community groups in the conduct of community-engaged research that aims to improve household and ambient air quality.

PHR: Project Narrative Because the disease risk experienced by an individual is intimately tied to the evolutionary history of the population, a better understanding of the evolutionary forces that contribute to risk in modern day people will help improve clinical practices and personalized care. Using Native Hawaiians and Latinos as examples, the results of the research program proposed in this application will provide a better understanding of the demographic and adaptive histories, and elucidate the evolutionary etiology for elevated risks of diseases such as obesity, type-2 diabetes, and childhood leukemia, in these understudied populations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Regional myocardial ischemia that leads to myocyte necrosis results in focal scar formation and a reduction in ventricular systolic function. Initially, myocardial and cellular remodeling serve to compensate for decreased systolic function by maintaining stroke volume and systemic perfusion. However, progressive remodeling can become injurious leading to further myocyte loss and decompensation. One pivotal factor that determines the degree to which remodeling occurs is the constitutive properties of the focal scar. Data suggest that there is a direct relationship between replacement scar stiffness and subsequent ventricular remodeling. Therefore, to improve outcomes for Veterans who suffer myocardial ischemia and infarction it is critical and necessary to define the cellular, molecular and biomechanical processes that govern and determine myocardial scar physical properties. Accordingly, we have focused our research efforts on defining the role of one novel cellular mechanism and its molecular determinants in myocardial ischemia induced scar formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy and frequent alcohol use remains a key public health concern, particularly among young adults. The proposed work will collect intensive momentary assessment data to examine associations between higher-risk alcohol use episodes (binge, high-intensity, blackout drinking) and multiple indices of next-day (post- intoxication) cognitive functioning. By identifying the acute impacts of varying levels of alcohol use intensity on next-day cognitive functioning as well as the day- and person-level characteristics that moderate these associations, our findings will have critical implications for the role of alcohol use on everyday cognitive functioning and highlight subgroups most in need of monitoring and early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of the MARC program at the University of Texas at San Antonio is to provide a comprehensive evidence-based training and support infrastructure that enables underrepresented undergraduates at UTSA to develop as biomedical and behavioral scientists who transition into, and complete, doctoral level training programs (e.g. Ph.D. or M.D./Ph.D.). Our trainees will contribute to public health by enhancing the creativity and productivity of the national biomedical and behavioral workforce. Those who follow an academic path will also help to diversify the nation’s universities as faculty who are more representative of all Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term goal of the Indiana Genomics Research Training Program for Data Scientists (INGEN4DS) is to increase the diversity of the genomics workforce by producing well-trained data scientists with genomics expertise. Training will be available for 8 students each year with the goal of these students joining the genomics workforce or matriculating into PhD programs in genomics. This goal will be accomplished by providing hands-on training with genomics data and participation in state-of-the-art genomics research in areas relevant to human health, such as cancer and rare genetic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Liver damage induced by chronic alcohol drinking (alcoholic liver disease, ALD) remains an important health problem in the United States and ranks among the major causes of morbidity and mortality in the world, and affects millions of patients worldwide each year, with no accepted therapy available to halt or reverse this process in humans. The recent preliminary studies in our laboratory demonstrated that chronic alcohol exposure is associated with increased expression of nicotinamide N-methyltransferase (NNMT) in the liver. Our further investigations suggest that NNMT inhibition confers protection against alcohol-induced fatty liver development, suggesting that NNMT plays a pathological role in the development of ALD and represent an ideal therapeutic target for the clinical intervention. In this proposal, we will utilize state of the art approaches to test our hypotheses using both cell culture and animal models.

PHR: Narrative Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus, GAS) is responsible for human diseases of the respiratory tract, skin, connective tissues, and circulatory and immune systems. This proposal seeks to investigate the underlying mechanisms explaining how this bacterium suppresses effective immune responses. These experiments are important to determine whether inhibiting the bacterial immunosuppressive activities is a viable strategy to treat or prevent infections.

PHR: OVERALL Project Narrative This program project grant application focuses on the DNA tumor viruses, Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), Kaposi Sarcoma-associated Herpesvirus (KSHV), and human papillomavirus (HPV) to identify the critical mechanisms by which these agents induce human cancer and deregulate cell growth. The projects will investigate how these viruses modulate cellular processes including cell signaling pathways, epigenetic networks, and immune evasion and will explore potential therapeutics to treat virus-associated cancers.

PHR: Project 2: Project Narrative A subset of HPV types are the causative agents of cervical cancer and are also associated with an increasing number of oropharyngeal squamous carcinomas (OSCC). EBV and KSHV are also found in the oral cavity and cause oral cancers. Similar to HPV, EBV and KSHV link their replication cycles to epithelial differentiation. Our studies focus on the influence of RNA molecules (R-loops and long non-coding RNAs) in the life cycle of HPV as well as KSHV and EBV in the oral epithelium and their effects on viral pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying youth victims of violence most at risk for long-term post-traumatic distress is a pressing public health problem. This work seeks to identify dysregulation in neural circuitry supporting cognitive and affective processes two weeks after victimization predicts PTSD and other post-trauma symptom twelve months later. These data will advance our understanding of neurobiological factors associated with vulnerability to specific trauma-related pathology and provide an important step toward identifying appropriate early interventions in the wake of violence victimization.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) impacts 1.7 million people per year in the United States5. TBI often results in chronic changes in cognition and mood that we cannot effectively treat3,4. The likelihood of sustaining a brain injury is increased for military personnel. 15-20% of soldiers serving in Iraq and Afghanistan experienced a TBI during deployment6. The proposed research investigates the brain mechanisms contributing to persistent cognitive deficits following frontal TBI. Preclinical models are necessary to employ invasive techniques to measure, manipulate, and restore brain activity that will ultimately inform human TBI research. The current proposal aligns with the VA’s mission to identify clinically relevant biomarkers used to predict patient outcomes and assess treatments for Veterans. New treatment options follow a precision medicine approach: targeting a specific brain area/function that is individualized based on each unique trauma. This research tests the effectiveness of precision stimulation to remediate cognitive behaviors after TBI by restoring brain activity through neuroplasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project 4 Project Narrative The goal of this research program is to determine whether Epstein Barr virus alters the growth or cellular expression of HPV infected cells through transfer of EBV proteins or BART noncoding RNAs. The BART RNAs, which are the most abundantly expressed viral genes in vivo, can be processed to express 44 miRNAs or are intricately and distinctly spliced into multiple long noncoding (lnc) RNAs. This proposal will also assess the effects of the BART RNAs on cell growth properties and determine how the lnc RNAs affect cellular expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to develop effective strategies to mitigate the cardiotoxic effects of breast cancer therapies and to improve cardiovascular health in breast cancer survivors. We propose a randomized controlled trial of intensive systolic blood pressure (SBP) control (goal SBP <120 mm Hg) versus standard SBP control (goal SBP <140 mm Hg) among 130 patients with breast cancer at risk for cardiotoxicity due to hypertension and treatment with cardiotoxic cancer therapies. Results will: 1) establish critical data to inform clinical implementation of an intensive SBP control strategy for patients with breast cancer at risk for cardiotoxicity, 2) provide functional and mechanistic insights into the effects of intensive SBP control on mitigation of cardiotoxicity risk, and 3) guide future cardio-oncology practice recommendations on the role of HTN management to improve cardiovascular health in patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Magnetic resonance (MR) is a safe method for brain imaging that does not rely upon ionizing radiation. We will develop MR detection of HDO generated from metabolism of [2H7]glucose as a sensitive biomarker of glucose uptake and metabolism in the brain. Our overall goal is to develop a robust, MR based metabolic imaging paradigm for detection of cerebral glucose utilization that can be applied to all areas of brain research and to clinical targets of brain dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Project Narrative This project is aimed to determine the neuropharmacological effects of compounds acting on glutamate transporters for the attenuation of alcohol consumption and alcohol relapse behaviors. The innovative features of this proposal are to reveal the pharmacological actions of promising novel beta-lactams to determine their pharmacological and therapeutic effects for the treatment of alcohol dependence. By the end of the project, we anticipate identifying at least one advanced molecule that possesses the drug-like properties and pharmacokinetic profile needed to qualify for advancement to development.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Translational Coordination and Dissemination Center (TCDC) for the Somatic Cell Genome Editing Consortium (SCGE) will support integration of activities across the SCGE Program, using the extensive expertise of the team of investigators and program staff at the Medical College of Wisconsin. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lysosomal storage diseases are caused by genetic defects leading to anomalous accumulation of metabolites in lysosomes, the degradative and recycling compartment of the cell. These toxic products, when accumulated in large amounts, can be harmful to humans. The identification of novel mechanisms that regulate autophagy and compounds that improve cellular and organ function would lead to novel treatments for several human diseases including lysosomal storage disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This partnership project between academic institutions (Johns Hopkins University and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign) and vaccine development company (Advanced Bioscience Laboratories) and associated CMOs is to accelerate the development of a vaccine candidate against enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC), the category B priority pathogens of NIH, serious threats of antibiotic resistance of CDC, and a top cause of children's diarrhea and travelers' diarrhea. Currently, there are no licensed vaccines for ETEC, but a unique multivalent subunit vaccine candidate (MecVax) developed based on a novel vaccinology platform is demonstrated to be broadly immunogenic and protect against ETEC clinical diarrhea and intestinal colonization in animal models. A broadly protective vaccine for ETEC can prevent >200 million diarrhea clinical cases and save nearly 100,000 lives annually.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol misuse is often associated with pathological aggression, a recurrent pattern of disruptive and violent behavior, with a staggering socioeconomic impact. The animal studies proposed in this application will identify the mechanisms underlying the common causes of these two conditions, as well as their reciprocal interac- tions. Our results may lead to the identification of new targets for the treatment and prevention of alcohol-asso- ciated violence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Washington State University ESTEEMED program (MIRA) will equip high achieving freshman and sophomores from underrepresented groups with the skills needed to complete their undergraduate degrees, matriculate into a graduate program, and pursue a career in biomedical research. Through the WSU MIRA program, a diverse and well-trained pool of scientists and engineers will contribute to creative and innovative health solutions allowing the United States to remain a world leader in biomedical sciences. Moreover, by increasing diversity in the biomedical sciences workforce MIRA will enable the United States to eliminate health disparities across the nation by providing an empathetic workforce that reflects all socioeconomic backgrounds.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tracheal intubation (TI) in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) is frequently complicated by adverse safety outcomes such as adverse tracheal intubation associated events, multiple TI attempts, and oxygen desaturation. We have developed, refined, and tested a Personalized INtubation Safety (PINS) Bundle that targets 5 evidence-based domains for a prospective and individualized approach to TI planning and management. We propose a pragmatic stepped wedge cluster randomized trial of NICU patients who are intubated across 8 participating hospitals to determine if the PINS Bundle, compared to no PINS Bundle, reduces the incidence of adverse tracheal intubation associated events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to advance the pre-clinical development of a broad spectrum Shigella vaccine consisting of Shigella flexneri (S. flex.) 2a, and S. sonnei O-polysaccharide (OPS) conjugated to Shigella IpaB (a highly immunogenic and protective Type III secretion system protein) using innovative technology: cell-free expression of IpaB and precise (site-specific) OPS-IpaB conjugation. S. flex 2a OPS-IpaB elicited robust immune responses in mice and afforded high levels of protection against S. flex 2a and S. sonnei lethal infection; a bivalent S. flex 2a and S. sonnei OPS-IpaB conjugate vaccine is expected to have broad efficacy and cover the most relevant disease-causing serotypes. UMB and Vaxcyte have partnered to refine and scale up vaccine production, assess vaccine efficacy and protective immunity in animal models, and establish cGMP manufacturing procedures in preparation for toxicology studies and clinical evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About half of women presenting for breast cancer screening in the U.S. have dense breast tissue, which makes cancer detection more difficult on mammography, even when performed as a tomosynthesis exam (3D mammography), and puts these women at a higher risk of delayed detection and breast cancer death. Yet, there is no consensus on which supplemental screening technique should be offered to improve cancer detection among women with dense breasts. In this work, we will perform the first multi-institutional trial (called Density MATTERS) to evaluate whether adding the functional imaging technique of molecular breast imaging (MBI) to tomosynthesis or performing MBI instead of tomosynthesis can improve cancer detection and reduce late-stage cancers, thereby providing a cost-effective, well-tolerated, and safe screening solution to reduce the burden of breast cancer in women with dense breasts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Deficits in neuronal circuit assembly in the visual system are implicated in a variety of disorders; thus, establishing correct wiring patterns of neuronal circuits during development is essential for proper brain functioning. The proposed research has high levels of public health relevance because we will combine circuit level insights on long-range neuronal connectivity development with gene expressions to illuminate a new way to determine novel therapeutic targets for neurodevelopmental disorders such as schizophrenia and autism. This work aligns with NIH’s mission to transform the understanding and treatment of visual disorders and mental illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although viral myocarditis is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, the mechanisms underlying viral myocarditis are not fully defined. The goal of the experiments described in this proposal is to define how pyroptosis, a pro-inflammatory mechanism of cell death, contributes to reovirus myocarditis. Defining the mechanisms of myocarditis induction is essential to an understanding the systemic disease and may foster development of therapeutics for treating viral heart infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will develop synthetic scavenger medical countermeasures (MCMs) for fentanyl. There is a growing need for new MCMs that can be used in conjunction with receptor antagonists like naloxone to overcome the limitations of current treatments, such as re-narcotization, low efficacy against potent opioids (e.g., fentanyl) and too high dosing. This exploratory research project will develop low molecular weight, highly potent synthetic scavengers of synthetic opiates as a novel MCM strategy that can be broadly applied to many Pharmaceutical Based Agents (PBAs).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatments that are currently available for antibody-mediated diseases such as the autoimmune blistering diseases, pemphigus vulgaris (PV) and pemphigus foliaceus (PF), are generally immunosuppressive, are associated with adverse events and/or have limited efficacy. To address these issues, in this application we propose to develop a novel treatment that selectively removes the autoreactive antibodies which are involved in the disease process, without affecting the levels of other antibodies that are important for protection against infectious agents such as bacteria and viruses. This approach has the potential to be a game-changer for the clinical management of PV and PF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although chemosensory dysfunction has serious physical and mental health consequences, loss of smell and taste was largely under-appreciated prior to COVID-19, having few evidenced-based interventions available for treatment. The present study will address this critical gap in healthcare by examining the use of smell training and trigeminal nerve stimulation to enhance olfactory function and associated impairments in mood and cognition. This study has the potential to significantly advance an area of science largely ignored, as well as improve the current standard of care for those suffering with chemosensory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Kainate receptors are ionotropic glutamate receptors important in synapse regulation and have been linked to neurological deficits including epilepsy, autism, mental retardation, and schizophrenia, making them important as pharmacological targets. Postsynaptic kainate receptors have been found to create a trans-synaptic junction with presynaptic Neurexin3β and extracellular scaffolding C1q-like protein as an intermediate. This proposal aims to investigate the functional and structural properties of this junction in order to understand the role this trans-synaptic junction plays in neuron function and correlate this junction with known behavioral deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study intends to use a new tonsil organoid platform to study molecular mechanisms regulating the human adaptive immune response to influenza. We will investigate how host factors and antigen factors regulate the magnitude and breadth of the influenza-specific antibody response in lymphoid tissues. This research will combine two novel technologies, immune organoids, and a high throughput antibody-detecting protein array, to elucidate the mechanisms of antibody affinity maturation and breadth in a fully human system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a disease of progressive obstruction and loss of the lung vessels with a median survival of slightly better than 5 years despite current therapies, with mortality resulting typically from right heart failure. This program seeks to identify the mechanisms by which dysregulated signaling of BMP9, which regulates pulmonary vascular homeostasis, may contributes to the pathogenesis of PAH. Novel strategies that selectively activate signals downstream of BMP9 may reveal the mechanisms responsible for its diverse effects on vascular integrity, and could represent novel strategies for treating PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal examines the neural underpinnings of how sensory information about space is processed by the insect brain to control navigation through the environment. Insects are vectors of human diseases and common agricultural pests, so understanding the neural mechanisms that control their navigation is highly relevant to global human health and wellbeing. Further, as spatial orientation is one of the cognitive functions that deteriorate early in Alzheimer’s disease, conserved neural circuit motifs identified in our studies may contribute to a better understanding of the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NYU LONG ISLAND SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains the primary cause of death worldwide despite availability of a substantial armamentarium to combat it. High LDL and low HDL are risk factors for CVD, hence, understanding their regulation could lead to the identification of novel targets useful for drug development. Here, we plan to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying how miR-541-3p decreases LDL and increases HDL. These studies should identify new proteins and mechanisms that may serve as potential targets to decrease the risk of CVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neurodevelopmental disability associated with prematurity, which leads to life-long morbidity and substantial personal and societal costs, is increasingly correlated to cerebellar insult. This proposal uses inducible genetic manipulation of cerebellar neurotransmission to undertake a comprehensive examination of the role of cerebellar function as it relates to circuit formation, neural function and animal behavior. This proposal has the potential to uncover causative mechanisms underlying a significant and growing cohort of patients with neurodevelopmental disability and may guide both preventative measures and disease modifying circuit manipulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We previously reported that type I interferon signaling induced in response to the asymptomatic liver stages of malaria parasite infection compromise protective adaptive immunity by inducing dysfunctional hepatic memory CD8 T cells. Using infection of the liver by malaria parasites as a model for hepatotropic infection, this application seeks to characterize malaria-induced hepatic CD8 T cell dysfunction to determine how hepatocyte-intrinsic type I interferon signaling reshapes hepatocyte transcriptomes and metabolomes to impair hepatic T cell immunity. Observations from this work will guide the development of highly efficacious liver directed anti-malaria vaccines.

PHR: Public Health relevant statement This project is to design, produce and conduct proof of concept experiments to test a novel therapeutic reagent that has the potential to rapidly activate immune defenses against many infectious diseases. The project builds on results from research on basic immunological mechanisms conducted over the past decade and on the combined expertise with protein engineering design and production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  As the number of older adults continues to rise, and the prevalence of individuals affected by neurodegenerative disease increases, understanding the interpersonal factors that contribute to caregivers’ health decline will become increasingly important. Identifying interpersonal mechanisms that promote or hinder caregivers’ health will point towards potentially modifiable factors that could reduce the collateral damage of neurodegenerative disease. Findings from the current research could facilitate the development of targeted and effective interventions to maintain the health of caregivers and the individuals for whom they care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative: The sudden and profound physiological changes in critically ill patients cause dramatic variations of concentrations of antibiotics that we actually deliver, away from those that are effective and, often, towards those that are harmful. In theory, this challenge can be addressed by high-frequency therapeutic drug monitoring, which would allow us to adjust delivered doses of antibiotics as these concentrations change – yet, in practice, there are no clinically validated analytical methods that can perform suitably rapid and cost-effective quantification of drugs. In this project, we systematically develop modular components, which, individually or combined, will enable precise and accurate measurements of antibiotic concentrations in real-time at the bedside.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This research will exploit novel features of the Atlantic killifish vertebrate model system to elucidate gene- environment interactions that contribute to chemical-induced congenital heart disease. Natural selection across dozens of generations has created wild killifish populations that diverge dramatically in sensitivity to chemical effects, and our prior results have provided a catalog of genetic variation among populations that underlies these differences. We will leverage this unique natural experiment to reveal the genes and pathways that contribute to chemical-induced congenital heart disease (CHD), a common human malformation associated with environmental exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Building on our recent discovery that antimalarial drugs display potent therapeutic and adjunct therapeutic efficacy against Mycobacterium abscessus infections, this research project proposes to thoroughly investigate the mechanisms underlying the therapeutic benefits of these drugs and to extend their use to the treatment of Mycobacterium avium infections. Success in this approach could be a short route to the clinic.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each of us has the potential to respond uniquely to a drug based on our genetics. Not understanding how a drug works in diverse groups of people can lead to serious inequities in health and wellbeing. Our preliminary data provides evidence that a drug called ulipristal acetate may not work as well for people with an active form of a certain gene (CYP3A5); the active form is more prevalent in Black individuals. We have designed this project to determine the impact of this gene and others on ulipristal acetate metabolism as this has important implications for its ability to prevent pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WESTERN MICHIGAN UNIV SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative B-cells play various critical roles in protecting against microbial invasions by secreting antibodies and cytokines, and dysfunction of B-cells causes immunodeficiency, autoimmunity, or leukemia/lymphomas. Emerging evidence has shown that not only innate-immune B-cells but also a portion of adaptive immune B cells originate from fetal progenitors, independently of hematopoietic stem cells. The objective of this project is to develop a landscape of the developmental process of all B cell subsets from fetus to adult, exploring the precise origins and functions, thus, contributing to filling the knowledge gap in B-cell biology.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) is an age-related marker of blood cancer and cardiovascular diseases. Early and pre-disease detection of rare somatic mutations associated with CHIP in clinically healthy normal-aging Nigerians is much needed as they could offer important prediction of the risk of developing hematological malignancies and provide information on potential targets of therapeutic interventions. This project will also enable me to acquire fundamental skills in error-corrected sequencing, variant analysis and data management critical for my establishment as an independent Africa-based medical geneticist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Measles causes a severe transient immunosuppression in healthy individual and severe complications in immunocompromised people. Recent U.S. outbreaks shows that 1 of every 600 measles infections in normal infants may also develop fatal measles encephalitis, underscoring the urgency of developing specific treatment for measles infection for the general population as well as for immune compromised individuals. Recent advances in our paramyxovirus research are ready to be applied to developing antiviral peptides to protect the individual and to halt measles host-to-host transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The interactions between neural stem cells (NSC) and the extrinsic microenvironment are poorly understood. The objective of this proposal is to address this gap in knowledge, enabling both optimization of therapeutic donor hNSC transplantation, as well as new insights into the in vivo consequence of signaling/transcriptional networks for hNSC localization and fate after SC. The long term impact of this work will be to elucidate novel mechanisms and roles of immune-NSC signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Kidney diseases are associated with significant comorbidities and mortalities and affect close to a third of the US population, yet their pathophysiology remains incompletely understood. Macula densa cells play pivotal roles in the maintenance of the normal structure and function of the healthy glomerulus and also in the development of glomerular injury in kidney diseases, yet their primary pathogenic role has been largely overlooked. We propose to study the role of macula densa cells and their neuron-like function in the normal and diseased kidney, and to develop new therapeutic approaches for glomerular kidney diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the burdens of families living with dementia, whose needs are not met by traditional health care models. This project will accelerate research on the effectiveness and implementation strategies of a remotely-delivered collaborative care model for dementia, the Care Ecosystem, in 6 healthcare systems. During this unprecedented time of heightened strain on family caregivers, health care providers and health systems, will identify the effects of the Care Ecosystem on outcomes important to patients, caregivers, healthcare providers, and healthcare systems, and we will identify strategies that will facilitate successful implementation and sustainment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because pulmonary embolism is one of the leading causes of death in hospitalized patients, and its rapid diagnosis is crucial to guide emergency treatment and decrease economic burden. Therefore, our project will develop an innovative machine learning algorithm that can transform the care of patients with pulmonary embolism by enabling non-experts to use echocardiography at the patient’s bedside to detect life-threatening pulmonary embolism, direct emergency therapy, and improve survival. Our proposal fits the NIBIB’s overall mission to improve healthcare through innovative engineering and, more specifically, to develop transformative unsupervised/semi- supervised machine learning technologies to enhance analysis of complex medical images and data for diagnosing and treating a wide range of diseases and health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The fetal environment substantially influences risk for severe mental illnesses (SMI), some of which do not fully emerge until early adulthood. The proposed studies will build upon our previous cross-sectional work suggesting that increased exposure to folic acid during early pregnancy confers protection against postnatal SMI risk through longitudinal effects on cerebral cortical development. We will conduct prospective MRI, clinical, and cognitive assessments of children who are at clinical high risk for SMI, to determine whether exposure to folic acid supplements early in pregnancy favorably alters their neurodevelopmental trajectories and risk for psychopathology in adolescence, and explore neural mechanisms that could mediate these effects.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health goals of the candidate's research program are to examine pathways linking sleep and pain, which is key to unlocking new advances in treatment to prevent chronic pain. If perioperative melatonin is shown to be feasible in a pilot trial, this will allow efficacy testing of this complementary treatment, addressing a critical need for non-opioid options to reduce pain. In addition, the candidate will expand her interprofessional mentoring program to rigorously train the next generation of patient-oriented pain researchers equipped to address the pain epidemic facing our nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF) is the commonest complication after open heart surgery and is a growing clinical problem. Also, POAF is no longer considered a transient one-time event as a longer duration of POAF is associated with worsened long-term survival and risk of AF recurrence. The studies in this research proposal will change the paradigm for the treatment of POAF following open heart surgery, and contribute significantly to the management of this common complication.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The pathogenesis of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) involves interactions between genetics, environmental and microbial factors, and immune responses with an inherent complexity making prevention and cure elusive. Current cohorts do not allow for characterization of the evolution of this multifactorial milieu before disease inception limiting our ability to predict disease. We aim, in a novel, pre-disease-inception, high-risk, familial IBD cohort to characterize the microbial and genetic contributions to IBD to allow for improved stratification of those at highest risk for developing IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Mosquitoes are exceptionally prone to dehydration due to high water loss rates, but few integrative studies have examined the comprehensive impact of dehydration on mosquitoes. In this study, we will characterize how periods of dehydration alter the behavior and physiology of mosquitoes, specifically in relation to their ability to act as disease vectors. Information generated from this proposed research will be critical to understanding the impact that water availability has on mosquito biology and pathogen transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is not known how the species safeguards its genome from the mutagenic insults of the fragile left-handed Z- DNA structure, which can form in the cells at simple repeat sequences. We discovered a natural biological process that eliminates Z-DNA structure in mammalian germ cells, and a novel DNA-binding protein that carries out this function, positing this protein as the guardian of the germ line. We will employ a combination of genetics, in vivo epigenome mapping, and in vitro biochemistry approaches to determine the molecular mechanisms and significance of managing Z-DNA structure in the germ line.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance The clinical development of antibiotics has led to unprecedented medical successes over the last century. However, despite these advances, bacteria-related infections remain a serious public health concern. Approximately 35,000 patients die every year in the United States alone. With the rare properties to both kill bacteria and potentially neutralize endotoxins in addition to overcoming common bacterial drug resistance mechanisms, AMP-based cationic peptide antibiotics (PAX) with properly optimized structures for systemic efficacy would constitute an effective therapeutic option for the treatment of MDR-related infections. We propose that PAX optimization can effectively overcome changes in lipopolysaccharide (LPS) or lipid A (a submolecular component of LPS) that confer resistance to AMPs, including bacterial resistance to the membrane-active cyclic lipopeptide colistin used as a drug of last resort against MDR gram-negative bacteria (GNB). Elucidating the molecular determinants for iterative PAX design will inform PAX optimization to overcome bacterial resistance. This proposal is a logical progression toward our long-term vision to turn PAX into an effective class of AMP therapeutics that can be designed and re-designed in response to clinical challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Medulloblastoma (MB) is the most common malignant childhood brain tumor, which accounts for large number of childhood cancer deaths. Despite the progress in treating MB, the 5-year survival rate for high-risk MB remains poor with high recurrence. These is a significant need to identify novel targets that treat the MB effectively with less side effects. We discover that RNA demethylase ALKBH5 may play an important role in MB growth and progression and therefore may serve as a novel therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will evaluate whether offering Somali women the opportunity to collect their own samples for HPV testing in primary care clinics is an effective strategy for increasing cervical cancer screening participation. Identifying effective and sustainable implementation strategies for HPV self-sampling in primary care could reduce disparities in cervical cancer screening among Somali patients. Findings may be transferable to other immigrant and minority groups facing similar disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutant p53 protein accumulation and MDM2B overexpression in cancer play critical roles in tumorigenesis. Currently, the mechanisms underlying mutant p53 accumulation in cancer and the tumor-promoting function of MDM2B are poorly understood. This proposed study aims to determine the role and mechanism of MDM2B in promoting mutant p53 accumulation and gain- of-function in tumorigenesis, and reveal the mechanism of MDM2B overexpression in cancer, which is crucial for the development of novel therapeutic targets and strategies for cancer carrying mutant p53.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL Native-like HIV envelope glycoproteins targeting B cells with the appropriate germline B cell receptor represent the most promising vaccine strategy so far but has only proven to be successful in a subset of vaccinees. Our Program will identify early determinants of broadly neutralizing antibody (bNAb) precursor induction, with a focus on the role of adjuvants and host microbiota, utilizing broad and integrated omics approaches to decipher the mechanisms associated with bNAb development. The results will inform future vaccine design and down- selection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to determine the role that socio-environmental contextual factors, including neighborhood socioeconomic status (SES) and the built environment, play in racial disparities in monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), the precursor to multiple myeloma. By measuring and thus disentangling the SES associations for MGUS by built environment attributes, we believe that potential new environmental influences may be illuminated as key factors for the racial disparities observed in incidence and prevalence of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: ! ! Project Narrative Lifecourse social and environmental circumstances may influence variation in risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRDs), including for US Latinos who face a disproportionate burden of both social adversity and exposure to pesticides via agricultural work. Yet, little is known about the unique and combined impacts of social adversity and pesticide exposure on ADRDs risk and risk factors, including for Latinos. In this project, we will leverage an ongoing cohort of Latina women living in an agricultural region and entering mid-life to study the relationship between early and mid-life social adversity, pesticide exposure, and ADRDs risk factors, measured via repeated cognitive assessments, brain biomarkers, and cardiovascular and inflammatory markers. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, is endemic in the Western US with potential to re-emerge as a deadly flea- borne zoonotic disease that can be transmitted from person-to-person. Although hundreds of years of research have led to a strong understanding of transmission and pathogenesis, there remains a lack of knowledge of the enzootic maintenance of Y. pestis and the factors that support an epizootic outbreak. This project addresses this gap by applying modern technologies to examine Y. pestis escape from the midgut and the potential for transovarial transmission to propagate infection in the flea vector thereby contributing to the enzootic maintenance of plague.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes are among the most abundant cells in the human brain, they are in close contact with nearly all synapses, and have emerged as important regulators of nearly every aspect of brain development, function and maintenance. Compelling evidence now exists that astrocytes participate in the processing of information in neural circuits and ultimately control behavioral output, but how they do this remains poorly defined. Our work will shed light on how astrocytes receive information from neurons and in turn modulate neural circuit activity, basic operational principles of the brain that are highly relevant to human brain function and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) is a lethal lung condition characterized by increased pulmonary artery pressures due to abnormal proliferation of endothelial cells in the blood vessels in the lung. Mitochondrial function and calcium levels are known to abnormal in PAH endothelial cells, but the link between dysfunctional mitochondria and calcium levels is not known. We hope to identify why mitochondria are dysfunctional in PAH endothelial cells, and how such dysfunction promotes abnormal calcium levels, with the hopes to discovering new therapeutic options for this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: There are many childhood cancers that have failed to respond to the latest advances in cancer therapeutics. Rather than target the protein that drives the cancer, we will eliminate the RNA that encodes for the protein that drives one of these, the usually lethal liver cancer, Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (FLC). Our underlying hypothesis is that we can design ways of eliminating the RNA for the driver that are more specific with fewer side effects and thus produce a more powerful therapeutic than if we had targeted the protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To be successful, an antibody-based HIV vaccine must reliably elicit at least 2-3 different specificities of potent, broadly neutralizing HIV antibodies. We have assembled a stellar team of investigators into the Multi-Omics Vaccine Evaluation (MOVE) Consortium to propose a streamlined approach for HIV vaccine development, enabled by deeply integrating advanced multi-omics techniques and sophisticated informatics throughout our experimental approach. The overall goal of this proposal is to accelerate development of an HIV vaccine by parallelizing the design and evaluation of promising immunogen candidates and rapidly discover an HIV vaccine that induces broad, durable immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is an important and growing public health problem among young people in the United States with consistently higher rates of suicidal behavior found among youth involved with the juvenile justice system. Little is known about factors associated with suicidal behavior unique to youth incarcerated in the justice system and even less attention has been given to the heightened risk for suicide in youth after they are released. To better inform targeted suicide prevention strategies, the proposed research will use advanced machine learning techniques to examine youth characteristics and conditions of the incarceration environment to identify youth at elevated risk for future suicidal behavior following their release from confinement in the juvenile justice system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section  Modest weight loss (>5% body weight) is the most effective strategy to help individuals with prediabetes prevent or delay type 2 diabetes mellitus. Most individuals with prediabetes, however, do not engage in evidence-based Diabetes Prevention Programs for weight loss, and healthcare systems currently lack effective, coordinated, and patient-centered strategies to successfully support patients’ weight loss with other evidence-based resources (e.g. behavioral change programs, pharmacotherapy). This proposal aims to develop and test an innovative, multilevel primary care-based intervention to support weight loss among adults with prediabetes through (1) personalized weight loss plans; (2) remote weight monitoring using home-based digital scales; and (3) proactive outreach to address barriers and/or adapt plans if target weight loss is not achieved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vibrio cholerae is the etiologic agent of the severe human diarrheal disease cholera, which is responsible for severe morbidity and mortality in developing countries around the world. These proposed studies will characterize Vibrio cholerae-gut microbiome interactions in the protective mucus layer of the gut during V. cholerae infection, with the goal of better understanding how V. cholerae using intestinal mucin to promote pathogenesis and interactions with resident microorganisms and the host, and, potentially, discovering novel therapeutic and prophylactic interventions for cholera.

PHR: Project Narrative We seek to train the next generation of social, economic, and health professionals to carry out theoretically informed, methodologically sophisticated interdisciplinary research on demographic and population studies focused on child health and human development. We provide trainees with rigorous cross-disciplinary coursework in theory, methods, and evidence in core disciplines including economics, sociology, and public health. Trainees are mentored intensively to promote their development into independent investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The primary aim of this proposal is to determine in a prospective observational study whether immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI’s) are associated with accelerated progression of coronary atherosclerotic plaque by serial measurement of coronary plaque using coronary CTA. In animal and basic studies, these same immune checkpoints are also critical negative regulators of atherosclerosis and blockade of these checkpoints in animal studies increased atherosclerosis. The use of ICI’s has increased and continues to rapidly expand; therefore, there is an urgent need to test in a clinical study whether ICIs lead to accelerated coronary atherosclerosis and to provide insights into the mechanisms involved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Wu, Xiaohua, TSRI Studying the mechanisms underlying the protection of common fragile sites and structure- prone DNA sequences Project Narrative  DNA sequences prone to forming secondary structures, such as AT-rich sequences present in common fragile sites (CFSs) and G-quadruplexes (G4s), are genetically unstable and are often associated with chromosomal rearrangement breakpoints in cancer. We aim to study the mechanisms underlying the protection of structure-prone DNA sequences in mammalian cells and explore the functional coordination of pathways involved in maintaining the integrity of these sequences. Our study will provide new mechanistic insights into how genome stability is maintained in mammalian cells and offer new therapeutic strategies for targeted cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novel therapies for the most common malignant pediatric brain tumor, medulloblastoma, are hindered by a lack of understanding of the roles played by host-derived cells at the local tumor site. This project aims to address this knowledge gap by studying how perturbations in tumor intrinsic kinase signaling alters the composition of the tumor microenvironment (TME) and modulates anti-tumor immunity. Understanding exactly how such pathways can influence the quality of the tumor immune response is a critical step towards garnering prognostic information from the TME cellular characteristics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy (SUDEP) accounts for between 8 and 17% of all epilepsy-related deaths and, although our understanding of SUDEP is rudimentary, there is increasing evidence that respiratory arrest after a convulsive seizure is the primary cause in many cases. In support of this, we have found that seizure-induced apnea that occurs during the tonic phase and failure of postictal breathing recovery produce SUDEP in mouse models. Using novel mouse models of SUDEP, we propose to use chemogenetic, optogenetic, and electrophysiological techniques to elucidate the underlying neural circuitry that is recruited to cause seizure-induced apnea and SUDEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of the tumor suppressor SNF5 (SMARCB1) is the established cause of rhabdoid tumors—rare and aggressive childhood cancers with few treatment options and high rates of mortality. This proposal explores the hypothesis that loss of SNF5 drives rhabdoid malignancy, in part, by activating MYC, an oncoprotein with an extensive suite of pro-tumorigenic functions. Completion of this work will expose underlying molecular mechanisms of rhabdoid tumors and reveal whether MYC is a viable target for therapeutic intervention in these cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD4+CD25+Foxp3+ regulatory T cells (Tregs) play a critical immunomodulatory role in atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) impacting chronic inflammatory responses. We have identified single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) that substantively alter CD39 ectonucleotidase expression on Tregs and appear to associate with the burden of ASCVD. We will study how these differences in CD39 activity cause aberrant inflammatory responses and determine how these pathways can best be corrected to treat this most important disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Pulmonary infection with Mycobacterium abscessus (pMAB) is particularly challenging to treat because this bacillus displays intrinsic antibiotic resistance to most front-line drugs. Tigecycline, the first tetracycline with a glycyl moiety, overcomes the common resistance mechanisms in rapidly growing mycobacteria but it needs to be administered via intravenous injection. The approach studied here is to develop tigecycline as inhalational therapy for pMAB.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Much like armor, Gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Escherichia coli) have a unique outer surface that prevents the use of many antibiotics making infections caused by these organisms extremely difficult to treat. This proposal will help determine the molecular machinery used by Gram negatives to assemble their outer surface providing new opportunities for the development of novel therapies to fight multi-drug resistant bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In Uganda, the prevalence of hypertension among adult persons living with HIV is 27.9% yet only 5% achieve control. Integrating screening and treatment of hypertension in HIV care is recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for dual control; however, there is limited implementation of this guideline. The goal of this project is to conduct an implementation science study to integrate hypertension screening and treatment into patient centered community HIV differentiated service delivery models in Uganda using the WHO HEARTS protocol to improve hypertension control in persons living with HIV

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunity generated by acellular pertussis vaccines wanes rapidly, and does not prevent nasal colonization or transmission. We will use state-of-the-art mass spectrometry and bioinformatics tools to identify novel immunogenic proteins from circulating B. pertussis strains that are presented on MHC Class II and recognized by CD4+ T cells. We will evaluate the immunogenicity, protective efficacy and roles in pathogenesis of these proteins using a murine model of Bordetella pertussis infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Caring for a loved one diagnosed with Alzheimer’s Disease is highly stressful. The proposed project will investigate the biobehavioral mechanisms underlying a novel cognitive emotion regulation intervention in unpaid primary caregivers of persons diagnosed with Alzheimer’s Disease or Alzheimer's Disease-Related Dementias (ADRD) by examining how thinking about an emotional stimulus in a more adaptive way can predict changes in health-related behavior via changes in negative affect and psychophysiological health-related biomarkers. This work may hold clinical significance in the development of new interventions to improve emotional health and well-being in caregivers of persons with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Computed Tomography (CT) images play an integral role in screening and diagnosing lung cancer, interstitial lung disease, and stroke. While quantitative image features can facilitate accurate characterization of diseases, these features are highly sensitive to variations in how the CT images are acquired and reconstructed, negatively impacting their reproducibility and the performance of machine learning models that utilize these features. This project investigates the effects of varying CT parameters on these image-derived features and uses that infor- mation to identify optimal techniques to mitigate their effects in a task-dependent manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Discoid lupus erythematosus is a chronic disfiguring autoimmune skin disease characterized by an immune cell infiltrate predominantly composed of T lymphocytes, which appear to promote tissue inflammation and damage, but how they do so is not well understood. I will perform translational immunologic research on human skin and blood samples with parallel studies in a mouse model to delineate the roles of key survival, inflammatory, cytotoxic, and other effector pathways in potentially pathogenic T lymphocytes, and to probe how they are regulated. These efforts will advance our understanding of discoid lupus erythematosus and help identify targeted strategies for treating this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this application, a groundbreaking abdominal CT imaging paradigm will be implemented to generate spectral CT images from a single-kV CT acquisition and translated into clinical practices for wide clinical dissemination. This new paradigm will enable quantitative spectral CT imaging for all current and future CT exams without requiring expensive hardware modifications. This new paradigm will provide precise medical disease diagnosis while facilitating clinical workflow, thereby reducing the overall healthcare cost in conjunction with reducing radiation risks associated with current CT imaging.

The proposed research is relevant to public health because they have the potential to provide a better understanding of which young children are at high risk of metabolic consequences of obesity. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE STATEMENT Kidney disease is a major public health problem due to high treatment costs, mortality, and high comorbidities with other major diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The overall goal of the study is to understand how DNA-dependent protein kinase (DNA-PK) suppresses genomic instability and prevents the malignant transformation of blood cells via its KU-dependent assembly and release on both DNA and RNA. Specifically, we will 1) analyze RNA vs DNA binding by KU and DNA-PK; 2) characterize the impact of acute KU-depletion on RNA metabolism, 3) the physiological functions of the C-terminal region (CTR) and tail of Ku80 in normal hematopoiesis and malignant transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is common and causes extensive morbidity and mortality and we have effective psychosocial treatments, in particular Cognitive Behavioral Therapies (CBT) and Motivational Interviewing (MI); however, less than 10% of patients with AUD receive treatment. Primary care is a critical setting for identifying patients with untreated AUD, but limited accessibility of specialty addiction treatment and other barriers prevent patients from initiating and receiving effective AUD treatment. This project aims to fill this gap by testing the impact of a novel telemedicine-delivered MI-CBT treatment intervention (MI-CBT TeleTx) compared to enhanced usual care (EUC) on AUD treatment utilization and alcohol-related outcomes among primary care patients with AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Inquiry into the effects of long-term prescription opioid use in patients with chronic pain are highly relevant and timely due to the increased epidemic of prescription opioid use in the US. Using quantitative sensory testing, neuropsychological assessments, multimodal neuroimaging and advanced statistical techniques for data analysis, the proposed study seeks to identify the effects of long-term prescription opioid use on the brain and their relation to clinical symptoms. By detecting changes at behavioral, molecular and neural systems levels, this study will be pivotal in the development of effective pain management strategies in chronic pain, and training of Dr. Jarrahi as an independent investigator in the field of translational pain research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Microtubule targeted agents (MTAs) are a mainstay in the treatment of breast and ovarian cancers; however, acquired resistance to these drugs remains a significant problem. In the proposed research, I will identify key determinants for the targeted use of MTAs for the treatment of ovarian cancer (F99 phase), and further employ mechanistically diverse MTAs to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of adipocyte-mediated resistance in ovarian cancer (K00 phase). The proposed F99/K00 training and research will determine mechanisms underlying taxane resistance and promote a more rational use of a class of mechanistically underappreciated drugs for the more effective treatment of women’s cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The Epicenter for Emerging Infectious Disease Intelligence will establish research hubs in the Amazon and Congo Basin forest for emerging infectious disease research, building on our demonstrated commitment to capacity strengthening in these regions. Our proposed research will enhance surveillance for arboviruses and filoviruses in acute febrile illness cases, vectors, and vertebrate hosts that are perpetuating transmission in forest and urban systems. This work will advance an understanding of cross-species transmission dynamics for emerging viral threats, as well as optimize innovative and deployable surveillance and testing strategies to strengthen infectious disease surveillance and enable rapid response to outbreaks as part of the Emerging Infectious Disease Research Center network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will evaluate the implementation and effectiveness of HIV testing and prevention services in community pharmacies to increase HIV testing access and prevent delayed HIV diagnosis that results in higher community transmission and poorer treatment outcomes. Successful development of this model could establish pharmacies as a sustainable, HIV prevention source, particularly for populations with lower access to HIV prevention resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a progressive vascular disease with high morbidity and mortality. Type 2 BMP receptor (BMPR2) mutations are the commonest genetic causes of PAH. This application aims to elucidate the molecular mechanism of activation of BMPR2 and its downstream signaling pathway, which is critical for the maintenance of the healthy pulmonary vasculature and mitigating PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Underserved, racial and ethnic minority communities are experiencing higher rates of COVID-19 cases and associated mortality compared to whites due to long standing social and structural inequities that also drive disparities in chronic diseases such as stroke, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and hypertension. Patients with underlying chronic diseases who are recovering from COVID-19 depend on the support of family caregivers who are being exposed to the same pandemic and racial stressors, exposure that can affect the health and quality of life of both partners. The primary goal of this study is to test the efficacy of an adapted, telehealth-enhanced intervention that targets barriers impacting family illness management behaviors of survivor:carepartner dyads for improved quality of life and COVID-19/chronic disease related health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: A major challenge for treatment of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is the presence or emergence of therapeutic resistance to receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) inhibitors. We have identified a new approach for targeting cell surface glycoprotein receptors (such as RTKs) through inhibition of the oligosaccharyltransferase (OST). To advance this therapeutic strategy the proposed research will characterize and test OST inhibitors in genetically defined subgroups of NSCLC to identify mechanisms of drug sensitivity as well as novel inhibitors with the potential for clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This research will investigate how a protein hormone (parathyroid hormone, PTH) is able to interact with the surface of a cell in bone and transmit signals to the cell's DNA to regulate the expression of genes involved in bone breakdown. PTH is essential for maintaining serum calcium levels, but too much of the hormone or genetic diseases that act like PTH can cause major bone loss and disabilities. The results of our research will help develop treatments for hyperparathyroidism and other bone and skeletal disorders in place of surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is based on our recent findings that the expression of FoxO transcription factors is suppressed in articular cartilage from aged and osteoarthritis-affected human and mouse joints. The proposed research will investigate the role of FoxO in joint homeostasis, consequences of FoxO suppression in joint aging and osteoarthritis pathogenesis and determine potential therapeutic benefits of increasing FoxO expression. The findings from this work have potential to lead to a paradigm shift in the understanding of the impact of joint aging on osteoarthritis pathogenesis and lead to new approaches to prevention and treatment. !

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculous meningitis (TBM) is the most devastating form of childhood tuberculosis, with much of the damage caused by infarction, the pathogenesis of which is poorly understood. We will recruit a cohort of children with probable or confirmed TBM and will use advanced molecular, proteomic and neuroimaging techniques to better understand the pathophysiology of infarction in TBM. We will then use computer simulation to evaluate the impact of different therapeutics, with the aim of developing a more targeted approaches to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE)  This project will construct models of gene regulatory networks controlling early human development by taking an integrative approach involving perturbation of core regulatory network elements, quantitative genomic and proteomic measurements with high temporal and single-cell resolution, and systems level analyses. Knowledge gained from the study will provide a conceptual framework for dissecting gene regulatory networks during cell state transitions, and reveal general features of genomic variants that contribute to cellular and organismal phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Virtual simulators are powerful tools for training surgeons in skill-intensive minimally invasive procedures, however, to date most available simulators focus mainly on new surgeons in formal training programs, including medical students and surgery residents. There is a recognized need to support training and maintenance of skills for practicing surgeons. The goal of this project is to design, develop and evaluate open source software templates to train, retrain and advance performance of practicing surgeons to improve patient safety and healthcare outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is a devastating neurodegenerative disease of aging which poses a massive burden on the health care system but for which there is currently no effective therapy or cure. Accumulating evidence suggests that targeting microglia could be beneficial in slowing disease progression, and our labs have discovered a novel microglial drug target called PU.1, that, when reduced in humans, significantly delays the age of onset of the disease. Therefore, we propose development of a drug discovery program aimed at safely reducing PU.1 activity, restoring beneficial microglial function and ultimately slowing the progression of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Structural racism and discrimination (SRD) among African Americans has remained a historical legacy of the United States and the resulting trauma can modify physiologic function and be transmitted to subsequent generations. The proposed study seeks to investigate the impact of race and transgenerational SRD-related trauma among AA women on distinct epigenetic modifications at the maternal-fetal interface that are linked to altered immune cell development, activation, and signaling in the placenta and developing fetus. Results from these studies may inform future interventions to address health disparities among at-risk mother-infant pairs and can promote their overall health and well-being.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will help reduce the prevalence of bullying perpetration, victimization, and witnessing and improve the general bullying climate, sense of safety, responses to bullying (ie, positive bystander actions by students and more positive responding by teachers) as well as student-teacher and student relationships through the intermediate outcomes of teachers’ improved ability to detect, prevent, and intervene with bullying and peer conflicts in the classroom. The BCCU is a bullying prevention program that includes professional developmental and coaching that leverages motivational interviewing to empower teachers to engage in practice changes and mixed-reality simulation for guided practice of new skills. Together, the BCCU components addresses knowledge, attitudes, and skills of teachers to intervene with students who are directly involved (eg, victims, perpetrators) and indirectly involved (eg, bystanders/witnesses) in bullying, including foundational classroom management that integrates social-behavioral expectations, how to identify bullying behaviors in the classroom, and how to select and implement evidence-based strategies to address and intervene with these behaviors in real-time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The central nervous system has an intrinsic pain modulatory system that regulates nociceptive processing through descending projections from the ventrolateral periaqueductal gray (vlPAG) to the rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) that are relayed to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. This circuit inhibits pain normally but can shift to facilitate pain contributing to persistent pain states. The studies in this proposal will map and define the circuit by identifying relevant PAG neurons and their connections with the RVM and examine the underlying cellular mechanisms responsible for the shift from inhibition to facilitation of pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Improving adherence to physical activity (PA) programs is critical for overweight midlife adults (ages 50-64) in order to enhance weight management efforts and reduce risk of chronic disease and premature death. Current national PA recommendations, which call for PA of at least moderate intensity (64-76% of maximum heart rate), do not consider how people feel (i.e., pleasure or displeasure) while they are exercising, despite the fact that many overweight midlife adults find moderate intensity PA to be aversive. In this study we will compare the effects of an explicit recommendation for self-paced PA versus a traditional intensity-based exercise prescription (based on heart rate range) on PA behavior among previously low-active overweight midlife adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In this proposal we will develop a cross-sectional imaging technology termed dynamic µOCT (DµOCT) that identifies distinct cells and tissues using intracellular motility signatures, a proxy of cell activity and state. Research will involve conducting a series of experiments in spheroids, animals, and human tissue to understand the nature of the dynamic signal and determine the diagnostic capacity of this technology for distinguishing disease, cell/tissue activity, and response to therapy. We additionally will develop next generation DµOCT technology that will increase resolution, provide more powerful diagnostic algorithms, and enable the use of DµOCT in living patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  T cell development in the thymus depends on the thymic microenvironment, of which thymic epithelial cells (TECs) are the major component. However, TECs undergo a qualitative and quantitative loss over time, which results in thymic involution and T cell immunodeficiency in older adults, leading to increased susceptibility to infection and cancer, and difficulty in establishing protective immunity via vaccination. The purpose of this project is to develop novel recombinant Foxn1 fusion proteins and to determine the ability of the proteins to rejuvenate the aged TECs, and subsequently to enhance T cell generation in old mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Parasite infections lead to substantial morbidity and mortality in humans, livestock, and wildlife. Natural selection for host immunity (and parasite infectivity) causes variation in the prevalence and intensity of infection, but little is known about how most parasitic diseases evolve. This research will integrate lab and field experiments to describe how stickleback fishes and cestode parasites evolve to manipulate infection outcomes to their own benefit, how these changes are interdependent (i.e., coevolution), and how the process of coevolution varies over space and time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Norovirus-infected transplant patients may develop serious sequelae, but the host factors and clinical circumstances that dictate severity of infection are unknown. This proposal explores the role of the gut microbiome in modulating norovirus infections. The results from these studies may yield mechanistic insights on viral pathogenesis of human noroviruses and explore the potential therapeutic role of precision probiotics in the treatment of norovirus infections.
