IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The increasing affordability of genome sequencing has created new opportunities to personalize health care. To maximize the clinical impact of genomic information, we must train a workforce of physicians and scientists to interpret and manage genomic data, to work within teams of researchers from different disciplines, and to communicate genomic information effectively and responsibly to patients. Armed with this training, a new generation of scientists will develop and apply precision diagnostics and therapies to provide truly personalized health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative:  Signaling networks deficient in monoamine neurotransmitters have been linked to the onset and progression of intellectual deficits in Alzheimer's disease (AD). Thus restoring norepinephrine and dopamine inputs represents an effective approach to alleviating AD's cognitive and behavioral symptoms and could delay disease onset. Dopamine replacement therapy with the dopamine precursor L-DOPA remains the most effective treatment for restoring DA/NE inputs in humans. However, the L-DOPA oral tablet's pulsatile delivery is often associated with severe adverse effects after long-term use. Thus, the main goal of this proposal is to develop and optimize a novel therapeutic platform of live biological L-DOPA delivery to restore monoamine neurotransmitters to steady-state levels that relieve symptoms of ADRD without adverse effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Genetic variation can offer powerful clues about the biological basis of disease. Human genomes vary at scales large and small; while fine-scale (single-nucleotide) DNA variation is readily recognized by today’s analysis methods, many kinds of complex, larger-scale variation have been challenging to recognize and analyze. The goal of our work is to develop new, powerful ways to combine many kinds of genome analysis data to (i) understand how human genomes vary at these larger scales among many thousands of people; and (ii) identify many ways that genetic variation shapes human biology and risk of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative Currently, there is a paucity of research that systematically examines agents for chemoprevention men on active surveillance (AS) for prostate cancer (PCa). Several epidemiological, in vitro, preclinical and early phase trials completed by our team and others have shown that the green tea catechins (GTC) are potent inhibitors of PCa carcinogenesis through multiple mechanisms, bioavailable in tissue and plasma, reduces several intermediate biomarkers implicated in PCa progression and without toxicities at these doses. Based on the available evidence, we hypothesize that men with biopsy proven adenocarcinoma of the prostate who meet the criteria for AS, who receive GTC at a dose of 800 mg EGCG per day (vs. placebo) for 24 months, will have a significantly decreased rate of clinical progression. We will test this hypothesis using a rigorous experimental design in a phase II, randomized clinical trial to evaluate the bioavailability, safety, effectiveness and mechanism by which GTC prevents clinical progression of disease in men on AS for PCa. Results of the proposed study may inform development of a phase III clinical trial and ultimately provide a strategy for chemoprevention with GTC in men on AS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An individual’s level of engagement with their environment, often described as arousal, is impaired in a variety of neurologic disorders, including schizophrenia and Alzheimer’s. Systemic metrics of arousal, such as heart rate and pupil diameter, could be used as non-invasive, diagnostic markers if the link between arousal and brain activity was understood. The proposed research investigates how neural activity and cerebral hemodynamics slowly fluctuate with arousal level, measured systemically, and in turn influence behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: C-DIAS OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this revised P50 proposal, we envision a Center for Dissemination and Implementation At Stanford: C-DIAS. Public access to (reach) and routine delivery of (adoption) evidence-based addiction treatments are historic and persistent problems. Serving as an open, national and enduring resource, this unique Center of Excellence will integrate broad-based multi-disciplinary expertise, creatively develop expert capacity, advance the science of implementation, and promote the equitable sustainment of proven addiction treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is consistent with the broader public health goals focused on improving disease self- management among patients with advanced or serious illness and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) call for increased patient engagement in advance care planning (ACP) as part of standard care. Specifically, the proposed study will address this critical public health issue by refining and pilot testing the Conversations Helpful for Awareness of Illness Trajectory (CHAT) intervention to improve communication about illness trajectory, and subsequently improve symptom burden and advance care planning, among patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). Therefore, this study is aligned with the NIA’s long-term goals of improving the quality of care for patients with advanced illness and CMS’s goal of improving engagement in ACP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: The lack of molecular mechanistic insights into the initiation and progression of oral squamous cell carcinoma has been the main hindrance in the development of new, directed therapy. HuR an RNA-binding protein that is overexpressed in oral cancers, post-transcriptionally control gene expression of epithelial and metabolic genes. The experiments described in this proposal will evaluate the biological properties of HuR and the contribution of cross-talk between oral epithelium and T-lymphocytes using a mouse model of oral tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This multidisciplinary effort aims to accelerate the discovery of gene-environment (GxE) interactions that influence colorectal cancer (CRC) risk. We will conduct functional-genomic guided genome-wide GxE scans in over 230,000 racially and ethnically diverse CRC cases and controls across the spectrum of environmental risk factors. This approach improves the statistical power and biological interpretability of GxE findings. Discoveries have high translational potential for precision prevention as they can guide lifestyle interventions as well as personalize screening decisions, ultimately, reducing the burden of CRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many people suffer from Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF), but unfortunately, we do not have any drug treatments that consistently improve a patient’s ability to exercise or his/her quality of life in this syndrome. The goal of this proposal is to test whether improving skeletal muscle metabolism and energy production can improve exercise tolerance in HFpEF patients. We hope that this proposal will identify new ways to treat HFpEF patients, allowing these individuals, who are currently very limited in what they can do and how they feel, to enjoy life more.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The food additive nisin has been increasingly recognized for its broad-spectrum bactericidal action and immunomodulatory effects in both animals and humans; however, its clinical benefit in improving outcomes of human oral cancer patients has not been explored. Here, we will conduct a Phase I/IIa trial of nisin in patients with oral squamous cell carcinoma to establish tolerability and feasibility of the treatment regimen. In parallel, we will analyze patient biological samples for nisin-induced changes in oral microbiome diversity, inflammasome expression, and anti-cancer cellular responses, which we predict are the mechanisms through which nisin promotes an anti-tumorigenic environment and protects against oral cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To ensure equitable access to scientific advances, datasets must include patients reflecting the demographic distribution of disease. But our previous research demonstrates that many patients are uncomfortable with hospitals sharing their data with industry, and that individuals who identify as Black or Hispanic are consistently more likely to report discomfort. This research aims to explore and characterize hospital data-sharing practices with industry as well as patient response in order to identify areas for compromise that are respectful of individual patient autonomy and equitable in impact across diverse communities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of early-onset endometrial cancer has risen in young obese patients. The proposed study will result in the development of screening methods using methylation markers in cell-free DNA testing. Furthermore, given PAI-1 plays a role in comorbidity complications, the study may open new preventive measures targeting downstream PAI-1 pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Statement Recent years have witnessed an explosion of information derived from genome wide association studies (GWAS) linking genetic variation with increased risk for diseases such as Multiple Sclerosis (MS). To date, little mechanistic insight has been gleaned from the majority of risk-associated variants, a challenge reflecting their primary localization to non-coding regulatory regions of the genome. The proposed work will capitalize on emerging genomics approaches to prioritize lineage-relevant MS risk variants, determine their mechanism of action in contributing to the pathogenesis of MS, and as such, provide new avenues for therapeutic interventions targeting MS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposures to chemicals that mimic the estrogen hormone increase the risk of a woman developing breast cancer later in life. We have identified changes to the mammary gland following estrogen-like chemical exposures that are associated with breast cancer risk. The goal of this proposal is to determine how the hormone-like activity of these chemicals causes mammary gland changes and the role they play in increasing risk of developing cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our ability to effectively treat infections is threatened by increasing resistance among many microbes to the antibiotics that we use today. One approach to the development of new antibiotics is to engineer antimicrobial peptides (AMPs), miniproteins naturally produced by the human body to defend against microbes, which may treat infections both by killing microbes and by promoting an appropriate immune response. This proposal uses protein engineering and related technologies to systematically characterize and engineer human AMPs for the development of new types of antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcription factors (TFs) regulate gene expression responses to a variety of input signals; and ensuring accurate transmission of this information remains an important challenge in understanding disease progression as dysregulation can lead to autoimmune disorders or cancer. TF p65/RELA regulates hundreds of genes in the NF-κB pathway, including those implicated in inflammation and tumor suppression. Here, we will develop a precisely regulated, optogenetic, single cell, and genome-wide approach to comprehensively characterize dynamic regulation by NF-kB, providing a new platform to gather fundamental knowledge of gene regulation in human cells for downstream applications in therapeutics and biomedical engineering.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm birth is the greatest and costliest burden in perinatology and it not only results in a high rate of fetal mortality but also puts the children at a lifelong risk of negative health consequences. However, the factors that result in preterm birth are still not very well understood, which is largely due to our limited ability to monitor the human uterine maturation with sufficient spatial and temporal resolutions. We propose to investigate the feasibility of a wirelessly powered, wearable patch system capable of providing high-resolution three-dimensional mapping of uterine surface electrical activity during contractions, which would permit the study of birth-related risks and improve maternal and child outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative: Renal ischemia/reperfusion injury (IRI) occurs commonly in hospitalized patients and mechanistic evaluations are urgently needed in order to develop preventive and therapeutic strategies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Program Narrative Double hit lymphoma (DHL) and double-expressing lymphoma (DEL) are highly aggressive incurable B-cell malignancies that are characterized by co-overexpression of two oncoproteins called MYC and BCL2, which drive uncontrolled cell growth and resistance to cell death (for example that caused by chemotherapeutic drugs), respectively. Accordingly, there is a dire need for new therapeutic strategies to treat DHL and DEL and, using a novel cell-based platform and unbiased screening approaches, we discovered that these lymphomas have a unique transcriptional landscape that relies on protein kinases called CDK7 and CDK9 that are necessary to sustain the expression of genes in these lymphomas that control B-cell fate or that function as oncoproteins, including MYC. The proposed studies will define the role and mechanism by which CDK7 and CDK9 sustain DHL growth, survival and tumorigenicity, and will pre-clinically validate a therapeutic strategy that combines drugs that disable CDK7, CDK9 and BCL2 as a new therapeutic approach to treat DHL and DEL patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol-associated liver disease represents a growing public health burden, particularly among younger age groups, women, and ethnic minorities, and is now the leading cause of liver transplantation in the United States. This project will identify predictors of outcome and improve prognostication in severely ill patients with alcohol- associated liver disease. Identifying reliable non-invasive markers that characterize the distinct phenotypes of alcohol-associated liver disease will be crucial to advance our understanding of this liver disease, target interventions, and appropriately allocate resources including liver transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infects the majority of the world’s population for life and can cause severe disseminated infections in immunocompromised patients, e.g., transplant recipients, and a spectrum of developmental abnormalities in neonates. The goal of this proposal is to stabilize glycoprotein gB – a molecular machine that enables HCMV entry and spread – in its biologically-active, prefusion form, characterize its structure and antigenicity, and isolate prefusion-specific neutralizing antibodies from HCMV- seropositive donors. The new reagents and knowledge resulting from the proposed work could lead to a better understanding of HCMV immune response and correlates of protection and aid in the development of optimal vaccines and passive immunization strategies against HCMV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The rapidly increasing prevalence and serious complications of type 2 diabetes (T2D) underscore its importance as a public health issue. Despite advances in therapeutic options, optimizing glycemic control still remains an elusive goal. Since excessive glucose production is the main source of increased glucose levels in T2D, understanding mechanisms that regulate glucose production would have important therapeutic implications. Our recent data suggest that the brain exerts important restraining effects on the liver’s glucose production, but that elevated fatty acid levels in T2D impair this regulation. Using studies in both humans and rats, we hope to clearly elucidate the impact of fatty acids on the cells in the brain that control glucose production. These studies could therefore lead to new therapeutic target(s) for the treatment of T2D.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: The objective of this project is to understand the sources and routes of transmission for Shigella and Campylobacter, two important causes of diarrhea in young children, in an urban low-resource setting in Dhaka, Bangladesh. We will follow a longitudinal transmission cohort of households to identify and attribute sources of infections. These data will inform mathematical models to determine the relative importance of person-to-person and environmental transmission pathways. This project will transform our understanding of enteric pathogen transmission by moving from a broad understanding of fecal-oral transmission routes to pathogen-specific household and environmental pathways of highest relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Cochlear implants are one of the most successful biological implants, and while these devices provide hearing to people who have lost significant hearing, most ears implanted with a CI have inflammatory reactions to the device that negatively affects their performance. The implant is made of materials that cause an inflammatory reaction that results in scar formation and limits the ability of the device to provide optimal hearing. In the proposed work, we will perform experiments in mice to investigate the effects of the biomaterials that are used to make cochlear implants and the effects of electrical stimulation to understand how these aspects of cochlear implantation influence inflammation and scar formation in the cochlea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed study is to leverage high-dimensional, multi-scale, and highly heterogeneous genomics data to discover the essential molecular alterations of immune cells introduced by HIV and/or substance use disorder (SUD) at a single-cell resolution. In contrast to existing methods that rely on either transcriptome or epigenome only, this work assumes that several key transcriptomic, epigenetic, and regulatory network alterations jointly occur with HIV and/or SUD, resulting in immune system dysfunction. Hence, we propose a computational framework to depict the comprehensive immune cell regulome, construct molecular networks of various cell types, and pinpoint key immune dysfunction driver events at a single-cell resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) paired with rehabilitation exercises is currently the only FDA approved neuromodulation therapy for recovery of upper limb function after stroke, and understanding the mechanisms of VNS efficacy is key to improving patient responses to this novel treatment approach. Noradrenaline, an important plasticity-promoting neuromodulator, is thought to mediate many of the effects of VNS, and our labs have recently found that cortical noradrenergic signaling, in particular, is likely to play a critical role in VNS efficacy. The proposed research aims to causally examine the importance of VNS-dependent engagement of the central noradrenergic network in driving motor system synaptic plasticity and functional recovery after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Aggression accompanies a number of common human neurodegenerative disorders (e.g. Alzheimer's and other related dementias), with little understanding of how cognitive and aggression symptoms may be linked at the neuronal level. Aggression has been extensively studied in males of many species, but neglected in females (likewise, the interaction of sex and age is neglected). The objective of this research program is to identify the neural circuitry that governs female aggression (K99- mentored phase) and later transition (R00- independent phase) into discovering mechanisms of dementia-related pathology and how these changes affect aggression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiological data suggest that greater adherence to the Mediterranean-DASH Diet Intervention for Neurodegenerative Delay (MIND) slows the rate of cognitive decline and reduces the risk of Alzheimer's disease (AD).The current proposal leverages the first, ongoing MIND trial as well as existing community- and population-based data to examine how genetic differences in (a) AD predisposition and (b) nutrient metabolism modify the response to the MIND diet. Our research will provide mechanistic insights into the role that MIND may play in slowing cognitive decline and will also inform the implementation of MIND for optimal effectiveness.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The placenta serves a myriad of critical functions in maintaining a healthy pregnancy, ranging from nutritional to immune to hormonal. However, currently, there are no practical tools that enable providers to monitor and incorporate placental development into clinical care. The current proposal leverages an ongoing collaboration between computer scientists, physician scientists and mathematicians to enable the use of modern fully automated image analysis methodology and mathematical modeling such that fetal-placental growth trajectories can be monitored and integrated into the clinical workflow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative This renewal application for the Integrative Liver Cell Core (ILCC) proposes its continuation of unique and specialized services involving isolation and analysis of different liver cell types. As a national resource supported by the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, the ILCC provides these services at the regional and national levels to support medical research on alcohol-associated liver diseases and liver fibrosis, which are prevalent in our nation and around the world. The long-term goal of the ILCC is to help scientists develop new treatments for alcoholic-associated liver diseases and cirrhosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement One in two adults in the U.S. have at least one cardiometabolic disease (CMD) including hypertension, heart disease diabetes or stroke. Despite links between short sleep duration and cardiometabolic health, few studies have sought to improve CMD risk by extending sleep. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of a behavioral sleep extension intervention on sleep and CMD risk factors among patients with elevated blood pressure or hypertension. Successful completion of this study will advance the possibility of increasing sleep duration for improving cardiometabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Most patients with HCC who are not candidates for surgical removal or ablation are treated with chemotherapeutic agents that in sufficient concentrations are potent enough to kill cancer cells. Nonetheless, these treatments result in only limited improvements in patient survival because these agents do not reach the cancer cells due to the abnormal tumor microenvironment. The proposed work will benefit public health by developing a novel image-guided approach for treating the tumor microenvironment of HCC with combined mechanotherapeutic drugs and ultrasound cavitation to increase chemotherapy delivery to the tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anorexia nervosa (AN) is a serious psychiatric disorder associated with significant impairment and increased risk of death. This study will establish the extent to which neural bases of disgust generalization and extinction processes contribute to AN symptom expression, as well as determine the extent to which these patterns of neural activity predict AN symptom maintenance. By identifying the neurobiological processes underlying core symptom expression and maintenance in this population, the proposed research represents a critical next step needed to develop more precise models of AN and has potential for substantial impact on the development of innovative and effective neurobiologically-based treatments for this severe and persistent disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is the major cause of alcohol-related mortality, but the specific mechanisms underlying ALD development and progression have not been fully elucidated. We will develop a first-of-its-kind organotypic mouse liver model and investigate the effects of alcohol on multiple liver cell types in this model with comparisons to an in vivo mouse model of ALD that recapitulates several key features of human ALD. Our platform could be used to investigate the underlying molecular mechanisms by which cell-cell interactions in the liver determine progressive disease or adaptation due to chronic alcohol consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Pediatric Oncology Clinical Research Training Program (POCRTP) provides a comprehensive clinical research educational program that trains pediatric oncologists in clinical research; the program seeks to produce the next generation of leaders in the field of pediatric cancer clinical research. The trainees, designated “Paul Calabresi Scholars,” receive a mentored training experience in the design, implementation, conduct, and analysis of clinical research trials. The ultimate goal of the POCRTP is to educate Scholars to translate basic research discoveries into innovative treatments using effective clinical trials, thereby improving the prognosis of children with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with concerning breast masses require diagnosis, triage, and management; this typically depends on detailed examination of biopsy material, frequently obtained via core needles. However, such tissue-based diagnostics take time and skilled resources, and can induce delay in patient evaluation and appropriate care, especially in low-resource settings. We propose to develop an automated instrument into which needle biopsies of breast lesions can be introduced to immediately generate high-quality cellular-resolution and molecular stain images that can be used for diagnosis and treatment planning; the digital images can be interpreted locally, shared electronically, or even processed using artificial intelligence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative In this study we are trying to find the genetic features that cause atrial fibrillation, a common abnormality of the heart rhythm that can lead to a stroke. We will also use an automated computer program to measure millions of pictures of the human heart to discover genes for the heart size and function. We then study the function of the genes that we find using heart cells; ultimately, we hope to find new drug targets for atrial fibrillation.

PHR: We determined that AR interference activates the function of a network of cooperating transcriptional regulators that promote the lineage switch to treatment-emergent neuroendocrine prostate cancer (t-NEPC). The goal of this proposal is to determine mechanisms by which this network functions so we can block t-NEPC cell survival or prevent its emergence. A predicted outcome of our efforts is the identification of a new and effective treatment strategy for men with t-NEPC in the near-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project has high relevance to prostate cancer (PCa) and is expected to have a significant impact on current research and available treatments. Findings from this study will not only enhance our understanding of biology of bone marrow adipose tissue and its functional role in regulating the bone tumor microenvironment and metastatic progression, but it will lead to identification of novel candidate treatment options for improved patient outcomes. This work is likely to have high relevance beyond PCa and extend to other bone-trophic cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies have revealed that senescent stromal cells can secret factors to modulate tumor immune surveillance and thus promote tumor progression. Given that such factors have been identified in human breast cancer tissues across molecular subtypes and immunotherapy response amongst breast cancer patient is far from ideal, it is critical to understand how senescent stromal cells contribute to mammary gland tumorigenesis. The aims proposed here will not only broaden our understanding in how senescent stroma shapes tumor microenvironment but also help to identify potential strategies to improve response to immunotherapy by targeting cellular senescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Iowa (UI) Maximizing Access to Research Careers (MARC) program provides ongoing and intense academic and research support to undergraduate students and faculty research mentors in an effort to increase the rate of disadvantaged and underrepresented students matriculating to and completing biomedical doctoral research programs. The UI MARC program directly contributes to NIH’s effort of increasing the diversity of the biomedical workforce ensuring NIH remains a leader in scientific innovation and discovery. Supporting a diverse workforce, particularly a diverse group of research investigators, brings a wide range of perspectives and experiences to solve complex programs, and increases the likelihood that research questions related to human health are relevant to all populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The application of immunotherapy to breast cancer has been largely unsuccessful, even though tumors are infiltrated with many immune cells. Our proposal aims to reveal how the spatial organization and cellular interaction networks of intratumoral leukocytes regulate tumor progression and regression. Our findings may provide a better rationale for immunotherapy development and/or selection in breast cancer, paving the way for eventual clincal advancements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to characterize the prebiotic and immune mechanisms underlying the benefits of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) for improving post-operative survival of patients with colorectal cancer liver metastasis (CRCLM) by leveraging the recently launched, randomized placebo-controlled phase III trial of EPA treatment in patients undergoing liver resection surgery for CRCLM. We will also address causality and mechanism with dietary and microbial interventions in a novel ‘avatar’ germ-free CRCLM mouse model which is ‘humanized’ with stool from trial participants. Based on these unique resources and our experienced transdisciplinary team, the proposed research will provide unprecedented insight into the prebiotic and tumor immunomodulatory effect of EPA to improve the prognosis and response to surgical resection of CRCLM, offering compelling translational evidence for novel dietary and microbial strategies for CRCLM treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Thrombocytopenia is a condition characterized by low platelet counts; patients with thrombocytopenia are at risk of excessive, uncontrollable bleeding. The current standard of care is transfusion with donor platelet products to mitigate bleeding risks. However, donor platelets are expensive, carry significant risk of infections, have variable hemostatic efficacy, and have very short shelf life (3-5 days). Our innovative SynthoPlateTM technology can mimic platelet’s hemostatic functions while providing advantages of large-scale production and sterilizability to reduce contamination risk and ensure long shelf life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Our aim is to unify state-of-the-art chronic pain phenotyping methods, such as experimental pain testing and neuroimaging, with cannabinoid analgesic mechanisms in knee osteoarthritis patients. Our results will contribute significantly to the fundamental understanding of cannabinoid analgesic effects on central and peripheral contributions to knee osteoarthritis pain. Further, we have shown that this phenotyping approach is applicable to many other chronic pain conditions, so our results will have broad implications for developing personalized, non-opioid analgesics for pain management.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The substantial variability in the presentation of autism (ASD) is a key barrier in early diagnosis and in developing and evaluating effective treatments for the disorder. Because of this, the NIH and the Interagency Autism Coordinating Committee (IACC) have pushed to better understand the causes and impacts of this variability in individuals with ASD. The proposed project responds to this critical need by clarifying the impact of a potential key source of this variability: co-occurring anxiety and ADHD.

PHR: Project Narrative Social networks are a key determinant of health: directly through pathogen diffusion and indirectly through peer influence processes or role behaviors characteristic of a particular network position. While there is growing recognition of the importance of networks for health, training programs for health scholars almost never include social networks methodology training. This program will provide comprehensive training on the core ideas of social network analysis relevant for health training to produce a cohort of researchers prepared to leverage new network data for promoting health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have determined that histotripsy, a novel technology that ablates tumors precisely and non-invasively using high intensity ultrasound waves, triggers a sequence of cell death events in treated and distant, untreated tumors that culminate in a systemic anti-tumor immune response that is stronger than that generated by existing modes of tumor ablation. We will examine three distinct cellular events that follow histotripsy ablation – the exposure of contents hidden inside tumor cells, the triggering of inflammatory cancer cell suicide of cancer cells, and immune cell-driven cancer cell death – to determine the extent to which these unique events mechanistically drive the phenomenon of histotripsy immunostimulation. By understanding these events and testing preclincal strategies to harness and maximize them, we hope to establish a scientific foundation for implementing histotripsy tumor ablation as a means of maximizing the impact of cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will use a novel model of human fertility - vitrified donor oocyte assisted reproductive technology (ART) - to evaluate how air pollution influences human reproduction. Because vitrified oocytes are obtained from anonymous, young, healthy female donors months to years prior to the recipient couple's ART cycle, there is no correlation in exposure between the donor and the female recipient or the donor and the recipient's male partner. By leveraging this unique resource, our research will determine the independent effects of air pollution exposure during oogenesis and spermatogenesis on fertilization and early embryo development, the independent effects of air pollution on pregnancy outcomes as mediated through the oocyte and the endometrium, and the extent to which air pollution affects fertility potential in young, healthy women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the past decade, technologies that enable precision medicine have markedly improved, enabling the detection and analysis of a variety of soluble biomarkers, now referred to as the blood biopsy. In particular, assessment of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is increasingly being used for therapeutic decision-making in cancer patients; however, several challenges remain before this approach can be effectively implemented to truly advance treatment and prevention outcomes. The purpose of this grant application is to leverage the spontaneous canine cancer model to optimize a set of novel tools and methodologies for ctDNA based blood biopsy that facilitate early screening, minimal residual disease monitoring and interrogation of tumor genome evolution, with the goal rapid translation to human oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of our Training Program, in operation since 1971, is to provide research training in critical areas of alcohol studies for scholars and professionals with research backgrounds in public health, epidemiology, psychology, sociology, economics and other social sciences. The proposal describes a coherent and rigorous program of training in the alcohol field that addresses this challenge, offering training particularly in alcohol epidemiology, services, and policy research, all with a disparities focus. Trainees are equipped by their experience to obtain NIH funding and make productive contributions in their careers to the growth of knowledge concerning alcohol use, use disorders and related problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: B cells of the immune system are a leading model for the analysis of gene regulatory networks (GRNs), and variation in the human B cell regulatory genome has been associated with autoimmune diseases and differential vaccine responses. However, there has not been a comprehensive attempt to delineate the cis-regulome of primary human B cells in their resting, activated and terminally differentiated states or to assemble corresponding dynamic GRNs. Based on our recent success in assembling the first comprehensive murine B cell cis-regulome, our inter-disciplinary team is proposing to assemble a human B cell cis-regulome and corresponding dynamic GRNs, and study the consequences of disease-associated non-coding variation in the context of these dynamic GRNs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart, vascular and respiratory diseases continue to be leading causes of morbidity and mortality in the US, and reflect the complex interactions of environmental and genetic factors that modify the integrated function of proteins, cells, organs and organ systems and thereby, alter disease susceptibility, as well as responsiveness to therapies. Continued progress in precision diagnosis, treatment and prevention strategies for heart, vascular and respiratory diseases requires a mechanistic understanding at the systems level as it relates to the fundamental physiology of health and disease. Our long-standing translational cardiovascular and pulmonary (CVP) program, coupled with outstanding institutional support, provides trainees with opportunities to address modern-era data- driven research projects by delivering a contemporary and collaborative didactic research experience and professional development to train and mentor the next generation of CVP researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K08 proposal describes the training plan and expertise that the applicant, Dr. Steven Rhodes MD, PhD, will require over the subsequent five years to develop his career as an independent physician scientist investigating tumor and immune system interactions mediating the progression of NF1-associated peripheral nerve sheath tumors. Collectively, these studies will provide key insights regarding dynamic interactions between infiltrating T cell and neoplastic Schwann cells to modulate the tumor progression across various stages of the neurofibroma to MPNST continuum and to evaluate new chemopreventative strategies to prevent the malignant transformation in persons at risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inherited retinal degenerations are a leading cause of blindness worldwide, and visual impairment is an increasing public health issue, particularly with our aging population. Several types of retinal degeneration, affecting both the young and the old, are associated with variants in the ABCA4 gene. The studies in this proposal seek to bridge the knowledge obtained from clinical genetics of variants in the ABCA4 gene with their corresponding structural and functional consequences at the protein level so that more accurate prognoses and targeted therapies may be developed in the near future; we do this in concert with DEIA activities aimed at promoting diversity in the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer (PDAC) is a deadly malignancy characterized by extensive fibrosis and immune suppression. The complex interplay between tumor cells and their surrounding stroma has not been fully elucidated. Since current therapeutic approaches targeting individual components of the tumor microenvironment have failed to benefit patients, the goals of the project are to: define 1) Slit2- and 2) Slit3- dependent tumor/fibroblast/immune cross talk using genetic mouse model approaches, and 3) elucidate the impact of dual SLIT2/3 deletion in primary human CAFs in vitro on angiogenesis and tumor cell growth.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this revised proposal is to purchase the Alinity ci analytical platform to equip a new Core service to be housed within the MGH Center for Transplantation Sciences. In addition to providing mission- critical support to multiple CTS users by measuring immunosuppressive drug levels in large animal ‘translational’ transplant models and in rodent transplant models, this platform will support translational scientific projects for multiple other research programs across the MGH research community (tissue engineering and regenerative medicine, housed within the Center for Engineering in Medicine and Surgery; trauma; cardiovascular medicine and surgery; neural science; Center for Comparative Medicine; Knight Surgical Research Laboratory). In addition, through the Shared Equipment mechanism this versatile, high- throughput assay platform will support future growth in new research directions via development of multiple new assay capabilities, and newly meet the needs of the rodent research community through small-volume assay capabilities.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The FACSDiscover S8 Image-Enabled Spectral Cell Sorter is a powerful, cutting-edge research instrument capable of identifying dozens of unique cell populations from biological samples using fluorescence and imaging measurements. These cell populations can then be isolated with extremely high purity and subsequently analyzed to provide a deeper and much needed understanding of a wide array of human diseases to help develop the treatments of tomorrow. Allowing such discoveries is the current roadblock addressed by this application, which is aimed at bringing a currently unavailable novel high-end technology at Columbia University for the betterment of human health.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Measuring changes in energy production and use at the cellular level is critical to understanding biology. The Seahorse XF Pro Analyzer provides an increased throughput method to measure key components of cellular metabolic functions in live cells, over time. Thus, the Seahorse can comprehensively advance our understanding of human health and disease biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose biomarker-directed therapy for patients with HER2-amplified locally advanced rectal cancer. In a clinical trial and associated correlative studies (using tissue and blood samples, HER2-targeting 89Zr-trastuzumab PET/MRI scans, and patient-derived organoid models), we will evaluate the efficacy and biological effects of HER2-targeted induction therapy, alone and with standard-of-care chemotherapy, to treat HER2-amplified rectal cancer. This therapy has the potential to transform the care of this molecularly defined subset of rectal cancer, omit radiation and/or surgery, and avoid the morbidity of standard-of-care tri-modality therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Considering that over 80 million Americans live with obesity (2020 prevalence of body mass index ≥30 kg/m2 among adults was 41.9%), obesity is a major health problem in the United States. The 2021 Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval of the glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist, semaglutide (Wegovy), as an anti-obesity medication (AOM) is ushering in a radical shift in the treatment of obesity and AOMs are poised to become an important tool in population weight management. We have yet to understand how best to implement AOMs equitably and effectively in everyday practice, so we will detail the current state of AOM prescribing and implementation and engage a diverse array of stakeholders to design tailored interventions that optimize AOM access across health care settings based on best practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Clostridioides difficile infections (CDIs) are difficult to treat, resulting in 11,500 deaths in the United States every year. A challenge in treating CDI is the production of spores that germinate to vegetative cells, which cause the infection. Recurrence of infection occurs in 25% of patients. There are no antibiotics for the treatment of recurrent CDI. CDI is the deadliest of the five bacterial urgent threats. Understanding the process of spore germination is key to elucidating the basis for recurrent CDI. If spore germination could be prevented, the nefarious cycles of CDI can be interrupted. We disclose the discovery of a new class of antibiotics (the oxadiazoles) that kill C. difficile in the growing phase (vegetative cells). We also have found that certain oxadiazoles also inhibit spore germination. Our goals are to elucidate the spore-germination pathway, to show that inhibition of spore germination can stop recurrence of infection, and to discover new and more effective oxadiazoles that inhibit spore germination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Microglia are immune cells that act as the primary rst-responding sentinels in the brain. Although direct comparisons between microglia morphology and function are hard to make, it is clear that morphology changes in response to many diseases. Improved methods of microglia image processing and analysis are needed to directly link morphological changes with their corresponding functional consequences in models of many human disease processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy are a leading cause of maternal morbidity and mortality in the United States. Women and offspring exposed to hypertensive disorders prenatally face significant lifetime cardiovascular disease risk. The goal of this ancillary study is to test the enduring effects of a prenatal mindfulness training intervention, conducted in the parent RCT, on postpartum markers of maternal and infant cardiovascular disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) methods in use today measure human brain activity by tracking the associated changes in blood flow, volume, and oxygenation, and recent evidence suggests that these hemodynamic changes are controlled at a fine enough scale to permit localizing neuronal activity to the individual layers of the cerebral cortex, which would enable investigations of brain circuitry. Unfortunately, most fMRI methods lack the imaging resolution to detect these hemodynamic responses within cortical layers, which have a thickness of only a few hundreds of micrometers. To address this, here we will develop new tools using “line-scan” imaging to enable human fMRI with extremely high resolution in just one direction, perpendicular to the cortical layers, along with several technical advancements to make these tools reliable and widely usable, and then apply them to several investigations seeking to map out brain circuitry in healthy volunteers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Telomeric DNA synthesis is the cornerstone of telomere maintenance, which, if deregulated, leads to human diseases such as cancer and premature aging. While the mechanism of the initial part of telomeric DNA synthesis – telomere G-overhang extension by telomerase – is well understood, the subsequent telomere C- strand fill-in process is much less known. This proposal seeks to establish how the human telomere C-strand fill-in machinery assembles at telomeric G-overhangs and builds the complementary C-strand.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There is still much to be learned about how glial astrocytes and neuronal populations of the brain communicate to regulate complex behavior. We have identified transgenic strains that drive expression in specific astrocyte subpopulations and used them to define subpopulations relevant for sleep or circadian behavior. We will utilize these strains to define mechanisms of communication between the two cell types that mediate regulation of rhythmic behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Astroviruses are a global cause of gastroenteritis, commonly known as stomach flu, but currently there are no vaccines or treatments available to protect against these viruses. Identifying which human factors these viruses subvert to infect the intestine is critical for the generation of much-needed tools to study astroviruses in cell culture and in animal models. Defining these factors will also reveal key targets for novel antiviral therapies to prevent infection.

PHR: Project Narrative This application proposes to purchase a high-end mass spectrometer to support a strong cohort of NIH-funded researchers at Rutgers University and nearby institutions. This new instrument allows Rutgers Newark researchers and collaborators to speed up their biomedical research by detecting more proteins in cells and diseased tissues. Thus, adding this instrument to Rutgers Center for Advanced Proteomics Research is critical in improving our research productivity and the capacity to remedy human diseases, including infections, cancer, heart ailments, and brain diseases.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is a shared instrumentation grant for a protein analysis system that may quantitative and reproducible results as the most essential core piece of equipment for their current and future research. This is a critical state of the protein analysis system for investigators at NYMC, who while experienced with protein analysis and molecular biology, currently have no access to proteomics core. The ProteinSimple Jess System is automated, sensitive, and creates electronic data files that are impervious to manipulation, as it contains the raw and analyzed data, which can easily be uploaded to a data repository when it comes time to publish, thus, meeting established guidelines on NIH’s reproducibility and rigor.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Alcohol use disorder (AUD) affects approximately 14.1 million people in the United States. Despite the prevalence of this disorder, we lack a thorough understanding of its underlying neurobiological mechanisms. Here, we propose to use a multi-faceted approach integrating machine learning based behavioral analysis, cell type specific genetic manipulations, in vivo imaging and ex vivo slice physiology to begin to unravel the role of PVNCRH neurons in alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One of the heart’s two main pumping chambers, the right ventricle, sometimes fails and causes severe illness. The health of this heart chamber is difficult to monitor and treat, problems we aim to address with new ways to analyze a patient’s data. For patients with right heart failure our goal is to improve their chance of survival and shorten their time in intensive care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Melanoma is a deadly skin cancer that kills thousands of people in the US each year, despite revolutionary treatments such as immunotherapy; more forms of treatment are needed to improve outcomes for patients with advanced melanoma and to keep melanoma from spreading in patients with early-stage disease. Our group previously demonstrated that bacteria in the gut influence response to immunotherapy and showed that modifying these bacteria can improve treatment responses in patients with advanced melanoma. We will now study the impact of gut microbes in early-stage melanoma, with the goal of developing next-generation therapeutic strategies to better treat, intercept, and ultimately prevent melanoma.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein identification and quantification (ie., bottom-up proteomics) using high mass accuracy mass spectrometry is dependent on the ability to separate peptides using liquid chromatography (HPLC) prior to mass spectrometry. The requested Vaquish Neo UHPLC will provide a necessary upgrade to the current HPLC, which will no longer be serviceable due to age, for the Mass Spectrometry and Proteomics Core of The Wertheim UF Scripps Institute. As a bundled system with a current high mass accuracy mass specrometer, this instrument will will continue to be a campus-wide shared resource that will play a significant role in accelerating the biomedical applications and science for major and minor users, and for future researchers in neighboring institutions and counties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will examine mitral valve prolapse and co-occurring morbidities to enhance the clinical identification and treatment of cardiac valve diseases in people with risk factors that may result in poor cardiovascular health outcomes. Specifically, the project will describe the natural history of valve disease and resulting major adverse health events among people with mitral valve prolapse and a range of potentially complicating factors and will assemble that information to derive feasible multivariable methods for stratifying risk. The knowledge produced by this project will inform future public health initiatives and clinical care processes that aim to promote the healthiest possible outcomes in people with underlying mitral valve disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance to public health This project will develop a non-destructive assay for prognostication of patients with Barrett’s esophagus based on machine-learning analysis of 3D pathology datasets of endoscopic biopsies. This project will demonstrate that computational 3D pathology is superior to existing 2D pathology methods for risk stratification of Barrett’s esophagus biopsy specimens, and especially for distinguishing between aggressive and indolent dysplasias (pre-cancer). Therefore, this project has value for guiding critical treatment decisions by gastroenterologists and patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

PHR: NARRATIVE This proposed “Research Supplement to Promote Diversity in Health-Related Research” builds on the activities of the parent grant (R01-MH128198: the Aging, Transitions over the Life course, and Suicide (ATLAS) Project), to examine psychosocial risk and protective factors for suicide mortality and suicidal behavior within the Black population. This supplement supports a comprehensive mentoring and career development plan for the candidate, Eskira Kahsay, to guide her through the completion of her doctoral training and successful launch of her academic research career. This mentoring plan leverages long-standing partnerships with the Program for Research on Black Americans (PRBA) and the Michigan Center for Urban African American Aging Research (MCUAAAR), which collectively provide an ideal environment for supporting the professional development, team mentorship, and research activities of early-career investigators working in minority mental health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project intends to develop novel and high-impact statistical methods for studying the onset of asymptomatic diseases that can only be detected through periodic clinical examinations. These powerful new tools will enable investigators to analyze this important type of epidemiological data in a statistically efficient and unbiased manner, thereby facilitating the discovery of effective intervention and prevention strategies for many diseases of major public health significance, including diabetes, hypertension, HIV/AIDS, Covid-19, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cancer, and dementia.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advances in biomedical research have demonstrated that analysis of single cells is essential for understanding the biological processes underlying development and disease. At The Jackson Laboratory (JAX), we have the capability to analyze diverse components in the pathways involved in protein production, including RNA and DNA molecules, and other molecules that modify levels of proteins generated from RNA or DNA, but currently we have no options for high-throughput identification of the “proteome,” i.e., the complete set of proteins, in a single cell. Access to the Bruker timsTOF SCP mass spectrometer and the accompanying cellenONE for sample processing requested in this application will provide investigators at both JAX and other Maine research institutions with access to a state-of-the-art single-cell proteomics system that will significantly advance research on a broad range of diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mass spectrometry is a powerful analytical tool for separating and quantifying small molecule signaling agents in human physiology and disease. The SCIEX 7500 MS system can be used for measuring levels of compounds in biological samples while at the same time obtaining information about their chemical structure. There is a critical and substantial need for such an instrument to support the ongoing work of numerous NIH-funded investigators at Vanderbilt University Medical Center who are studying oxidized lipids (or fats) and their metabolites in human conditions associated with inflammation, including cancer, cardiology, and diabetes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  DNA methylation is one of the oldest known epigenetic modifications to the genome, playing an important role in the gene regulatory landscape by typically acting in a repressive context, with aberrant DNA methylation observed in various diseases and developmental disorders. Despite its importance, this property has not been assessed during the dynamics of mammalian development at high-resolution. We have developed new tools that will enable us to address key hypotheses regarding the mechanistic role of DNA methylation in conjunction with other epigenetic properties that will we apply to the developing mouse embryo with a further focus on intestinal epithelial cell lineages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Diabetes self-management education and support (DSME/S) helps people with T2DM learn and sustain healthy lifestyle behaviors and master complex disease management skills. Yet, only 7% of all adults with T2DM receive the DSME/S needed to effectively manage their diabetes care plan. New technologies supporting DSME/S programs are emerging, but most fail to meet the unique needs of older adults at high risk for unhealthy aging and cognitive decline related to poorly-controlled diabetes - creating a new digital divide. The See Yourself Health (SYH) team aims to bridge this digital health gap for older adults with the HOPE App, a new cloud-based immersive learning and telehealth program uniquely tailored for older adults with diabetes and clinically proven to maintain and improve cognitive and physical health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Minimally invasive surgery affords the advantage of faster recovery, reduced hospital stays, improved functional outcomes and a quicker return to normal activities, as compared to open operations. The proposed hyperspectral laparoscopic stereo imaging system, which is enhanced by our advanced deep learning AI algorithms, can detect malignant and vital tissues during robot‐assisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomy and therefore potentially improve the oncologic outcome (undetectable prostate‐specific antigen with no evidence of cancer recurrence) and functional outcome (recovery of continence and erectile function). The real‐time hyperspectral laparoscopic stereo imaging system will be integrated with the commercial da Vinci robot and will provide new capabilities of detecting cancerous tissue and mapping physiological parameters during surgery, in turn helping reduce cancer recurrence and improve survivals and surgical outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative Assessment of metabolism, consisting of energy expenditure (the number of calories burned) and substrate oxidation (whether carbohydrate, fat, or protein is burned as fuel), is critical to the study of human health and disease. A whole-room indirect calorimeter provides the optimal means to measure multiple components of metabolism in studies related to obesity and other chronic metabolic diseases. The proposed room calorimeter system will provide UAB with a state-of-the-art tool for assessing human metabolism in pediatric and adult populations, leading to advances in knowledge related to both the development and treatment of obesity and related metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is a gammaherpesvirus that establishes lifelong chronic infections in lymphocytes and other cells, placing the host at risk for several cancers, especially persons who are immune suppressed or infected with HIV. Defining interactions between KSHV and the host, especially how viral proteins inhibit immunity, is important for identifying new methods of treating and preventing KSHV-related cancers. The work of this proposal will employ model systems to establish functions for determinants of KSHV pathogenesis and test roles for specific immune functions in viral control.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The uterus contains glands that are essential for pregnancy and contribute to uterine-based endometrial disorders and disease, yet the developmental biology of epithelium and gland differentiation remains poorly understood. This gap in our knowledge will be addressed through an integrative systems biology approach that will define critical cellular and molecular pathways governing epithelial differentiation and gland development in the newborn uterus. This research is expected to significantly advance our understanding of the developmental aspects of uterine biology, determinants of adult uterine function, and provide a foundation for the design of clinical therapies to prevent, identify and treat human reproductive problems involving uterine dysgenesis, dysplasia, or dysfunction.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in cell state and function are often observed in response to disease and understanding these changes are critical components in diagnosis and assessment of novel treatments for infection, cancer, autoimmunity, and many other diseases. Flow cytometry is a powerful technique that allows for the simultaneous classification, numeration, and functional analysis of cells in a high-throughput manner from patient samples and model systems. Drexel University is requesting funds to purchase a spectrally enabled BD High Throughput Sampler, Symphony A5 SE high parameter cell analyzer to support cellular analysis at an unprecedented level by NIH-funded researchers at Drexel and surrounding institutions.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Human Immune Monitoring Shared Resource (HIMSR) serves faculty and trainees at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus (CUAMC) and CU Cancer Center members across the front range campuses (National Jewish Health, CU Boulder, CSU, VA, Children's Hospital, etc), has strong institutional support, and a stable financial infrastructure. This proposal seeks funds for the acquisition of a new state-of- the-art hyperplex fluorescence imaging platform, the Lunaphore COMET, to transform the research capabilities at CUAMC and expand current multiplex immunohistochemistry (mIHC) tissue imaging capabilities of the HIMSR. The Lunaphore COMET offers high multiplexing capability, compatibility with multiple sample types, customizable panel design, and produces open-source quantitative images of whole tissues, making it a valuable tool for studies of complex tissue microenvironments and advancing disease diagnosis, treatment, and drug development.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Stroke survivors with lower limb disability can improve their walking speed with high-intensity interval training (HIIT) rehabilitation therapy. However, some individuals may not respond to HIIT even when fully adherent to the program. To address this, we propose to build a predictive model that identifies if a Veteran with chronic subcortical stroke will improve their walking speed with HIIT by incorporating blood lactate as an early predictor of exercise response, and inhibitory neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and regional cerebral blood flow (CBF) as predictors of the brain’s potential to respond, while also taking into consideration other factors such as comorbidities, demographics, and fitness levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative – Funded/Parent Project Despite the recognized increased risks and consequences of mealtime difficulties and insufficient intake, people with ADRD are not provided with optimal person-centered mealtime care to manage the two interrelated and important health care problems (i.e., mealtime difficulties, insufficient intake). Developing an effective behavioral intervention that integrates person-centered mealtime care and management of risks of inadequate intake and malnutrition will address a significant long-term care need in adults with ADRD in diverse care settings, because such an intervention may have great potential to decrease mealtime difficulties, optimize intake, and improve nutrition and quality of life which are fundamental health needs as cognition declines. As a logical first step in intervention development and testing, data obtained from the proposed study will provide critical information to guide the refinement of the intervention protocol and clinical trial procedures and to estimate effect sizes for sample size calculation, which will be used in a future large-scale clinical trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of OPTIMAL on resident outcomes (e.g., mealtime difficulties, intake). Project Narrative – Administrative Supplement The PI has experienced a critical life event during the award period, which along with pandemic-related delays has impacted the progress of the funded project and increased the needs for more time and personnel support for the completion of the remaining study activities of the funded project. The administrative supplement support is critically needed to provide 1-year personnel support for a full-time research support coordinator and research assistants who have been working collaboratively with the PI and well trained to complete the remaining activities of the funded project. The administrative supplement support will ensure the continuity of the PI (Dr. Wen Liu)’s program of research in dementia mealtime care, support the PI to return to full productivity at the end of the supplement period, and facilitate PI’s transition from mentored career development award to research independence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Older adults experience inadequate muscle recovery following a disuse period leading to reduced muscle function and increased risk of falls. We have proposed to conduct a randomized clinical trial to test if metformin can improve muscle recovery in older adults and that this would occur by reducing cellular senescence and muscle fibrosis. These findings will aid in the future use of metformin to reduce cellular senescence and promote muscle recovery in aged individuals.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  This is a request to upgrade our energy integrating research CT scanner to a photon- counting system (Siemens NAEOTOM Alpha). The requested scanner is a paradigm shift in CT scanning, generating much more anatomic detail while allowing for simultaneously assessing both ventilation and perfusion together with signals of inflammation. Acquisition of this scanner will allow us to more accurately characterize structure to function relationships and to develop protocols which integrate this new technology into critical multi-center studies seeking to better understand COPD, Asthma and more recently long term COVID-19 in addition to allowing us to pursue our own investigations into lung disease etiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) may predispose human beings to an elevated risk of developing coronary heart disease (CHD) through modulating blood lipoprotein subspecies that are particularly relevant to CHD etiology, although epidemiological studies that examine inter-relationships among PFAS, blood lipoprotein subspecies, and CHD risk are limited. The proposed research aims to narrow significant knowledge gaps by evaluating prospective associations of PFAS exposures with lipoprotein subspecies and CHD incidence in well-characterized cohort studies of free-living individuals. Data from this research will shed light on potential effects of PFAS on cardiovascular health and may inform policy-making processes for regulating the production and use of PFAS in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Sickle cell disease and beta-thalassemia are molecular disorders for which few molecular therapies exist. Gene therapy in humans has demonstrated that molecular treatments work, but gene editing/deletion is costly, complicated, and inaccessible. In this project, we will develop chemical biology tools to temporally control a key transcriptional regulator that has been the focus of gene therapy treatments, thereby providing a path to more accessible therapies.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This shared instrument grant requests funds for a type of instrument that provides a rapid analysis of multiple characteristics of single cell suspensions. The requested instrument is a type of flow cytometer that can sort cell populations based on their expression of proteins that have been fluorescently tagged. It will be installed in a BSL3 facility where studies are performed on infectious pathogens that cause severe human disease. The requested equipment will empower researchers to enrich specific cell populations to use in subsequent assays in vitro or in vivo, providing critical insights into the function of cell subsets and their interactions in tissues infected with pathogenic viruses.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Involuntary weight gain or weight loss can lead to individuals becoming underweight, overweight, or obese, often indicating an inadequate response to acute health issues or the onset of chronic diseases. To comprehend the underlying causes and develop effective treatments, it is crucial to measure parameters such as energy expenditure and energy intake accurately. This can be achieved through the use of stable isotope tracer technology in combination with isotope ratio mass spectrometry, providing precise measurements for a comprehensive understanding of these phenomena. IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The goal of this grant is to obtain funding to purchase a state-of-the-art image-guided small-animal irradiation device (Precision X-Rad Small Animal Radiation Therapy (SmART)+ Biological Irradiator (Precision X-Ray, Madison, CT) that will allow delivery of x-ray irradiation in a precise and accurate manner to specific tissues of small animals. This will replace our current small-animal irradiator which is nearing the end of its useful lifetime. This device is needed to study radiation biology and therapy in a clinically relevant manner in small animals and is essential to continue the highly productive, NIH-funded research projects that make up our User group.

PHR: NARRATIVE We identified TROP2 as a highly promising and safe therapeutic target for CAR-NK therapy against pancreatic cancer based on extensive preclinical and IND-enabling studies. PHR: Project Narrative Magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) can measure the concentrations of chemicals in the brain. Computer modeling methods extract this information from the measured data, but different methods often deliver different results. This project seeks to develop new tools to capture this variability, to select the most appropriate modeling methods, and to describe the measurement uncertainty of MRS.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: The human body contains a great variety of tissues and cell types, which researchers must study under the microscope in order to understand their functions in health and disease. The requested Orion HT instrument features powerful optical technology that allows it to image up to 20 different color markers in a single automated scan, which will greatly expand our ability to identify multiple cell types within tissues and to visualize their interactions. The instrument will be installed in a core facility at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, where it will support a large community of NIH-funded researchers studying cancer, autoimmunity, inflammation, neurodegeneration and many other disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than half of low-income older adults (LOA) have maladaptive fall risk appraisal (a discrepancy between perceived fall risk versus physiological fall risk), which is a known contributor to decreased physical activity and no published study has evaluated interventions to help shift LOA with maladaptive fall risk appraisal to its healthy counterpart—adaptive (realistic) fall risk appraisal. We developed a technology-based, individualized, in-home Physio-fEedback Exercise pRogram (PEER), which includes a) physio-feedback using a real-time portable innovative technology—the BTrackS Balance System; b) cognitive reframing based on a novel fall risk appraisal matrix; and c) peer-led exercise by focusing on balance and strength training. The purposes of this clustered randomized controlled trial study are thus to: 1) examine the effects of the technology-based PEER intervention on fall risk reduction, dynamic balance and accelerometer-based physical activity; 2) examine the effects of the PEER intervention on fall risk appraisal shifting and negative self-perceptions of aging; and 3) explore participants’ experiences with the PEER intervention and potential barriers to access and adoption of the technology-based PEER intervention to inform future research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial dysfunction, mitophagy deficits, and the hyperactivity of mitochondria-associated ER membranes (MAM) are early and causative events in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease (AD). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity phenotypes may be useful to guide selection of anti-obesity medications and endoscopic devices to enhance weight loss. Current weight loss lifestyle interventions are not tailored to the physiological and behavioral factors contributing to obesity, and the use of phenotypes to develop long-term lifestyle therapy recommendations for obesity has yet to be investigated. This proposal aims to examine the efficacy of a phenotype-tailored lifestyle intervention therapy for obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will address the physiological importance of a tissue-to-tissue communication between the hypothalamus and white adipose tissue (WAT) in the regulation of aging and longevity in mammals. We have recently identified a specific subpopulation of neurons in a region called the dorsomedial hypothalamus (DMH). These specific neurons control WAT function, while WAT controls the activity of those neurons. The strength of this interesting feedback loop wanes over time, but why and how this feedback loop wanes over time remains unknown. In this research proposal, we will address this question and analyze how the functions of the DMH neurons and WAT deteriorate. The anticipated outcome of this study will advance our understanding of the systemic regulation of mammalian aging and longevity and provide a new possibility to develop an effective anti-aging intervention based on this critical tissue-to-tissue communication between the hypothalamus and WAT.
