IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is considered the “signature” injury of the recent US wartime conflicts, with approximately 15% of warfighters experiencing single or multiple mild TBIs (mTBI). PTSD is a frequent comorbidity in this population, with almost 35% of mTBI exposed Veterans reporting qualifying symptoms associated with their service in theater. The presenting symptomatology of PTSD (i.e., emotion dysregulation and cognitive deficits) may have an underlying basis in the biomechanical disruption by TBI of brain regions underlying emotional processing and memory. This same disruption may interfere with effective treatment. Animal models are necessary in order to unravel the effect of TBI on the brain circuitry underlying PTSD. We will therefore utilize high density electrophysiology (recordings) and stimulation in awake behaving rats and pigs to elucidate how TBI affects the circuitry underlying PTSD, the acquisition and extinction of PTSD-like behavioral phenotypes, and to develop a new neuromodulatory treatment for this co-morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Jackson Laboratory, in partnership with community college faculty across the state of Connecticut, proposes to develop a curriculum program to improve genetics and genomics literacy among community college students preparing to enter the biomedical research workforce. By targeting students training for entry-level professions and by developing online content modules, we seek to train a broad and diverse audience. Our content modules will expand students’ understanding of how human genomics intersects with healthcare, ultimately strengthening the future STEM workforce.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are requesting funds for a QPatch II-48 automated patch clamp system, designed for acquiring high-fidelity patch clamp data at medium to high-throughput. The design of the QPatch II recording plates allows patch clamping of cell types not commonly used with automated patch clamp systems, such as primary immune cells and iPSC-derived neurons or cardiomyocytes. There is currently no such system available at NYU or within New York City. High-fidelity patch clamp recordings using this instrument will allow us to gain insight into the roles of ion channels across disciplines (pathology, cardiology, immunology and neuroscience) and will facilitate translational research at NYUGSOM and the NYU College of Dentistry in Lower Manhattan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (FLC) is a rare cancer of children and young adults that has no standard or effective treatment options. The overall goal of our project is to study a novel cancer treatment that targets the unique metabolism of FLC tumors, in combination with other treatments that work on the human immune system. We will test this treatment approach in FLC patients and also learn about the mechanisms of response with this approach using tumors from the patients as well as preclinical models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal offers ungated, quantitative myocardial perfusion magnetic resonance imaging for atrial fibrillation (AFIB) patients. The new data acquisition and processing methods will allow for improved identification and quantification of the amount of myocardial tissue at risk in patients with AFIB and coronary artery disease. Accurate identification of the myocardial tissue at risk helps in their treatment management.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is relevant to public health as it examines the mechanistic-basis of calcific aortic stenosis; a prevalent disease observed in up to 35% of the population, including children suffering the congenital aortic valve malformation, Bicuspid Aortic Valve disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Allergic diseases afflict 40% of the United States population, but it is unknown how allergens activate dendritic cells which are required for the initiation of allergic immune responses. A research program will be undertaken to study the neuroimmune interactions that endow sensory neurons with the ability to detect allergens, and how sensory neurons and dendritic cells interact to promote the activation of the allergic immune response. These studies will provide fundamental basic immunological insights into how allergic disease is initiated and will lay the foundation to develop novel therapeutic strategies to prevent and treat allergic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetics and genomics are expanding into biomedical research and healthcare, so it is essential that all levels of the research and clinical workforce have some knowledge regarding these topics to ensure that this expansion is done in an inclusive and ethical way. Given the relatively high prevalence of many genetic conditions (e.g., familial hypercholesterolemia, breast cancer, sickle cell disease, etc.), establishing a knowledge-base for the wide applicability of genetics and genomics to the general public will facilitate integration of these topics into research to benefit health outcomes. We will create and freely share genomics learning modules (GEMs) enabling entry-level training and certificate programs to add genetics and genomics education to their curricula so that their graduates will be able to use, apply and disseminate this knowledge.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Illumination of many biomolecules produces a characteristic optical signature. These signatures provide valuable information on the three-dimensional structure of the biomolecule, including how structural changes enable biomolecular function, and how mutations or other modifications affect function. Purchase of the proposed instrument will enable University of Notre Dame researchers to measure these optical signatures as part of a broader effort to understand the molecular details of a wide variety of biological processes, including protein folding and aggregation, bacterial pathogenesis, and cancer mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project, to increase NCI clinical trials capacity, within the Michigan Cancer Research Consortium (MCRC)-National Community Oncology Research Program, will be the first to be completed by a Clinician Scientist (Elie Dib, MD, MS, FACP) who works with patients and families in a community setting. Nationally, the majority of cancer care is delivered in the community setting, making it essential to have representation from this type of research leader. Outside of MCRC, significant impact will also be felt by the Alliance Research Base and NCI, due to Dr. Dib’s deep contributions to clinical trials protocols, committees, and initiatives focused on immuno-oncology, precision oncology, and prevention and symptom intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) can alter the mRNA translation efficiency (mTE) of codons in response to severe nutrient-depleted environments to selectively synthesize proteins required for adaptation and tumorigenesis, we still do not understand the pathways that regulate this process in human cancers. This proposal aims to decipher the signaling cascades and mechanisms that regulate the mRNA translation efficiencies of Ser codons upon Ser-starvation, and to target these pathways during PDAC tumorigenesis. The findings from this work will have a profound impact on our fundamental understanding of the pathways and mechanisms that regulate the mTE of Ser codons, identify a therapeutic vulnerability in the adaptation to Ser-starvation in PDAC, and can greatly shift our perception of the effects of codon regulatory pathways in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: High Throughput Screening (HTS) employs advanced automation to test very large and diverse compound libraries for finding novel chemical modulators that serve as the basis for early-stage drug discovery. HTS workflow architecture must orchestrate the use of multiple instrumental components (i.e., dispensers, incubators, plate readers…) in concert with one another to complete parallel screens in support of an HTS drug discovery campaign. Requested are replacement dispensers that automate the bulk reagent dispensation into assay plates since the present units are obsolete having reached “End of Support” for equipment hardware and software operating systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The differentiation process of lung alveolar epithelial type 2 (AT2) cells into alveolar epithelial type 1 (AT1) cells plays an essential role in the repair and regeneration of alveolar epithelium following injury. Therefore, it is important to gain insights into the mechanisms governing this cellular differentiation. This project aims to explore the mechanistic role of mitochondrial calcium uptake in regulating metabolic dynamics, which influence chromatin structure and gene expression during the transition from AT2 to AT1 cells.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative State-of-the-Art Preclinical PET/CT Imaging System Yale University PET Center This proposal aims to provide a state-of-the-art preclinical imaging instrument for combined Positron Emission Tomography (PET) and Computed Tomography (CT) research studies. PET/CT imaging is used to detect and quantify biochemical processes and physiological functions in the living body across broad applications of oncology, cardiology, psychiatry, neurology, metabolic disorders, and inflammation. Addition of a new preclinical PET/CT system to replace an end-of-life PET-only system will allow us to leverage the Center's expertise in radiochemistry and quantitative PET imaging to support exciting research studying new mechanisms for the diagnosis and therapy of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will explain how societal stressors experienced from early childhood into young adulthood affect Latinx youth’s mental health. Using an integrated data analysis approach, investigators will pool data from five longitudinal Latinx cohort studies spanning 2010-2026 to follow 2,515 Latinx youth and mothers from youth’s age 2 to 22. Knowledge about Latinx youth’s mental health trajectories within a context of societal stressors and modifiable family stress processes and adaptive factors will inform effective Latinx mental health interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Neutrophils are immune cells that are critical for containing and clearing an infection, yet they have the capacity to damage tissue and contribute to microclot formation if over activated. Neutrophils may play an important role in pathogenesis of Long COVID. Here, we aim to define neutrophil phenotypes with single-cell RNA sequencing and test neutrophil functionality and contributions to microclot formation in order to define the role of the neutrophil in pediatric Long COVID. Our goal is to unveil novel strategies for diagnosing and treating Long COVID with the goal of improving health outcomes in these children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: To reduce the high toll of global deaths and morbidity caused by infectious diseases, we will generate and use new kinds of information about disease causing organisms. We will perform genomic, transcriptomic and functional research on viral, bacterial, fungal, and vector-borne pathogens under a Genomic Center for Infectious Diseases to identify new threats and targets for treatment, inform clinical treatment of disease, and support public health initiatives to monitor and respond effectively to infectious diseases outbreaks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Changes in endothelial cell function, which are the main lining layer of cells within the vessel wall, occur secondary to disturbed arterial blood flow, resulting in a process called endothelial to mesenchymal transition (EndMT). In severe atherosclerosis, and its subsequent clinical complications, such as heart attack, EndMT plays a fundamental role by promoting inflammation, yet the mechanism of EndMT formation secondary to disturbed blood flow is largely unknown. Our research identifies the interleukin-1 receptor activated kinase (IRAK1) as a novel regulator in d-flow-induced EndMT and understanding the mechanism whereby IRAK1 alters endothelial function may provide novel therapeutic targets to limit atherosclerosis and its complications in patients with heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Temporomandibular disorder (TMD), characterized by mechanical pain and masticatory allodynia, is the most common form of orofacial pain and negatively impact patients’ quality of life. In this project, we aim to identify and validate if and how LPA/LPAR signaling contributes to TMD pain. Success of this project may open new doors for development of safe and effective methods to prevent and treat TMD pain.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Both human disease and healthy human development are driven by intricate events occurring at the nanoscale within cells. The Zeiss LSM 980 with Airyscan 2 uses cutting-edge developments in fluorescent microscopy to let researchers at the University of Rochester peer inside the cell at smaller length scales, faster time scales, and for longer periods of time. This technology will have a transformative impact on ongoing NIH-funded research into how developing organisms form proper tissues, which molecular elements drive evolution, how pathogens cross from the bloodstream into tissues, how cells organize their DNA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: At least 250,000 individuals in the United States have a spinal cord injury (SCI), with approximately 12,000 new cases per year, and over 15% of these individuals are veterans (VA 2009). SCI typically results in loss of bowel function. The standard of care for individuals with neurogenic bowel dysfunction involves the implementation of a bowel program for predictable, effective elimination of the bowels. The bowel routine can require over an hour to evacuate the bowels and this process typically requires the assistance of a caregiver, which adds to the cost of care and reduces independence. Restoring bowel function is considered a high priority by individuals with SCI, but remains a critically unmet need requiring further development (Anderson 2004). This project will develop a novel approach using electrical stimulation to improve bowel function. Providing improved, independent bowel control is the ultimate goal of this project, which would enhance the quality of life for veterans with SCI and reduce the financial impact on the Veteran Health Care system.

PHR: Narrative Cryo-electron microscopy is the prevailing methodology for determining macromolecular structures relevant to human diseases and therapies, but is not readily available to researchers in the Midwest. This application requests support to overcome this limitation by acquiring a Thermo Fisher Scientific Glacios Cryo-Transmission Electron Microscope equipped with Falcon 4i Direct Electron Detector and Selectris Energy Filter as a shared regional facility at the University of Kansas Medical Center. This will allow researchers to obtain broad insight into a range of biological processes to advance their primary mission of improving public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Technologies that allow real-time monitoring of engineered immune cell distribution within tissues would transform patient treatment and management in oncology. This project will develop stimuli-responsive contrast agents that provide on-demand and long-term deep tissue imaging of cellular immunotherapies via diagnostic ultrasound, using anti-tumor macrophages as an exemplary model. Through this work we will establish a platform technology that can be broadly adopted for in vivo monitoring and modulation of cellular immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Expanded availability of virtual care encounters in Primary Care provides new opportunities to improve Veterans’ outcomes by aligning encounter modalities with their needs and preferences. Yet, Veterans and their Primary Care physicians (PCPs) lack personalized information about the benefits and costs of different Primary Care modalities that is needed to maximize the value of Primary Care encounters. To address this problem, we will use surveys and interviews to identify what Veterans and PCPs perceive to be the benefits and optimal uses of different Primary Care encounter modalities. We will then supplement our existing system for communicating encounter costs to Veterans and PCPs with new interactive messaging about benefits and optimal uses of different encounter modalities. We will optimize this novel Advancing Decisions about Virtual Service Encounters (ADViSE) intervention through user-centered refinement before evaluating its effects on Veteran-centered outcomes, use of virtual care, and intermediate health outcomes in a randomized trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative. Mycobacterial diseases are a huge burden on global public health. There is a need to better understand the biology of mycobacteria. In this proposal, we will characterize a novel mechanism of chromosomal DNA transfer that has been described in both fast- and slow- growing mycobacteria and, we hypothesize, has played a major role in mycobacterial cell-cell communication and the evolution of mycobacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are requesting a laser scanning confocal microscope for a microscopy facility that operates at Biosafety level 2 containment, for live cell imaging of samples containing human pathogens and/or potentially infectious biological agents. Located at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health our projects include work with microbial pathogens that cause Lyme disease, Influenza, Malaria, cryptococcosis, toxoplasmosis and listeriosis disease. The requested instrument would significantly enhance a wide variety of studies that are relevant for the advancement of public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Feeding is an essential behavior, and the proper regulation of feeding is crucial for maintaining physical and mental well-being. The proposed research aims to investigate the neural circuit mechanisms that integrate external and internal food sensory signals to regulate feeding behavior and feeding-related endocrine function. Compromised function of these mechanisms may contribute to endocrine dysfunction, eating disorders, and body weight changes including obesity, which collectively afflict a large proportion of the United States population.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative This application seeks funding for the purchase of an cutting-edge 3D stimulated emission depletion super- resolution microscope system. This state-of-the-art technology will significantly enhance the research efforts of 13 NIH-funded investigators who are addressing vital areas of biomedical research such as neurodegeneration, stroke, aging, vascular disease, pain, diabetes, heart failure, vision, immune-mediated disease, kidney disease, and breast and prostate cancers. Unveiling the molecular mechanisms at the heart of these substantial public health issues necessitates the incorporation of this microscope into our shared resources as a first of its kind at the University of Texas Health Sciences Center at Houston and the Texas Medical Center, making it a crucial and foundational addition to our research capabilities.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oligonucleotide therapeutics is becoming the third major class of drugs, with fourteen drugs approved. In this proposal, we request funds for equipment to synthesize, purify, and quality control a large number of uniquely modified oligonucleotides in parallel. This equipment will enable the screening and identification of novel therapeutics for a wide range of preclinical research by University of Massachusetts Chan Medical School investigators (and collaborators) and eliminate a significant roadblock in moving oligonucleotide-based therapies toward patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The hippocampus is a brain region that has a key role in learning, memory, and emotions. A group of neurons in the hippocampus, called inhibitory neurons, are needed to keep in check overall activity, and when they are abnormal the hippocampus becomes hyperactive, as occurs in schizophrenia and anxiety. The goal of this study is to investigate how these inhibitory neurons function and are connected in primates, which is necessary to develop therapies for psychiatric diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study aims to examine whether improvements in the academic or health outcomes of youth following a transition into high quality, mixed-income housing are mediated by shifts in social mobility beliefs, and whether these relations vary with age or racial-ethnic background. Results from this study will clarify a mechanism by which community redevelopment policies create opportunities for academic and health benefits and provide important information about who benefits most from these types of policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: For this planning grant proposal, we will complete the detailed clinical trial planning necessary to initiate a clinical trial meeting NIH and NIAMS requirement. We will specifically develop detailed clinical, operational and regulatory activities; develop a data safety monitoring plan; identify and vet clinical sites; develop and test training materials, obtain investigational drug; establish data collection, management and data analysis plans; develop a final budget; and submit a U01 application for subsequent funding. The overall goal of the proposed U01 study is to assess the efficacy, safety and durability of sequential treatment with denosumab and zoledronic acid to prevent and maintain bone loss after acute SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying negative regulatory effect of STING on antitumor immunity, whereby cGAMP importation into tumor-infiltrating T cell induces STING-mediated cell death. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: About 15-30% of the COVID-19 virus infected population suffer long-term and report ongoing neurological sequelae with diverse neurological manifestations including dementias. Often these dementias result from the abnormal aggregation of tau proteins, called tauopathy, which leads to loss of cognition, as in Alzheimer’s disease; however, the precise molecular mechanism underlying this remains unclear . Herein, we aim to examine the cellular and molecular mechanisms of COVID-induced tauopathy and identify and validate novel lead drug targets toward intervening onset or progression of tauopathy.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: NARRATIVE Replacing the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) system with the new NovaSeq X Plus will improve services provided by the UAMS Genomics Core Facility to all users. The University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS) Genomics Core Facility is an important resource for faculty and students in Arkansas who are involved with cutting-edge biomedical research. State-of-the-art genomic scientific instrumentation is essential to facilitate novel research for faculty and students in Arkansas and, help achieve the goal of obtaining NCI Cancer Center Designation by UAMS.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Our existing micro-CT in the core facility of Center for Collaborative Research (CCR) became dysfunctional which placed the NIH-funded researchers and other users of micro-CT in a dire situation. To this end, the S10 large grant mechanism is the only way for NSU researchers to obtain a new micro-CT (Bruker SkyScan 1276). Based on the following facts and condition available for this S10 application; 1) excellent panel of 7 major and 7 minor users who have research project that require micro-CT, 2) absence of high resolution in vivo micro-CT in any academic institution in South Florida, 3) experienced support staffs designated for the operation of the new micro-CT, 4) the efficient management and maintenance of all shared equipment in the CCR by Dr. Robin Krueger, NSU Director of Scientific Facilities, 5) the technical expertise of micro-CT operation available from Dr. Heidari, designated operator, and other major users who have experience in operating current SkyScan 1176 micro-CT, 6) well balanced oversight committee composed of internal and external researchers who are users and non-users, as well as 7) outstanding institutional support for the infrastructure and maintenance service, we are confident that the proposed acquisition of SkyScan 1276 micro-CT will strongly benefit the research and training at NSU and neighboring institutions in line with the mission of NIH.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Lightsheet microscopy is a technology that provides the ability to rapidly acquire millimeter-scale fluorescence image volumes at subcellular resolution, providing a practical solution to the challenge of fluorescence microscopy of large optically-cleared tissue samples, such as the entire organs of animal models. This is a proposal for funding to purchase an Alpenglow 3Di Open-Top-Lightsheet microscope system that will enable Indiana University investigators to conduct exciting and entirely new studies that will enhance their NIH-funded research and advance their goals to address serious issues in human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the last three decades, hundreds of genes have been associated with inherited retinal dystrophy highlighting the heterogeneous basis of these blinding diseases. Here, we identify a shared photoreceptor nuclear migration pathology caused by mutations in either ARL3 or RP2 genes linked to autosomal dominant and X-linked retinitis pigmentosa, respectively. Using an RP2 mouse model we will investigate how misplaced nuclei impact photoreceptor function and disease progression, examine gene-independent therapies, and elucidate the signal guiding nuclear migration during retinal development; so that we, as a community, are better positioned to develop new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The indirect calorimetry system, Promethion-Core, is one of the best products in the market that has been used by a long list of NIH-funded research institutes. It simultaneously quantifies multiple parameters including oxygen consumption, carbon dioxide production, energy expenditure, substrate utilization, food and water intake, and spontaneous activity. Those data are crucial for research groups that study a wide range of diseases related to metabolic disorders, such as diabetes, obesity and cardiovascular diseases, cancer, and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Rapid advancements in genomics have resulted in remarkable achievements, but they have also exposed inequities in supporting entry-level educators, particularly at community colleges that serve under- represented students. To bridge this divide, we propose the creation of the Genomic Education Modules (GEMs), grounded in real genomic data research, and designed to fill needs within existing courses, that focus on strengthening participants’ hands-on skills with data. Our strategy also includes training through a yearly in-person Learn-a-thon, comprehensive support, and scalability that leverages our experience bringing online education to millions of learners, ensuring flexibility and adaptability for a broad network of educators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will apply lessons learned from past Mixed Toxin Exposures (MTE) to assess the short term (~2-3 years) health impact of MTE following the East Palestine, Ohio (EP) train derailment and associated toxin release – and to learn lessons from this that can be applied to mitigate impact when the next MTE event strikes. This study assesses both EP toxin (EPT)-specific and previously MTE-related health outcomes to provide the broadest possible contribution to knowledge. It takes understanding (that we have pioneered) of toxicity mechanisms that traverse specific chemical class, to inform assessment of protection and vulnerability factors that may help this study to not only improve the lives of those affected in this MTE event but potentially the lives of others when future such incidents arise.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Positron Emission Tomography (PET) /Computed Tomography (PET/CT) is critical for the development of new molecularly targeted radiopharmaceuticals for imaging and theranostic treatment of cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Interleukin-6 (IL-6), a pleiotropic cytokine that functions through “cis-“ and “trans-“ signaling, plays an important role in the pathogenesis of diabetic retinopathy (DR). We hypothesize that disruption of the IL-6 cis-trans balance within Müller glial cells (MGCs) contributes to the altered levels of vascular endothelial growth factor A & B (VEGFA, VEGFB) seen in DR, and that the contribution of IL-6 to oxidative stress and blood-retinal barrier breakdown may be mediated by a VEGF-dependent mechanism. Results from our proposed studies have the potential to provide a new therapeutic approach to mitigate the retinal neurovascular pathology associated with diabetes by restoring the IL-6 cis-trans balance in the retina.

PHR: Project Narrative Macro-autophagy and mitophagy are crucial for maintaining cellular homeostasis by efficiently removing unwanted cellular proteins and damaged mitochondria. This proposal will investigate the beneficial role and mechanisms of Sigmar1-mediated activation of macro-autophagy and mitophagy in protecting HF. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it investigates whether a novel artificial intelligence– based method, which allows primary care providers to screen patients for vision-threatening diabetic eye disease in the primary care clinic, improves screening and follow-up care rates across race/ethnicity groups and reduces racial/ethnic disparities in screening. If this screening strategy is effective, it could replace our current screening system, in which primary care providers must refer patients with diabetes to an eye care provider for a dilated eye exam, a separate appointment that less than one-third of at-risk patients attend. Because higher screening and follow-up care rates would prevent unnecessary vision loss, the proposed research is relevant to the National Eye Institute’s Strategic Plan and Notice of Special Interest, which emphasize the importance of eliminating vision loss and improving quality of life through public health and disparities research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Primary cilia are signaling hubs on the cell surface with demonstrated roles in promoting islet cell coordination and function in diabetes, however the signaling pathways by which cilia mediate islet cell communication have not been elucidated. This proposal aims to identify the intra-islet paracrine regulatory mechanisms by which primary cilia modulate islet cell activity via the major α/β-cell secretory products. Completion of this study will facilitate the identification of new therapeutic targets for preserving islet function and improving glucose control in diabetes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks support to acquire a state-of-the-art fluorescence activated cell sorter (FACS, Becton Dickenson FACS Melody instrument) for use by Stanley Manne Children’s Research Institute (SMCRI) investigators at the Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital in Chicago. FACS analysis is critically important for biomedical research in diverse disciplines related to human health, as it permits the collection of specific cell types from heterogeneous suspensions of cells, typically obtained through the enzymatic digestion of intact tissues, organs or tumors. SMCRI investigators currently must compete for access to heavily subscribed FACS instruments at neighboring institutions, so the acquisition of this instrument will accelerate research productivity of its investigators who study diverse biomedical processes that are central to human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to enhance our understanding of a type of cell called a mural cell, which plays a crucial role in the health and function of our blood vessels. We plan to utilize cutting-edge techniques to manipulate stem cells, turning them into mural cells, which we will then study in a lab-created miniature organ model. This research will expand our knowledge of blood vessel development and function and pave the way for potential new vascular disease treatments and regenerative medicine advancements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a versatile and flexible light-sheet fluorescence microscopy (LSFM) platform, which will be able to perform a wide range of imaging applications, ranging from single cells to cleared tissues. LSFM are typically highly specialized instruments, but we hypothesize that versatility is needed to realize the full potential of LSFM in the life sciences. To study the efficacy of therapies, we will image calcium signaling and cytoskeletal structure in human derived cardiomyocytes, highlighting the adaptability and potential of our instrument in biomedical research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias are significant drivers of disability, health burden, and costs for older adults, their families, healthcare systems, and public programs such as Medicare and Medicaid. The research will discover how high glucose levels from diabetes and pre-diabetes, diabetes treatment, and injury to the brain’s blood vessels impact cognitive function and the risk of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (in layperson language) The research projects contained in LIFESPAN-D will determine the health and cost-related effects of two large federal nutrition assistance programs (SNAP and WIC) on diabetes outcomes across the life span. Food insecurity is a common, potent factor that leads to type 2 diabetes among low-income populations and contributes to socioeconomic and racial/ethnic difference in health for people with diabetes. We will take advantage of new policies in SNAP and WIC rolling out in California so as to measure the effects of these programs on (a) diabetes care and diabetes complications (such as heart attacks, kidney failure, amputations) among older adults who already have type 2 diabetes, as well as (b) the development of pregnancy-related diabetes or type 2 diabetes or among pregnant mothers and adults with prediabetes, respectively.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-002 - Evaluation of Natural Experiments of Nutrition Assistance to Prevent and Control Diabetes among Low-Income Communities

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Providing health coverage for 37 million American adults who are poor, aged, or disabled, policy decisions made by state Medicaid programs can have a profound impact on the health and healthcare of people living with diabetes. Our proposed center will combine multidisciplinary strengths in diabetes care, health policy, data science, and causal inference and will leverage existing, unique access to national UnitedHealth Group Medicaid managed care claims and harmonized EHR data, state Medicaid, and Medicare claims from 3 states. With these assets, we will utilize rigorous natural experimental designs for the timely and policy-relevant evaluation of 1) the health and economic effects of different state-level managed care approaches for medication prior authorization and medication refill durations for diabetes medications; and 2) the medium- to longer-term effects of ACA coverage expansion on diabetes care and outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-002 - Effects of Medicaid Coverage and State-Level Delivery Approaches on Healthcare Quality, Outcomes, and Costs for Adults with Diabetes

Curricula, programs, and training within the department are designed to meet the professional preparation of students as well as the manpower, continuing education, training, and advisory needs of the region and state.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Occupational Safety and Health Program Improvement

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: The International Association of Fire Fighters (IAFF) is proud to be a partner with the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) for nearly 24 years. The IAFF has continued its nonacademic occupational safety and health training program to meet the specific training needs of fire fighters. The major objective of this program is to address the burden of occupational safety and health among fire fighters by providing state of the art training by translating scientific discoveries into practice through effective education, training, and outreach. The IAFF recognizes that every emergency call is a potential hazardous materials (HazMat) call. Each year thousands of fire fighters are exposed to chemical and biological hazards in the performances of their duties. The IAFF understands that training students in hazards, defensive actions, and to OSHA and NFPA standards can help minimize and eliminate exposures. Our mission is to train all levels of fire fighters in their own departments and customize the training to meet jurisdictional hazards. IAFF programs are developed and taught by highly trained fire fighters who bring valuable experience to the classroom. IAFF training efforts have proven to reduce risk and protect fire fighters safety and health through effective training.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: International Association of Fire Fighters' Emergency Responder Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance Statement The Meharry occupational medicine residency program provides high quality training opportunities that will produce exceptional occupational medicine physicians who will positively impact the health of workers and their communities. The importance of this training rests on the continually increasing demand for highly skilled occupational medicine physicians who can effectively address the health needs of a growing and diverse US workforce and ensure the highest standards of occupational health and safety are met. In keeping with the mission of Meharry, the training competencies are geared towards attaining knowledge and skills necessary for serving the healthcare needs of underserved populations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Meharry Occupational Medicine Residency Training Program

The design limitations in current PPE provide challenges for healthcare workers (HCWs), especially while doffing certain components of PPE. The improvement in gowns and respirators could have a substantial impact on public health, both domestically and internationally.

PROJECT_TITLE: Occupational Safety and Health Research (R01)

The project aims at providing education in occupational health and safety that is broad in scope so the practitioner is prepared to contribute to the advancement of the profession above and beyond the requirements of the law. It is expected that after a few years of practice, trainees will provide guidance and significant support to the advancement of health and safety in the workplace and will be resourceful in applying scientific principles for the diagnosis and control of occupational health problems.

The CCC will provide common administrative and technical support for in-person and telephone/video Network meetings, facilitate communications between study sites and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and promote the accomplishments of the Network to audiences beyond those reached by an individual site.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT United Healthcare has implemented an innovative program for its members with the most complicated and expensive health care needs, called the National Care Coordination (NCC) program. The impact of the NCC program on the care of adult enrollees with commercial insurance, specifically those who have diabetes, is a critical and timely question that remains unanswered. Our team will work in collaboration with UHC and the CDC to evaluate the impact of this program to inform future UHC strategies and national policies of care coordination for patients with complicated health care conditions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-002 A Pragmatic Nationwide RCT of Coordinated Medical, Behavioral, and Social Services to Improve Care and Utilization among High-Cost, High-Need Insured Patients with Diabetes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: NARRATIVE Diabetes mellitus is one of the most common chronic diseases in the United States and the prevalence seems to be increasing. South Carolina DiCAYA Youth is a state-wide, population-based surveillance effort tailored to estimate diabetes incidence and prevalence in children and adolescents under the age of 18 by type of diabetes, age, sex, race/ethnicity, and geography, and builds on the SEARCH for Diabetes in Youth registry effort in South Carolina and nationally. Understanding the burden of diabetes in youth will assist with future health care planning and public health prevention efforts.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-001 DiCAYA: South Carolina Youth (Component A)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes is one of the most common chronic diseases among adults, effecting over 30 million people in the United States in 2017, with young adults ages 18-44 years accounting for ~ 3 million cases with limited information on diabetes type. Ongoing, efficient surveillance is essential to inform health care delivery systems and generate testable hypotheses related to the natural history of diabetes in this age group. The current study seeks to assess the long-term trends of the prevalence, incidence and early clinical characteristics of young adults with diabetes in our racially and ethnically diverse population to assist in the identification of sub- populations for focused efforts on diabetes prevention and reduction in co-morbidities.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative Over 30 million people in the United States live with diabetes mellitus, and many suffer from diabetes-related complications. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act had a positive impact on patients' health insurance rates, healthcare access, and health outcomes yet we do not know the long-term impact of the affordable care act, nor the effect of health insurance instability, on diabetes-related complications. Answering these questions is critical to informing current decisions being made regarding the future of the Affordable Care Act and additional healthcare reforms being brought forth that could impact millions of patients living with diabetes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP20-002 ACE-D: Assess insurance Coverage Expansion on Diabetes complications

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the last decade, increases in diabetes complications such as hyperglycemic coma and heart attack have paralleled increases in out-of-pocket health costs among people aged 18-64. This project will determine whether 3 natural experiments that reduce out-of-pocket costs improve acute and chronic diabetes complications over the longer term. Results could provide evidence about actionable interventions at the Federal, state, and employer level that improve the health of diabetes patients.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Natural Experiments of the Impact of Population-targeted Policies to Prevent Type 2 Diabetes and Diabetes Complications - 2020

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) This Training Project Grant proposal is in keeping with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Healthy People 2020 (also with the new 2030 framework) and the NIOSH mandate to provide an adequate supply of qualified personnel to carry out the purposes of the Occupational Safety & Health Act. The main objectives are to: 1) seek support for sustaining and increasing the number of occupational medicine trained physicians who have broad experience and sufficient competence to enter practice without direct supervision, and 2) bring a dimension of training that emphasizes the occupational health needs of the rural workforce with special attention to agriculture. This will be accomplished through a multi-faceted approach including a didactic course of study, including the Agromedicine Workshop, exposure to outreach and research activities at the NIOSH Southwest Center for Agricultural Health, Injury Prevention and Education (SW Ag Center); a supervised practicum experience in collaboration with the Rural Family Medicine Residency Program in Pittsburg, TX and with the National Center for Farmworker Health (NCFH) and affiliated Migrant and Community Health Centers; and field experiences such as worksite “walkthroughs” at industrial, agricultural and rural job locations. .
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Innovative Training Experiences for Occ Med Residents in Non-urban & Ag Settings

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will increase understanding of the acceptability and health consequences of switching from cigarettes to electronic cigarettes among older adult smokers at high risk for lung cancer who are currently uninterested in quitting smoking. By switching to electronic cigarettes, older adult smokers will potentially reduce health risks that are associated with cigarette smoking, such as nicotine dependence and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Engineered T cell therapy can effectively kill ovarian cancer cells, but there are still tumor-driven hurdles that T cells must overcome to truly beat ovarian cancer. The goals of the proposed research are to understand precisely how these tumors can block killing by T cells and to develop rational strategies to enhance cancer- killing without causing adverse side effects. Many solid tumors escape T cell therapy using the same obstacles that ovarian cancer employs, so our findings will likely help improve immunotherapies against multiple cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes is increasingly prevalent among women during their childbearing years and disproportionately impacts Black and Latina women. Type 2 diabetes increases the risk of maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality, but there are currently no evidence-based strategies to implement clinical guidelines for improving reproductive outcomes among adult women with type 2 diabetes. The proposed research will advance our understanding of clinical and health system approaches to improving reproductive health outcomes and delivering reproductive health care to reproductive-aged Black and Latina women with type 2 diabetes, by: 1) elucidating their reproductive decision-making processes and reproductive health care preferences using person-centered and structural competency frameworks, 2) adapting an existing patient decision support intervention to support reproductive decision-making and reproductive health counseling delivery in primary care to meet the needs of this population, and 3) assessing acceptability and feasibility of the adapted intervention and examining the implementation context for the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The overarching goal of this proposal is to examine the organization and recovery of visual functions following large posterior cortical resections in childhood. Cutting-edge psychophysical and neuroimaging procedures, as well as novel analytic approaches, will be employed to elucidate the nature and changes in topography and selectivity of the cortical and subcortical visual system pre- and post-surgery (and longitudinally thereafter), and the mechanisms that give rise to the restitution of function. Examining the consequences of such resections provides a rare but highly informative window into neural plasticity that can contribute significantly both to a fundamental understanding of the visual system and to clinical and translational application (possible rehabilitation methods and guidance for surgical protocols).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: In the aging Veteran population, the prevalence of acute disabling events and chronic diseases will continue to escalate. Dr. Ryan’s ongoing research tests interventions to improve the health in aging Veterans after stroke and in those with diseases and comorbidities including obesity, HIV, and cancer. Her work develops exercise rehabilitation strategies to improve cardiorespiratory fitness and strength and reduce sarcopenia by providing new information to guide risk reduction and potential rehabilitative strategies in older Veterans. She also designs creative rehabilitative mechanistic research translating findings from the bedside to understanding basic mechanisms underlying disability at the cellular and molecular level. Dr. Ryan’s research, leadership, service, and mentoring combine to enhance the independence of aging Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension and atherosclerosis are among the major complications of diabetes that are associated with high morbidity and mortality, and therefore significant healthcare problems. This project will use state-of-the-art approaches to identify novel factors and mechanisms involved in the development of diabetic cardiovascular diseases, including those that persist even after glycemic control. The results could uncover much needed newer and better therapeutic targets to curb the development and progression of diabetes induced accelerated cardiovascular diseases, with significant clinical implications.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Following hospital discharge, risk of depression is significantly increased in cardio-vascular disease (CVD) patients. Moreover, CVD patients with depression face reduced functioning, increased morbidity and mortality, and diminished quality of life. Unfortunately, most depressed CVD patients do not receive appropriate evidence-based care for their depression, often because they are unable or hesitant to travel to VA providers for the regimen of 8-12 weekly visits of evidence-based psychotherapy such as Behavioral Activation (BA). We now propose to compare effectiveness, in terms of central outcomes of functioning, of BA for depression delivered via Home-based Telehealth- to standard post-CVD hospital discharge best-practices care in a 2x4 (treatment by time) repeated measures RCT crossover design (baseline, post-treatment, 3 & 9-month follow- up) with 132 depressed CVD Veteran patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The development of the peripheral nervous system is critical for proper motor function and sensory perception; however, loss of polarity in mouse Schwann cells leads to defects in timely myelination and Remak bundle formation, which can contribute to peripheral neuropathies and neuropathic pain. By understanding the interaction between extrinsic cues, from the extracellular matrix, and the internal state of Schwann cells, this study will allow us to better understand how Schwann cells interact with their environment to regulate myelination and Remak bundle formation.

Our proposed studies will enable the use of stem cell technologies to generate a more abundant and effective source of cancer specific T cell therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative We will use an interdisciplinary approach to examine how the activity of prefrontal astrocytes adapts from the onset of heroin use to habitual seeking and relapse. We will determine how astrocytes incorporate into the neural network to coordinate neuronal ensemble dynamics and heroin-seeking behavior. Results will identify astrocytes as a novel cell population that can be targeted to disrupt heroin-conditioned associations, reducing relapse vulnerability in patients suffering from opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Institute of Medicine’s report “The Health of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender (LGBT) People,” published in 2011, called for the development of evidence-based and rigorous research aimed at understanding the health implications of hormone use in transgender individuals. The goal of the proposed research is to extend follow-up data collection over an additional 4 years for this multi-site, observational study examining the physiological and psychosocial outcomes of existing medical treatment protocols for gender dysphoria in two cohorts: early pubertal and late pubertal transgender and gender diverse youth. Results from this study have the potential to significantly impact the medical and mental health services provided to transgender and gender diverse youth in the U.S. by making available rigorous scientific evidence outlining the longer-term impact and safety of early treatments based on pubertal development stage.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Uterine fibroids (leiomyomas) are remarkably common, benign tumors of the uterus that are a significant threat to women's health. Uterine fibroids are characterized by unregulated proliferation, which we found to be promoted by glucocorticoid signaling. The overall goal of this proposal is to determine the molecular mechanisms by which glucocorticoids regulate uterine fibroid growth and proliferation, including cross-talk with the ovarian hormone receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arterial smooth muscle is responsible for vascular tone and is therefore a major contributor to blood flow and pressure regulation in vascular health and disease. Derangements in Notch signaling result in smooth muscle dysfunction and genetic mutations in the signaling pathway are associated with human syndromes featuring stroke and vascular anomalies. This project serves to uncover novel molecular mechanisms through which Notch signaling regulates arterial vasoreactivity and hemodynamics and to provide the foundation for Notch- targeted pharmacologic therapies for treatment of arterial hypertensive disease, thereby informing our understanding of basic mechanisms of vascular physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Sex differences in the development and prevalence of mental illnesses are widespread, suggesting that the risk factors that promote disease susceptibility may be distinct in men and women. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: It is very difficult to treat the severe disabilities observed among Veterans with Severe Mental Illness (SMI), such as Schizophrenia, Schizoaffective Disorder and Bipolar 1 Disorder. These Severe Mental Illnesses affect thousands of Veterans; they are also associated with impairment in community (social) functions that increases the burden of suffering to Veterans and their families. Current treatment for the impairment is inadequate. We propose systematic studies to study simplified, non-religious Yoga exercises as a rehabilitation tool for Veterans with SMI. We will also study the characteristics of Veterans who are more likely to accept and adopt Yoga exercises over 12 months, and the barriers they encounter. Our aims are well-aligned with the VA Secretary’s priorities, the VA Strategic Plan, the MISSION Act and the Whole-Health Wellness approaches promoted by the VHA Office of Mental Health and Suicide Prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative Intestinal humoral response occurs in an environment exposed to multiple metabolic stimuli, from both diet and commensal bacteria. We identified the transcription factor SREBP2 as a potential key regulator of germinal center response. Oxysterols, oxidized forms of cholesterol, have been shown to control SREBP2 activation and transcription activity. This proposal aims to identify the mechanisms by which SREBP2 shapes germinal center B cell differentiation in antibody-secreting plasma cells and to map oxysterol niche and its extrinsic requirements. Thus, insight into the oxysterols-SREBP2 axis during germinal center B cell differentiation and into the cellular and environmental regulation of oxysterol production, will be generated from this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Within a decade, many blind individuals are likely to be offered a wide range of options for sight restoration - including electronic prostheses, gene therapy and optogenetics. However the vision provided by almost all of these technologies will differ substantially from normal sight. The question of this proposal is – What role can cortical plasticity play in helping patients make use of the artificial visual input provided by sight recovery technology?

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The Oregon Health & Science University (OHSU) National Library of Medicine (NLM) T15 Biomedical Informatics Training Program trains future researchers and leaders in biomedical and health informatics, the field devoted to improving personal health, health care, public health, and biomedical research through the use of data, information, and their associated technologies. This NLM Training Grant will enable us to support predoctoral (PhD students) and postdoctoral trainees pursuing courses, an in-depth research project, and related academic activities. This proposal is a competitive renewal for a seventh five-year cycle of funding for the OHSU program, which has been a leader and innovator in the program for three decades.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes and the glial progenitors from which they derive are the most abundant cells in the human CNS, and modulate both the structure and function of neural networks; they are also potential reservoirs of CNS HIV infection, which is itself associated with deficits in cognition that may both persist and progress, despite optimal control of systemic infection. Nonetheless, because of HIV1's phenotype-specific and species- selective virulence, it has been difficult to study human HIV1 infection, or its associated neurocognitive disorder, in animal models in vivo. To address this issue, we propose to use mice neonatally-transplanted with human ESC-derived glial progenitor cells and microglia - in which most host glial progenitors, and a large fraction of astrocytes and microglia, are ultimately replaced by human cells - to assess the effects of striatal HIV1 infection – with and without chronic exposure to methamphetamine, a common drug of abuse in HIV - on human astroglia, and ultimately on the structure, transcription and behavioral output of striatal neurons in the HIV1-infected brain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The research in this CDA-2 proposal is highly relevant to Veteran Health, because heart failure with preserved ejection (HFpEF) disproportionately affects Veterans and is the number one reason for hospital discharge in the VA Health Care System. Exercise intolerance, a predictor of mortality risk, is a common complication experienced by patients with HFpEF, perpetuating physical inactivity and accelerating disease progression. This research proposal will address this fundamental gap in knowledge by elucidating peripheral vascular control mechanisms (i.e., autonomic and vascular function) that underlie inadequate skeletal muscle blood flow, thereby contributing to exercise intolerance, as well as evaluating the efficacy of a novel knee extensor exercise training intervention to improve this aspect of HFpEF pathophysiology. Such improved understanding in HFpEF pathophysiology is a critical step towards identification of potential therapeutic targets and exercise-based rehabilitation strategies that may lead to improved quality of life and patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to develop multiparametric cardiac MRI and automated deep learning based cardiac MRI analysis workflows for improved assessment for complications after heart transplantation, the treatment of choice for many patients with end-stage heart failure. Cardiac MRI will be developed to allow for efficient application from pediatric to adult patients in order to evaluate its diagnostic value for non-invasively detecting complications and to investigate the impact of differences in heart donor and recipient characteristics on the performance of the transplanted heart. In addition, we will leverage an existing large cardiac MRI database to allow for long-term 5-year follow-up to establish new measures for improved outcome prediction and therapy management in heart transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will use innovative methods and existing data sources to examine the clinical, health system, and policy factors that impact health care use after functional disability. The population of older adults with functional disability is growing, and disability results in high levels of potentially burdensome health care use. Assessing the role of health systems and policies, such as Medicare Advantage, in shaping care for this population is critical to improving the quality of care for all older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall The University of Kentucky Center for Appalachian Research in Environmental Sciences (UK-CARES) will enhance programmatic and scientific capacity to facilitate innovative discovery and new understandings of environmental exposure pathways of concern to our community (e.g., water, air, emerging threats). Further, the Center will foster career development of environmental health scientists interested in tackling challenging environmental health questions facing rural Appalachia. UK-CARES will achieve these goals by providing advanced infrastructure and expertise, cross-disciplinary training and mentorship, and multidirectional community-academic partnerships to reduce health risks and health disparities in rural Appalachia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE These studies are relevant to public health for two reasons. First, they will identify the molecular alterations that contribute to the proatherogenic functions of CD8+ T cells and their association to plaque pathology and cardiovascular events. Secondly, they will determine whether these alterations are causally implicated to atherosclerosis in vivo using innovative systems models of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH For breast cancer tumors to survive and grow, they must escape detection and elimination by the immune system. Our previous research has suggested that the hormone progesterone may play a role in altering immune signaling pathways in breast cancer cells. The proposed study uses new sequencing tools and animal models to determine whether progesterone decreases the ability of immune cells to invade and recognize tumor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies will develop a comprehensive understanding of the molecular pathways that control the spread and recurrence of head and neck cancer. This information will provide the foundation to appropriately select patients who will respond to existing treatments, and identify novel strategies to sensitize tumors to treatment. Ultimately this will improve survival of patients with head and neck cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative – Overall Our goal is the characterization of immune signatures (IMS) of T cell subsets associated with a wide-range of common respiratory pathogens in the context of natural infection, disease, and vaccination. These studies will build on our current success as a HIPC center and employ longitudinal approaches to investigate the role of circulating and lung tissue-resident antigen-specific T cells in protective immune responses. To accomplish this goal, we will profile pathogen-specific CD4 and CD8 memory T cells, lung tissue-resident memory T cells and their T cell receptor (TCR) repertoires using unbiased single-cell assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: While successful genome inheritance requires that each gamete – sperm or egg – receives one copy of each chromosome, an estimated 35% of human zygotes contain an incomplete chromosome set, resulting in miscarriages and birth defects. The research proposed here addresses the mechanisms that regulate interaction and information exchange between the parental chromosomes during sexual reproduction, which is essential for correct chromosome segregation into gametes. A better understanding of the structure and dynamics of chromosomes during sexual reproduction will elucidate the mechanistic principles that control chromosomes across biological processes, ranging from gene expression to cell division, and will ultimately shed light on the chromosomal dysfunctions that lead to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Narrative This project explores a unique non-invasive therapy for traumatic brain injury (TBI). We have compelling evidence demonstrating the neuroprotective effects of a novel nano pulsed optoacoustic laser therapy (NPLT) applied to the injured brain. In the proposed studies, we will use an established pre-clinical model of TBI to evaluate the efficacy of NPLT in mitigating cognitive and neuropathological outcomes when applied in the acute or chronic phase after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood and adolescence are critical developmental periods during which traumatic experiences can lead to impaired executive function and increased likelihood of psychopathology. While stress related brain aberrations have been widely noted, far less is understood about their developmental trajectory and whether the specific timing of the emergence of stressors may impact long-term function of brain networks related to cognitive function. The proposed work aims to fill this gap by training a promising physician-scientist who will utilize cutting- edge brain mapping methods and longitudinal analytic tools to identify the impact of trauma exposure and HPA axis activation on developmental trajectories of cognitive control in typically developing children and adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Photoreceptors remain viable to perform their essential function throughout a lifetime despite chronic stress and maintaining healthy pools of mitochondria is crucial for photoreceptor health. Investigating mitochondrial movement and quality control mechanisms can yield insight into photoreceptor robustness. I propose using several novel transgenic zebrafish to assess photoreceptor mitophagy and mitochondrial movement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation is emerging as a potential treatment to decrease alcohol craving and consumption. This project will test the effects of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation to the medial prefrontal cortex with and without naltrexone on participants’ choices to drink alcohol and on brain neurotransmitter levels in a controlled, hospital-based setting. This application will provide Dr. Wai with the necessary training and expertise to conduct translational research using brain stimulation and magnetic resonance spectroscopy to identify novel treatment approaches and study neurotransmitter response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Microbial infection of the eye can lead to ulceration, a precursor to blindness. This project works out mechanism(s) by which a natural peptide in human tears is protective against microbial infection by negating previously unappreciated ocular virulence factors. A logical outcome is the development of new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This year an estimated quarter million American men will be diagnosed with prostate cancer (PCa) including 14,000 men in the Veterans Health Administration (VHA). Men with localized PCa are often treated with surgery, a treatment that is associated with high rates of side effects such as erectile dysfunction (ED) and urinary incontinence (UI) which impact quality of life. Yoga may improve control of UI and improve ED by bringing awareness to and strengthening the pelvic floor musculature. The objective of the proposed randomized controlled pilot study is to assess the feasibility of an innovative hybrid (in-person and virtual) twice-weekly yoga program that includes a prehabilitation component and to obtain preliminary data that will help assess its potential effectiveness in alleviating PCa treatment symptom burden (primarily ED and UI). The long-term goal is to develop a scalable and sustainable yoga program that helps VHA cancer survivors manage their treatment side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This competitive renewal RO1 application aims to further dissect the mechanisms by which hydrogen sulfide, a novel uterine artery dilator we pioneered the last funding cycle, utilizes to mediate estrogen- induced uterine vasodilatation in normal pregnancy and how these mechanisms are impaired in preeclampsia. New data obtained will enhance the cellular and molecular understanding of estrogens, ion channels, uterine artery vascular smooth muscle contractility and tone, and uterine blood flow. The knowledge will in turn inform new pathways to assist the development of therapeutics for combating preeclampsia and other pregnancy failures and will also shed lights on the understanding of the cardiovascular protective effects of estrogens.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) is a debilitating psychiatric illness impacting work, social, and family functioning. Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the sole evidence-based psychotherapy for OCD; however, no randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have examined the effectiveness of ERP among Veterans or individuals with both OCD and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The proposed 4-year RCT will compare outcomes of ERP to those of a stress management control among Veterans with OCD. Primary and secondary aims will examine whether Veterans’ functioning, quality of life, and OCD symptoms differ between the ERP and control in the full sample of Veterans with OCD, and in the half of the sample with both OCD and PTSD. The tertiary aim is to conduct a mixed-methods formative evaluation of the implementation potential of ERP in VA mental health settings. This work addresses RR&D clinical priorities related to cognitive-behavioral interventions for improving Veterans’ functioning, participation in society, and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of children and adults with dermatomyositis (DM) still experience long-term functional impairment with modern treatments. Drug repositioning is an untapped opportunity to identify existing treatments that work in a precise manner for complex autoimmune diseases, like DM. Using a combination of single-cell RNA sequencing, computational drug repurposing, and ex-vivo cell culture assays, we will identify existing compounds that perturb DM-associated molecular networks in DM-associated cell types with the long-term goal of improving health outcomes through the identification of precision medicine treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Proposed is a novel, non-invasive, laser and ultrasound based imaging technology, namely photoacoustic chemical imaging or PACI, that can map the key chemical properties of the tumor microenvironment in vivo, guiding healthcare providers on what would be the best option for treating the cancer patient, e.g., radio-, chemo-, or immuno-therapy. In this research, PACI powered by chemical nanosensors will be used to study the correlations of the imaged tumor’s chemical compositions with the cancer’s responses to therapy, based on mouse models of specific patient-derived breast cancer tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The purpose of this renewal is to provide intensive short-term research training for 24 selected pre-doctoral medical students in the most outstanding laboratories and training sites at the Yale School of Medicine. The specific research experiences will range from fundamental molecular biology and cellular physiology to applied clinical studies in heart, lung, blood, and sleep (HLBS) related diseases. The program is designed to attract the most highly qualified Yale medical students into careers as physician-scientists in the biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic diseases, including obesity and diabetes, are rampant in the United States and across the world. Nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ) is the master regulator of fat cell biology and the target of anti-diabetic drugs that uniquely reverse insulin resistance but have serious side effects, while glucocorticoid receptor (GR) is the target of steroids that are used to treat inflammatory conditions, but cause obesity, diabetes, and lipid disorders. Our innovative genome-wide and systems approaches will provide fundamental insight into molecular mechanisms underlying tissue- and individual-specific effects of PPARγ and GR, guiding new therapies and predictions of patient-specific metabolic responses to commonly prescribed drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart attacks–a major cause of death–are most commonly caused by coronary artery disease. While there are powerful imaging methods to detect coronary disease by PET (looking at blood flow in heart and inflammation in the arteries) or CT (depicting anatomy and calcium deposits in the artery), physicians are not able to use these data effectively to identify patients at the highest risk of adverse events— due to complexity and lack of automation. The investigator proposes to establish a large multicenter PET and CT imaging registry and with artificial intelligence tools, automate analysis and quality control, and develop decision support tools utilizing collectively all available PET/CT images and clinical information (beyond what is possible by subjective visual analysis and mental integration) for identification of patients with high-risk disease who can benefit from treatment with aggressive therapies—while providing patient-specific explanations of the risk factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Rural US residents are at high risk for food insecurity and type 2 diabetes (T2DM).6,7 Recent studies have shown promise for improving health indicators for food insecure people with T2DM by distributing healthy food,22-24,29 but these interventions have not been tested in the rural populations who may benefit from the interventions the most. This study's objective is to determine whether a scalable, sustainable home food delivery intervention that is designed with rural food insecure patients with T2DM in mind can improve their health and diet quality.
