IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Insomnia affects an alarming number of Veterans with psychotic disorders; and is a major contributor to poor functioning, high distress, and unrealized rehabilitation and recovery. I have developed guidelines to assist providers in clinically tailoring the gold standard intervention for insomnia–Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I)–so that it meets the unique needs of Veterans living with psychosis. This study will evaluate whether CBT-I delivered using these guidelines improves both sleep and functioning in Veterans living with psychosis and insomnia. This project will also examine the extent to which improvements in insomnia are associated with longer-term functional benefits. If CBT-I delivered in line with these guidelines is effective, the guidelines can be integrated into the existing national VA CBT-I trainings, manual, and online treatments to enhance the rehabilitation of this highly affected yet underserved Veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) is a major complication of diabetes affecting about 50% of the veteran population. The symptoms range from pain, numbness, paresthesia and ulceration in the extremities it is also the major cause of non-traumatic amputations. The only option physicians have to slow progression of DPN is glycemic control but in type 2 diabetes, the most prevalent form in the veteran population, good glycemic control is ineffective. There is a desperate need for an effective treatment. Our pre-clinical studies have demonstrated that increasing the dietary intake of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA), commonly found in fish oil, slows the progression of DPN and induces nerve repair through reducing inflammatory stress and increasing the production of resolvins, neuroprotectin and maresins, metabolites of the omega-3 PUFA eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and/or docosahexaenoic acid (DHA). However, it is unknown what the most effective form or source is for omega-3 PUFA and that question will be investigated in this application.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a medically complex disability that poses unique barriers to employment for Veterans. Returning to work after SCI improves health and quality of life, which in turn can lower risk for suicide in this high-risk population. Hence, the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) supports interventions that help Veterans with SCI return to work and prevent suicide. Customized employment (CE) is an innovative strategy for tailoring vocational services to meet the needs of people with complex disabilities. To address barriers to employment faced by Veterans with SCI, CE can be adapted for use by the VA as a part of SCI medical rehabilitation. The research goal is to evaluate a CE intervention for Veterans with SCI (ACCESS-Vets) to help them discover their strengths and find and maintain competitive integrated employment in their communities. This study may provide a model for making VA vocational services for Veterans with SCI more effective and sustainable.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veteran suicide has been an increasingly concerning issue. Suicide prevention is a top priority for VA as we continue to seek new and inventive ways to reduce suicide rates among Veterans. Many experts agree that suicide prevention efforts could be improved by making suicide-specific interventions easier to access. The current project aims to move toward that goal by testing a web-based suicide prevention intervention using an experimental design. The 30-minute intervention aims to teach Veterans coping skills that are designed to ease the emotional distress that often comes with thoughts of suicide. The project will evaluate whether Veterans report more improvement in suicidal ideation severity when this intervention is added to their normal course of treatment. Findings will aid our understanding of whether these types of interventions would be helpful to give to thousands of Veterans who suffer with suicidal thoughts – particularly if we can make it more accessible in non- therapy settings like primary care clinics, emergency departments, or from home as a mobile application.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: VA research has been advancing a high-performance brain-computer interface (BCI) to improve independence for Veterans and others living with tetraplegia or the inability to speak resulting from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal cord injury or stoke. In supervised research sessions, iBCI technology has enabled individuals with severe paralysis to use computers by imagining their own hand movements to control point-and-click actions for on-screen typing, browsing the web and other familiar enabling activities. In this project, we enhance deep learning neural network decoders and multi-state gesture decoding for increased accuracy and reliability and deploy them on a battery-powered mobile BCI device for independent use of computers and touch-enabled mobile devices at home.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This project will determine whether a specific type of deep-learning approach to artificial intelligence, utilizing deep variational autoencoders (VAEs), is as sensitive as a glaucoma expert for assessing glaucoma progression, will predict future image-based representations of structure and function in eyes with glaucoma, and will provide better correlation with quality-of-life outcome measures than with clinical data currently used. If so, incorporation of VAEs into clinical practice will lead to better diagnostic capability, earlier treatment intervention, and better visual and quality-of life outcomes in our veterans suffering from glaucoma.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Nearly 90% of people with Parkinson's disease have speech and voice disorders that negatively impact their ability to communicate effectively in daily life. This study will test the hypothesis that a combined speech and exercise intervention will improve speech intelligibility in people with Parkinson's disease and speech impairment. This approach would offer an affordable way to continue to both instruct and encourage training by veterans virtually indefinitely through our remote access technology. These findings may help VA clinicians provide optimal care for the many veterans with Parkinson's disease and speech impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UCSF Postdoctoral Training Program in Hepatology is designed to provide MD and PhD scientists the skills to conduct independent research relevant to the liver. The Program fills a need for basic and clinical investigators who will develop new knowledge to aid the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of liver-related ailments. The Training Program enables faculty to provide focused research instruction to 4 trainees per year. Importantly, it also enables trainees to enroll in didactic courses and obtain an advanced degree. The ultimate goal of the Training Program is for graduates to become independent investigators, meaningful contributors to the field of hepatology, and mentors themselves. The expectation is that the trainees’ research successes will translate into improved outcomes for patients suffering from liver diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative There is a nationally recognized need to train a cadre of PhD researchers who are prepared to conduct research at the interface between biomedical science and clinical medicine, where unparalleled opportunities exist to impact patient care. The purpose of this grant is to address this need and train the next generation of PhD scientists in interdisciplinary, translational research. We will employ a competency-based curriculum and provide clinical exposures to outstanding trainees in order to equip them to successfully translate basic science discoveries into clinical outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric endocrine diseases such as obesity, insulin resistance, and diabetes profoundly impact the future of both the affected individuals and society as a whole. T32 funding since 2004 at the University of Minnesota has allowed a group of experienced mentors with extensive research experience to successfully train the next generation of academic pediatric endocrinologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Drug addiction is a major public health concern, mainly characterized by high vulnerability to relapse despite sustained periods of recovery. The proposed experiments will characterize the mechanisms by which neuronal ensembles within the nucleus accumbens, a neural substrate for reward seeking and motivated behavior in the brain, encode cocaine seeking behavior and extinction training, in response to cocaine-associated context/cues. Knowledge gained from these studies will broaden our understanding on the circuitry coding drug-associated rewards, and therefore advance our fundamental understanding to the pathological neuroadaptations in the context of drug addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The microbiota of cancer patients is correlated with their response to immunotherapy drugs, but the mechanisms of specific commensal bacteria strains have not been elucidated and limit their translation into new therapeutics [7- 14]. We recently discovered that beneficial Enterococci strains express a unique enzyme, Secreted Antigen A (SagA), which generates peptidoglycan fragments to engage immune anti-tumor mechanisms. These exciting findings reveal fundamental microbiota mechanisms in cancer immunotherapy and afford a new opportunity to engineer a novel recombinant probiotic drug to delivery SagA, R-5780, to improve cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among the more common visually threatening congenital eye defects are anophthalmia (total absence of the globe); microphthalmia (anomalously small eye in the orbit); and coloboma (failure of the closure of the fetal fissure) – collectively referred to as MAC. There have been few if any population-based studies to: 1) describe the proportion of cases due to pathogenic variants in known MAC-related genes; or 2) systematically characterize co-occurring phenotypes in these individuals (herein termed “deep phenotyping”), which could provide insights into the underlying etiologies of these conditions and inform precision medicine efforts. Therefore, objectives of the current study are to 1) better define the MAC phenotype and 2) characterize the role of known and potentially novel pathogenic genetic variants that confer MAC susceptibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative MRI guidance of cardiac catheterization provides a non-ionizing alternative to X-ray fluoroscopy and can improve soft tissue contrast. Recent advances have increased the availability of MRI-safe devices, but clinical use remains limited due to the relatively poor image quality of single-shot, real-time MRI. In this research, we propose to develop a novel, multi-beat data acquisition and image analysis approach to improve anatomic image quality and device visualization, which we test in silico, in vitro, and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Our center will study how genetic variants impact function by studying their effects in all cell types of 8 mouse tissues. We will measure the expression of genes as well as the activity of regulatory elements in a large number of individual cells from these tissues to build maps of which variants impact the expression of these genes in different cell types. We will also measure the impact of genetic variation on inflammation. Our results will help interpret the impacts of variants on gene function in humans as well as support the design of better mouse models of human disease.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  This project aims to develop an ultrasmall nanoparticle, metal intarcalated carbon dots (M@Cdots, M=Gd, and Bi), to enhance radiotherapy against non–small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). We conjugate neurotensin (NTS) to the surface of M@Cdots to improve tumor specificity. It is expected that with efficient dose enhancement, minimal metal leakage, excellent tumor selectivity, sufficient intratumoral penetration, and efficient renal clearance, NTS-M@Cdots will lead to greatly improved radiation therapy outcomes at the same or even reduced radiation doses while causing minimal systemic toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to establish the neural mechanisms of intra-individual variability in responding, a robust characteristic of ADHD. We will perform secondary data analyses of three existing datasets, to identify a biological measure of neural processing efficiency and link this measure with both variable responding and underlying network dynamics. The results will help to identify an appropriate biological target for treatment and monitoring strategies in disease states, such as ADHD, where intra-individual response variability interferes with cognition and performance in daily life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Hepatocellular carcinoma is the fourth leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide and is marked by lipid accumulation within the context of fatty liver disease. This project uses microscopy, biochemistry, and in vivo mouse models to investigate novel lipid droplet trafficking mechanisms influencing tumor growth in hepatocellular carcinoma. Completion of this work will advance our understanding of the role of lipid droplets as potential therapeutic targets against liver cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The National Academy of Medicine (NAM) labels chronic pain as one of the most extensive health care issues facing our society with “severe impacts on all aspects of the lives of its sufferers.”1 Pain predominant chronic multisymptom illness (Pain-CMI, e.g., fibromyalgia) is a particularly debilitating and presumptive service connected condition for Veterans who deployed to the Gulf region. Health coaching is an appealing potential approach to improve the disability of Pain-CMI because it is personalized to the Veteran’s unique goals and beliefs about Pain-CMI and it will be widely available as the VA is rolling out health coaching. The goal of this proposal is to understand if health coaching is also efficacious for a complex pain condition, Pain-CMI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy is higher among rural populations, who have some of the lowest COVID-19 vaccination rates in the nation. Community pharmacists, who are the one of the most trusted and accessible health professionals in rural areas, are well-positioned to provide COVID-19 vaccinations and address vaccine hesitancy in their communities. This project will examine sustainable ways to support rural pharmacists as they implement COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy counseling practices to mitigate the negative impact of COVID-19 and SARS-CoV-2 variants in underserved rural populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Glycoscience Training Program provides an interdisciplinary training environment for a diverse group of predoctoral students with research interests in carbohydrates, working at the Chemistry-Biology interface. This training program capitalizes on unique research strengths and capabilities in the glycosciences that exist at the University of Georgia. The program will recruit six new T32 trainees per year, and will emphasize scientific rigor, quantitative methods, communication, and other skills that will prepare them for a broad range of career opportunities in research, education, and government.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) is a leading cause of mortality in the United States and around the world. Although OHCA occurs via heterogeneous mechanisms and manifests a time-dependent pathophysiology, the current resuscitation protocol uses a singular, one-size-fits-all approach that belies the underlying dynamic physiology within and across OHCA patients. The current project will evaluate innovative approaches of artificial intelligence that asses continuous bio-signals from the defibrillator monitor to gauge patient-specific physiologic status, which in turn may help target differential treatments that align specific therapy with the individual patient’s acute OHCA physiology, and ultimately improve resuscitation and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE SUMMARY Identifying the effects of a significant stressor, the COVID-19 pandemic, and underlying systemic conditions, defined together as a syndemic, on mothers and children is critically important, as impaired parenting impacts neonatal development and infant/early child mental health. This study aims to apply complementary methods to investigate maternal experiences of the syndemic, note differences between Black and non-Latinx White (NLW) women’s experiences, identify other stressors that may impact women’s mental health, and talk with Black women about their experiences with the syndemic and racism. We will observe early child development and parental interactions at ages 24 and 48 months, to identify how toddlers’/preschoolers’ environment and mothers’ mental health contribute to their development and well-being.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), one of the most common endocrinopathies in women, presents with anovulation and hyperandrogenism in adolescence, and is associated with multiple co-morbidities. Research on the presentation and response to treatment in youth is limited, and no mechanism is currently available in the United States to query the early natural history and response to existing medications in a diverse population of youth with PCOS. The overall goal of the project is to describe the presenting reproductive and metabolic phenotypes, natural history, and response to therapy in a large sample of geographically, ethnically and racially diverse youth with PCOS, as a first step to develop personalized therapy strategies, and priority areas for development of new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop a new implantable medical device for treating severe psychiatric illness, especially mood and anxiety disorders. Many, if not all, of these disorders arise from communication failure in distributed brain networks, networks that communicate through rhythmic, oscillatory firing of large groups of brain cells. Our device will implement new algorithms that measure and control that rhythmic firing, restoring patterns of healthy communication.

PHR: Project Narrative The central nervous system is an HIV reservoir and a barrier to cure of the virus. In this project, we will study the effect of a novel treatment with baricitinib to decrease the central nervous system HIV reservoir in people with HIV. If successful, this medication could be part of combination HIV cure treatments in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood ADHD is one of the most common neurodevelopmental disorders with prevalence of 5-10% across the globe, and is characterized by pervasive deficits in cognitive control and motivation. This project seeks to uncover dynamic cognitive processes and functional brain circuits underlying impaired cognitive control, its modulation by reward and their relation to core ADHD symptoms. The proposed research will provide new insights into the brain and cognitive bases of childhood ADHD using novel cognitive, neuroscience and computational models and will contribute foundational knowledge that eventually facilitate more effective and precise interventions to reduce the global burden of ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Symptom relapse is quite common in the course of illness of schizophrenia, yet its pathophysiology has not been well captured in most previous research, as few studies account for the common confounder of treatment non-adherence. In this proposal, we aim to study brain functioning in individuals treated with long acting injectable antipsychotics at the time of relapse, for whom medication delivery can be confirmed. The results from this study will generate knowledge about the essential brain mechanisms of psychosis relapse despite confirmed medication delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE Quiescence is a critical property of adult muscle stem cells, but how it is maintained and how these cells transition into the activated state in response to muscle damage are poorly understood. We have developed in vitro techniques allowing the study of muscle stem cells in a more quiescent state than previously possible, and propose research that will illuminate both quiescence and transition into the activated state. Such information is required for muscle stem cells to be utilized in a therapeutic setting for muscle diseases or aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Mantle Cell Lymphoma is an aggressive and usually fatal subtype of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma whose pathogenesis is poorly understood, and new therapeutic options are urgently needed to improve the care of MCL patients. The transcription factor SOX11 is over-expressed in over 90% of MCL tumors and is associated with poor prognosis. Using a combinatorial approach that incorporates novel mouse models of MCL, small molecule SOX11 inhibitors, Ibrutinib(BTKi) and/or Venetoclax(BCL2i) resistant primary samples and PDX models, this application will define the role of SOX11 overexpression in MCL and explore the utility of inhibiting SOX11 directly as a novel therapeutic avenue for this incurable disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) is a leading cause of vision loss in the US. Individuals with diabetes are instructed to receive annual eye exams until visible vascular changes appear which take 10-15 years to develop. The established premise that DR is only a microvascular disease, as clinically defined, has been challenged in recent years by evidence that retinal neurons undergo changes in function and structure prior to the vascular pathology. A fundamental gap in our knowledge of DR pathology is whether neuronal dysfunction is associated with or causal to the late stage vascular defects. The proposed experiments in Veterans with diabetes are designed to elucidate if neuronal defects precede vascular defects in DR and if treating neuronal deficits with levodopa early in DR will prevent the late-stage vascular defects that result in vision loss. The proposed work will inform the clinical management of DR and potentially shift detection and treatment earlier to prevent vision loss.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Substance use disorder (SUD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) frequently co-occur and having both disorders is associated with greater psychological and functional impairment than having either disorder alone. This is especially true in residential settings where both disorders are more severe than outpatient settings. Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is highly comorbid with both disorders and untreated OSA is associated with worse functional impairment across multiple domains, worse quality of life, worse PTSD, higher suicidal ideation, and higher substance use and relapse rates. Treating OSA with evidence-based positive airway pressure (PAP) in Veterans with SUD/PTSD on a residential unit is a logical way to maximize treatment adherence and treatment outcomes. This study compares OSA treatment while on a SUD/PTSD residential unit to a waitlist control group. We hypothesize that treating OSA on the residential unit, compared to the waitlist control, will have better functional, SUD, and PTSD outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk for acute leukemia treatment-related toxicities, but few studies have investigated survivorship outcomes in this subgroup. The proposed work will compare chronic health conditions, neuropsychological outcomes, and quality of life in Down syndrome survivors of acute leukemia to age and sex-matched children with Down syndrome and no history of cancer. Our objective is to comprehensively characterize outcomes in survivors of Down syndrome-associated acute leukemia and identify related risk factors, in order to inform clinical practice guidelines for survivorship care of this understudied and vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE High sodium environment can activate immune cells and stimulate lymphatic vessel growth. Our data reveal that kidney injury leads to renal accumulation of sodium, immune cells, and increased lymphatic vessel number but also causes a heretofore unrecognized impairment in lymphatic function connected to sodium transporters and lipid oxidation products. We propose intrarenal sodium directly stimulates lymphatic vessel growth but that lymphatic interaction with sodium-activated immune cells promotes interstitial stagnation subsequent tubulointerstitial fibrosis involving the sodium transporters and lipid oxidation products which we propose are novel targets to intervene in progressive kidney damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative There are ~400,000 epilepsy patients in the U.S. who do not respond to medication and do not have visible lesions on their clinical brain imaging data. Without visible lesions on their brain images it is difficult to figure out where in the brain the seizure signals originate and provide neurosurgical treatment to stop their seizures. We propose to develop a type of brain imaging that will detect many of the epilepsy brain lesions that cannot currently be seen and thereby enable more epilepsy patients to have the option of neurosurgery.

PHR: The Center for Studies in Demography and Ecology (CSDE) at the University of Washington proposes a training program to create a new generation of population scientists and demographers equipped with skills to conduct data intensive research with advanced computational and statistical methods. At the core of this program is a collaboration between CSDE, the eScience Institute (UW’s data science center), and the Center for Statistics and the Social Sciences (CSSS), three units with long standing relationships, a proven track record (including a BD2K track in Big Data for Demographic Research), and combined expertise in demographic methods, data science, computer science and statistical methods. Through this collaboration, trainees will take a series of coursework in the following areas: advanced statistical methods and machine learning, coding, databases, data visualization/communication, and data ethics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT There is a large gap in current biomedical research field to address development and training of individuals from underrepresented minorities who would serve as the next generation pool of qualified scientists studying host and microbe interaction. The MUSC RAISE program seeks to overcome barriers that have prevented or hindered undergraduate students from gaining experiences that would engage and inspire students to continue their professional careers in the field of Microbiology and Immunology. The major goal of the RAISE program is to foster the expansion of a cadre of diverse scientists who will become part of the biomedical workforce dedicated to the development of scientific advances to tackle human diseases and disease processes dynamically associated with host and microbe interplay.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Discovering the genes and mechanisms that make one individual more vulnerable to addiction than another is key for designing better therapeutic interventions. Here we propose to create dozens of new mouse models for addiction that we will characterize for addiction behaviors, brain structure, and gene expression profiles in key brain regions known to regulate addiction. Successful completion of this project will yield rich datasets and mouse resources that can be exploited by the entire addiction research community to discover novel therapeutics for addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maintaining body heat is necessary to survive in the cold, but our understanding of thermoregulatory brain circuits remains incomplete. The proposed project will determine the specific brainstem neurons and circuit mechanisms that transform cold-sensory input into “cold-defense” behavioral and autonomic responses. This preclinical information holds the key to translational studies that will exploit thermoregulatory circuits for therapeutic benefit.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gonorrhea affects about 87 million people globally, annually. The causative organism, Neisseria gonorrhoeae has become resistant to almost every antibiotic in clinical use. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is a devasting disease and the leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States, for which surgery is a critical treatment option. During surgical procedures for patients with NSCLC, many important decisions are made by the surgeons to define the diagnosis of the tumor and the extent of tissue resection, however the clinical technologies that currently exist to support surgeons in these difficult assessments are outdated, slow, and prone to many errors, leading to dire consequences for patients. In our study, we propose to refine and validate a groundbreaking new technology that allows tissues to be accurately identified in the patient and on excised specimens, providing surgeons with new capabilities in obtaining real- time and molecular-based information to guide their surgical decisions and improve outcome for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying new therapeutic targets for neurological disorders, such as epilepsy, autism spectrum, or other pervasive developmental disorders. Determining how small G protein networks coordinate nervous system development and function will provide significant advances in the understanding of brain function and nervous system disorders at a fundamental level. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge about living systems and to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Polysubstance use of fentanyl and methamphetamine is increasingly common and associated with substantial morbidity and mortality, yet vastly understudied. The proposed research will use animal models of polysubstance use that mimic patterns of drug use in humans to examine the striatal neural mechanisms that underlie addiction- related behaviors. This work is significant as it will let us identify what neural cells and adaptations may be particularly relevant targets for therapies aimed at addressing polysubstance use and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Basic and clinical research can be expected to have a dramatic and constructive impact on visual disabilities. The Vision Training Grant at the University of Washington supports research and education of young scientists who will make the next generation of advances to conquer biomedical problems in vision and ophthalmology. The opportunities for vision training at the University of Washington are multidisciplinary and cover a broad spectrum of disciplines from cellular and molecular biology to systems biology, visual perception and computational neuroscience and we welcome the opportunity to contribute new solutions to help decrease blindness and morbidity in the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis is an inflammatory disease, occurring preferentially in arterial branch points exposed to pro- atherogenic unstable blood flow while the straight parts of arteries exposed to uni-directional athero-protective stable blood flow are spared. Here, we propose a novel hypothesis that atheroprotective stable flow stimulates expression of HEG1 in endothelial cells, which in turn inhibits endothelial inflammation and protects endothelial barrier function, preventing atherosclerosis development. Our study purports that HEG1 is a novel flow sensor (mechanosensor), which plays a key role in atherosclerosis development and is a novel therapeutic target in prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis.

PHR: RELEVANCE NARRATIVE Our observational study will monitor and evaluate a cohort of pregnant African American women to better understand the correlation between environmental stressors (i.e., demographics, socioeconomic, and psychosocial factors) and poor sleep quality that we postulate portends adverse pregnancy outcomes (APO) more prevalent in African American women compared to Caucasian women. We expect to uncover new risk factors predisposing African American women to APO. This information will help guide the development of preventive and management strategies for curtailment of racial disparities in APO.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) execute fate decisions to produce different blood cell lineages, a process which is perturbed in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). We propose to study how lamin B1 organizes the genome in 3-dimensions inside the nucleus in order to regulate HSC fate decisions, and how deletions of the lamin B1 gene contribute to MDS pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Aging is a universal and potent risk factor for heart disease. Blood vessels stiffen with age in both men and women with women’s arteries stiffening later in life, faster, and with significantly worse outcomes than men. We discovered that the receptor for estrogen, located on the blood vessel, plays a role in aging-associated blood vessel stiffness. This proposal will determine how blood vessel stiffening differs between men and women with age and how the female sex hormone estrogen and its receptor may contribute to this process. These studies will identify sex-specific therapies to improve cardiovascular outcomes with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goals of this longitudinal study are to identify diagnostic neural biomarkers of anxiety in adolescence; determine the effects of environmental exposures, including COVID-19 pandemic-related stressors, on anxiety-relevant neural biomarkers; characterize pre-pandemic neural, physiological, behavioral, and environmental factors that increase risk for adolescent anxiety in response to pandemic-related stressors; and develop composite profiles of neural, physiological, behavioral, physiological, and environmental characteristics from infancy through adolescence that robustly predict anxiety across development. The findings will enhance our understanding of the etiology of anxiety in youth, with a focus on adolescence, a core risk period for the development or exacerbation of anxiety. This knowledge is expected to inform the development of novel strategies to identify and treat youth at risk for anxiety difficulties prior to the emergence of clinical pathology and to characterize new targets for intervention for youth experiencing symptoms.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance) In the United States, children’s development differs markedly as a function of their family’s socioeconomic status (SES). Although risk factors contributing to these disparities have been broadly studied, we have only a superficial understanding of how these factors “get under the skin” to influence biological processes that shape key developmental outcomes like language and cognition. The goal of this proposal is to integrate approaches from the biological and psychological sciences to understand SES disparities in language and cognitive development. Using state-of-the-art methods from across the social and biological sciences, we investigate the contributions of adverse gestational environments and postnatal caregiving environments to SES disparities in language and cognition in the infant-toddler period and at age 5. This research will answer key questions about the origins of SES disparities in developmental outcomes that have important implications for theory, policy, and practice.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF SCIENCES, TECH & TECH OF BAMAKO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to develop a multiplex real time test that can detect both HIV and Hepatitis B infection with a single test. The test will be able to detect types of HIV and Hepatitis B viruses that are unique to Mali and West Africa. The test will also be adapted to the low resources, limited equipment, supplies, and technicians in a low- and middle-income country (LMIC), such as Mali. I want to become a leader in the development of tests to diagnose and monitor infections but are adapted for use in LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vein of Galen aneurysmal malformations (VOGMs) are among the most common and severe congenital anomalies of the human cerebral vasculature, causing sudden catastrophic intracranial hemorrhages that are often lethal despite neurosurgical intervention. We propose to use a multidisciplinary approach that combines cutting-edge, next-generation DNA sequencing and bioinformatics with biochemistry and structural biology to elucidate the genetic architecture and molecular mechanisms of VOGMs. Resulting advances will illuminate critical aspects of human cerebrovascular development and disease pathogenesis; improve clinical prognostication and decision-making; and provide a mechanistic foundation for the rationale use of repurposed drugs and/or design of targeted therapeutics relevant for VOGM and potentially other cerebrovascular lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Immunoglobulin µ (IgM), is a type of antibody integral to the mammalian immune system and is especially critical in the early stages of development. The complexity of IgM has historically made them difficult to study and our current understanding of how IgM functions on a molecular level remains limited. We will apply new techniques to elucidate study the activation of IgM, which will be critical for development of future biotherapies for treatment of cancers, infectious diseases, and autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative High-risk polypharmacy is common among older adults in the United States, is particularly dangerous for individuals with dementia or cognitive impairment, and is associated with harms such as adverse drug reactions, falls, and higher costs of care. This project aims to test in a pragmatic clinic-randomized controlled trial two electronic health record-based behavioral economic nudges to help clinicians reduce high-risk polypharmacy among their older adult patients and in the subgroup with dementia or cognitive impairment. If these nudges prove effective, they could be deployed in other health systems throughout the county to lower the risk for medication-induced harm to older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proteins shape our cells, tissues, and organs in response to the complex interplay of genomics with environmental and developmental cues, and thereby hold the key to understanding how individual genomic variation affects our phenotype, disease susceptibility, and drug responses. UniProt provides a reference resource that efficiently standardizes and organizes knowledge of proteins and their functions in forms that both humans and machines can understand and interpret. The UniProt knowledge framework enables biomedical researchers to rapidly understand what is already known, enabling them to design insightful experiments to understand human disease at a molecular level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis (CH), i.e. the presence of clonally expanded hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow and blood of healthy individuals, is now recognized as a near-universal phenomenon that predisposes to myeloid malignancies and offers an opportunity to understand the initiating processes of oncogenesis. This proposal harnesses unique genetic models developed in the Papapetrou lab to characterize the cell-intrinsic and extrinsic effects of CH mutations and investigate the mechanisms that govern the initiation and progression of leukemogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Calcification that develops in leg arteries of patients with diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and peripheral artery disease is strongly associated with increased cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. This proposal seeks to demonstrate that a specific enzyme, the phosphodiesterase 10A (PDE10A), plays a crucial role in vascular calcification by regulating p38-MAPK-MMP-3 signaling. Our goal is to target PDE10A as a novel therapeutic strategy to reduce medial artery calcification and prevent amputation in our patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Despite many advances, many children with type 1 diabetes (T1D) and their families continue to struggle with diabetes management, placing them at risk for short- and long-term complications. Strong partnerships between T1D medical centers, families, and school health staff through a collaborative care model may better support these children to manage their chronic condition. In this proposal, we will adapt and test a school- partnered collaborative care model for T1D, with special attention to factors affecting implementation, acceptability, and sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Results from this study could help address the current mental health crisis among adolescent girls by leverag- ing real-time data to identify near-term risk factors that more optimally predict when girls will experience esca- lations in suicidality, as well as common earlier precursors to suicide such as nonsuicidal self-injury and de- pressive symptoms, and leveraging neuroimaging data to identify which girls may be at highest risk. This infor- mation is critical for improving real-time risk detection, designing just-in-time suicide prevention and inter- vention approaches, and accelerating the discovery of potential neural markers of risk and/or protection from these serious emotional health problems. Additionally, the study will provide rigorous empirical data on the real-time positive and negative links between social media use and adolescent emotional health that can inform public perceptions and policies surrounding social media use among adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe maternal morbidities are life-threatening conditions that can occur during delivery or postpartum, thereby causing short and long-term consequences for a woman and her family. Cardiovascular complications are the leading cause of postpartum maternal morbidity and are more common among Black and Hispanic women compared to White women. The proposed project will evaluate an innovative postpartum blood pressure monitoring program aimed at improving blood pressure management, decreasing health emergencies, and reducing population rates of cardiovascular related severe maternal morbidity among women of color.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The collagen-rich desmoplastic stroma of pancreatic cancer has a big impact on its progression, aggressiveness, metastatic spread, and response to therapy, but the underlying mechanisms remain unknown. We found that cleaved collagen fragments stimulate pancreatic cancer growth and metabolism, whereas intact collagen fibers inhibit tumor growth. In this proposal, we will study the molecular mechanisms by which collagen fragments and fibers antagonistically control pancreatic cancer metabolism and growth through the receptor DDR1 and transcription factor NRF2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We seek to understand the neural basis of somatosensation – touch and proprioception – during manual interactions with objects. To this end, we measure time-varying limb postures, forces exerted on sensorized objects, and neuronal responses across the entire somatosensory neuraxis, as monkeys grasp objects whose size, shape, and location is under experimenter control. We then leverage what we have learned about somatosensory coding under active conditions to develop ever more intuitive ways to convey sensory feedback to bionic hands via electrical interfaces with somatosensory cortex.

PHR: NARRATIVE A network of signaling proteins convey and interpret information provided by T cell receptors to prevent human disease. The emergence of T cell-based therapies provides impetus to define the regulatory mechanisms used by the T cell signaling machinery to process information. The proposed research will use new approaches to interrogate the relationship between the regulation of signaling proteins and how a T cell perceives a potential antigenic agonist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The abnormal atrial substrate (atrial cardiomyopathy) is associated with elevated risks of ischemic stroke dementia, and other cardiovascular outcomes, such as heart failure. Progress in preventing these adverse outcomes has been hampered by unresolved heterogeneity underlying atrial cardiomyopathy; hence, this K24 grant will support a project that will use machine learning and dense phenotypic data to identify clinically relevant subtypes of atrial cardiomyopathy. Additionally, this K24 grant will foster a supportive environment for the mentoring of junior investigators involved in patient-oriented research and facilitate acquisition of new cutting-edge skills by the PI and his mentees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative We propose a path to commercialize an affordable, automated breast cancer detection (GeneXpert® BCD) assay that analyzes our published, hypermethylated gene panel in fine needle aspirates of palpable breast lesions to rapidly detect malignancy, for use in low- and middle-income countries. In collaboration with our industrial partner, Cepheid, and our clinical team in South Africa, we will analytically and clinically validate the assay for future commercialization. Innovative approaches to increase early detection and decrease treatment delays of breast cancer can save thousands of lives in the many resource-poor areas of the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the complex web of brain regions that control feeding behavior is critical for understanding and treating obesity. Although typically considered in relation to motor control, converging lines of evidence suggest that the cerebellum--an ancient brain region containing >1/2 of all neurons in the human brain and possessing powerful mechanisms for learning--also plays an important role in cognition and motivated behavior. The goal of this proposal is to identify a potentially vital role for the cerebellum in the adaptive regulation of feeding behaviors related to obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current HIV prevention strategies that require daily oral dosing are burdensome to the user and, consequently, are often not followed. We will use state-of-the-art chemistry and pharmacology research to build on our successes and continue the development of a long-acting, one-year implant for sexual HIV prophylaxis. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will lead to a rigorous, mechanistic understanding of the innovative devices' mode of action, protect all the relevant anatomic sites, and significantly improve clinical practice for HIV prevention and, possibly, treatment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Many Veterans suffer chronic pain from deployment-related injuries or other causes, resulting in poor quality of life. The amount of disability a Veteran suffers is a combination of injury (biological or neurological processes) and mental interpretation of the pain signals. In many cases, no physical problem is detected in an X-ray or other scan. Patients whose pain disability is amplified by psychological factors can benefit from receiving cognitive behavioral therapy and other mental health (MH) care in addition to medical procedures. However, many refuse this MH care. To help motivate these Veterans, this study will explore whether subconscious bias toward pain revealed in special computer tasks may be a useful marker to identify Veterans who could benefit from MH care. The study will explore how feasible it is to test for this bias with computer tasks, and whether subconscious bias is greater in pain patients compared to other kinds of Veteran patients, and whether bias relates to other measures of psychological distress. These data will help develop a mobile app that could motivate MH care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative Due to the national opioid death epidemic and serious OUD physician shortages, this proposed study of identifying implementation barriers/facilitators of establishing pharmacy methadone medication units (MUs) is timely needed. We will produce multiple publications and an electronic implementation toolkit for establishing MUs to quickly disseminate the toolkit and publications to OTP directors and pharmacists nationally through the help of our consultants. The content of the toolkit will use the well-established Canadian model of pharmacy MUs as a framework and specify applicable information of WHAT, WHO, WHERE, WHEN, and HOW instructions for each element of standards of care of MU based on study findings and allowed US federal regulations to help pharmacists and OTP directors establish and practice MUs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research has shown that uptake of our new PET radiotracer, 64Cu-CANF-Comb, in carotid atherosclerotic lesions in patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis who underwent carotid endarterectomy (CEA) surgery correlates with features of high-risk plaque in ex vivo CEA specimens collected from these patients. Additionally, preliminary retrospective assessment of outcomes in asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis patients who did not go on to surgery showed higher PET uptake of radiotracer in patients who later had ischemic cerebrovascular events than in patients who did not. In this proposal, we further explore the potential of this PET radiotracer to stratify asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis patients, identifying patients with ‘higher-risk’ atherosclerosis who would most benefit from surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the use of antiretroviral therapy (ART) has allowed people living with HIV to live without detectable virus, ART alone is not sufficient for reducing the viral reservoir. Adeno-associated virus (AAV) vectors can provide long-term expression of HIV-1 broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) and HIV-1 inhibitors, which could potentially replace or used in combination with daily administration of ART to reduce the viral reservoir. Here we propose novel AAV gene therapy technologies to suppress an established SHIV infection in rhesus macaques in place of ART, evaluate the rate of the viral reservoir decay, and improve the safety of AAV vectors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Retroviruses must integrate into their host genome and cause a variety of devastating diseases including AIDS and leukemia. Integration into the host genome is catalyzed by a complex of the viral integrase protein with the viral copy DNA (termed an intasome), which assemble with a variable number of integrase subunits depending on the retrovirus. The goal of this proposal is to utilize advanced single molecule imaging technologies and well- defined retrovirus models with different integrase multimeric architecture to quantitatively determine the rules for intasome assembly, stability, and host genome capture-integration mechanics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative As the medical field evolves in the 21st century, there is a growing understanding that minimally invasive diagnostic tools will be increasingly useful to diagnose or monitor a wide variety of diseases. This project will deploy and test skin volatile organic compound (VOC) detector systems in both hand-held and wearable formats for 20 diseases at two clinical testing sites. When coupled with other non-invasive vital sign sensors, these integrated data streams will be interpreted using artificial intelligence algorithms for real-time diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Major challenges exist for including genomic information broadly into clinical risk assessment in diverse and multi-ethnic populations, and issues of bias in research databases, community engagement, and access to leading-edge digital technology disproportionately impact underserved populations. We will recruit 2,500 ethnically diverse and medically underserved NYC patients into a clinical trial to estimate individualized disease risk and investigate the impact of genomic risk communication to patients and their physicians, including trust and understanding of the information, uptake of recommended interventions, and psychosocial outcomes. We will work closely with our NHGRI, eMERGE, community, industry, and health system partners, and use lessons learned to inform future research and clinical strategies, maximize efficiency for genomic medicine delivery, and promote health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to develop computer software that will improve the design of treatments for movement impairments caused by conditions such as stroke, osteoarthritis, spinal cord injury, orthopedic cancer, and limb amputation. The proposed software would take advantage of the same computer simulation technologies that have revolutionalized the design of airplanes and automobiles. The software would allow researchers to build a virtual model of the patient and then systematically test various treatments scenarios in the computer to identify the most promising treatment option, and how to implement it, for the patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Rare variants in SETD1A are associated with dramatically increased risk for schizophrenia, but the clinical phenotype and cellular mechanisms are poorly understood. We will investigate cognitive and psychiatric symptom phenotypes for carriers of SETD1A variants enriched in a founder population, the Old Order Amish. We will study pluripotent stem cells derived form a subset of these individuals to characterize variant  cell  brain  disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is a group of diseases that damage retinal ganglion cells, and can lead to irreversible blindness if left untreated, and as the world's population ages, it has been estimated that the global prevalence of glaucoma will reach at least 111 million individuals by 2040. While reduction of intraocular pressure can slow disease progression, patients with low pressure can progress to blindness. In this project, we will determine if non- invasive measures of the eyes vascular and how it responds to changes in intraocular pressure are determinant factors for glaucoma progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Through this Avant-Garde Award, I plan to fill in the gaps of the United States Ending the HIV Plan for persons who use drugs (PWUD). My pioneer award vision is to develop a mobile hub and spoke model that has mobile pharmacies and clinics on wheels that deploy a rapid response sustainable workforce of trained community health workers and pharmacists that literally meet the community where they live. They will provide rapid HIV testing, opioid use disorder (OUD) diagnosis, same day deployment of medication treatment for OUD, PrEP and ART, and retain them on treatment where they live to advance the goal of ending HIV in PWUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction is one of many prominent features of Alzheimer’s disease. Abnormal crosstalk between mitochondria and other cellular organelles were shown to play critical role in AD pathogenesis. The current application focuses on such abnormal inter-organelle crosstalk in AD neurons, which will provide novel mechanistic insights in AD pathogenesis and likely produce novel therapeutic targets for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The clinical implications of B cell deficiency in SCD are not fully understood and requires investigating both the clinical implications and the mechanism of B cell deficiency. The rationale underlying this proposal is that assessment of B cell development and survival in SCD may enable risk assessment or reduction of infections. By understanding B cell deficiency in SCD, we can reduce the infection-related morbidity and mortality in SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure remains a leading global health and economic burden, yet current therapies to treat heart failure are largely ineffective, likely due to late-stage disease intervention. We aim to elucidate molecular mechanisms that occur earlier and drive disease progression in order to identify new therapeutic candidates to improve clinical outcomes. In this proposal, we will investigate the transcriptional regulation of metabolic dysfunction and resulting energy insufficiency that is known to contribute to heart failure.

PHR: Project Narrative Successful completion of development requires tight control of gene expression. The research described in this proposal will examine the basic mechanisms that determine where and when the DNA regulatory elements controlling gene expression are used. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project contributes to public health knowledge by building on the Michigan Contraceptive Access Research and Evaluation Study (M-CARES) to evaluate the long-term effects of mothers’ access to free contraceptives and reductions in unintended pregnancies on an understudied group: children. By providing a more comprehensive evaluation of the intergenerational benefits of subsidies for contraception in the U.S., this study informs the implications for changes in Title X funding under the Public Health Services Act.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 500,000 people in the United States have end-stage kidney disease and are receiving dialysis therapy. Impaired mobility and disability are important contributors to their high rates of morbidity and mortality. This proposal tests a novel approach to improving their care by systematically evaluating the effects of dialysis initiation on skeletal muscle fibrosis and physical function, based on the hypothesis that earlier initiation of dialysis in appropriate patients could improve outcomes by preventing physical function decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Congenital cardiac anomalies represent the most common birth defect, affecting nearly 1% of all live births and despite significant advances in their surgical and medical management, these conditions remain a leading cause of death and disability in the newborn period. One significant source of morbidity and mortality arises from complications associated with the use of currently available prosthetic vascular grafts, cardiovascular patches, and replacement heart valves that are frequently required to perform reconstructive procedures. Tissue engineering offers a potential strategy for creating improved biomaterials for use in congenital heart surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative RhoGEF proteins represent a diverse array of signaling molecules that play critical roles both in normal human physiology and in diseases, especially cancer. This knowledge will greatly facilitate the development of therapeutics for the treatment of diseases where RhoGEF proteins are implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Immunosuppressive conditions, such as HIV infection, may play a major role in SARS-CoV-2 transmission and emergence of variants of concern. We will use advanced molecular methods to determine the effect of HIV infection on SARS-CoV-2 evolution and epidemiology in a high HIV-prevalent country. Information from our study could be used to develop interventions to prevent and prepare for emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Center for Genomic Editing and Recording will create technologies to enable robust, comprehensive exploration of genes and genetic pathways responsible for human disease in addition to the development of higher-level multichannel molecular recorders that will allow us to track and reconstruct the life history of cells in an in vivo setting. Collectively, these technologies have profound implications for genome science, therapeutic strategies for somatic disorders, and genetic diseases as well as understanding normal development and disease processes such as tumor evolution and the mechanism of metastases and response to therapeutic challenges. In addition, we aim to create a vibrant environment in which scholars across educational and socioeconomic levels can engage without barriers, where diverse students at every stage of development will be exposed to novel opportunities for training, research and skill development, and new ideas in a dynamic interdisciplinary research environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The overarching goal of this R01 renewal is to advance our understanding of the impact that LKB1 inactivation has on mitochondrial bioenergetics, metabolism and therapy response in lung cancer. We propose to perform an in vivo structural and functional imaging study of mitochondrial heterogeneity in lung tumors following LKB1 inactivation using a novel approach that combines positron emission tomography (PET) imaging with ultra- resolution 3-dimensional electron microscopy and respirometry. These studies hold promise to deepen our mechanistic understanding of how LKB1 loss represses OXPHOS dependent metabolism through structural reorganization of mitochondria with the goal of improving therapeutic responses in LKB1MUT LUAD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: G-protein coupled membrane receptors are the most common targets for FDA-approved drugs, and their patterns of protein phosphorylation contain the information required for their activation and function. However, it is challenging to characterize these complex hyper-phosphorylated regions with accurate site- specific identification and quantification. We propose to develop and apply an ultrahigh resolution mass spectrometer using ion mobility spectrometry which will enable the necessary resolution and sensitivity to elucidate these complex hyperphosphorylated regions of proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rapid expansion of the US older adult population highlights the public health importance of preventing frailty—an age-related syndromic state of vulnerability and heightened risk of adverse health outcomes. Increasing physical activity is a promising intervention to prevent frailty but initiating and maintaining habitual physical activity is difficult for older adults, particularly those encumbered by health challenges. This project aims to test and compare novel, remotely deployable strategies to reduce daily sedentary time among inactive, prefrail older adults as a first step to form long-lasting physical activity habits and combat frailty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Prions are infectious protein-only zoonotic agents that can rapidly evolve in a new replication environment. Little is known about how prions can overcome new replication environments that can include anti-prion drugs, environmental degradation, and transmission to a new host species. The long term goal of this application is to determine the relative contributions of the dominant prion strain and substrains to prion replication in new environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) offers a great promise for the treatment of a variety of diseases including blood cancers, but causes a major complication termed graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). Trillions of bacteria habit in human's gastrointestinal tract, some of which are potential harmful while many are beneficial to the host health. The current research aims at identifying and validating individual bacterial strains that can help to reduce GVHD and improve patient health, which may ultimately bring a benefit to the patients who need HCT for a therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the CD53 interaction network regulates normal B cell trafficking and controls immune response and antibody production in humans. This network also facilitates malignant B cell trafficking to bone marrow and lymphoid organs. Thus, understanding the specific functional role of CD53 network and the underlying mechanisms will lead to the better management of normal immune response and to new therapeutic strategies for treating leukemia and lymphoma.  .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Natural killer (NK) cells are cytotoxic effector cells that are important for antitumor and antiviral immunity. Improved understanding of the ontological relationships and transcription factor circuitry regulating NK cell differentiation and function is critical as NK cells advance into the immunotherapeutic arena. Our preliminary data suggests that Bcl11b, a transcription factor studied primarily in T cell development, may be a master transcription factor regulating canonical and adaptive NK cell differentiation. The experiments outlined in this application are designed to test this hypothesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We recently published an easy-to-use battery that can predict upcoming reuse events in patients being treated for opioid use disorder (OUD), and we then migrated that battery to a smartphone platform and demonstrated retention and compliance of over 85% in an OUD population. Our analysis of existing clinical trial data suggests that adjusting buprenorphine dosing in response to reuse events reduces relapse rates. Here we propose to: (1) test the hypothesis that our battery can be used to trigger dose adjustments before reuse events and that this has the effect of reducing reuse and relapse in medication-based OUD treatment; (2) examine the willingness of clinicians to employ this strategy; and (3) examine the cost-effectiveness of these adjustments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: JAEB CENTER FOR HEALTH RESEARCH, INC.
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes Endothelial Keratoplasty Study (DEKS): Impact of Diabetes on Corneal Transplant Success and Endothelial Cell Loss As individuals with diabetes comprise an increasing proportion of the donor cornea pool as well as the recipients of the donor tissue, questions continue to arise regarding the suitability of tissue from donors with diabetes for corneal transplantation, a major health concern considering nearly 50,000 tissues were distributed by United States eye banks and used for corneal transplants by United States surgeons in 2018. The DEKS will conduct a large, prospective, multi-center, masked clinical trial assigning corneas from donors with or without well characterized diabetes status to patients undergoing corneal transplantation, also characterized by diabetes status. The study will examine transplant success and the loss of endothelial cells after surgery, definitively determine the impact of donor and recipient diabetes on these outcomes, and thus help guide the eye banking and surgical community as to the safety and effectiveness of transplanting donor corneas from individuals with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying effect moderators is crucial for personalized delivery of treatment and prevention interventions, but doing so is incredibly difficult using standard study designs. This work will synthesize, extend, and apply methods for identifying effect moderators when multiple studies are available, with a particular focus on the complexities in mental health research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to understand the molecular basis for how an atypical chemokine receptor (ACKR3) that is broadly involved in tumor growth and metastasis, interacts with its cellular partners to control growth pathways and the scavenging of its extracellular ligand, CXCL12, both being key for its contribution to cancer. Through the use of cutting edge biophysical techniques, hypothesis based cell-based assays, and unbiased mass spectrometry, the research team will define features and mechanisms that can be exploited to identify new treatments for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As opioid use disorder (OUD) and hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection prevalence continue to rise in the United States, particularly among young women, new strategies are needed to identify high-impact venues to address both epidemics together. Pregnancy is a motivating time for women to engage in care for both their own health and that of their families. This project will utilize programmatic and public health data and simulation modeling to project the clinical and cost-effectiveness of employing interventions in the perinatal care venue to reduce opioid-related mortality and HCV transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood trauma survivors have higher rates of treatment dropout during medication treatment for opioid use disorder (MOUD), with those who leave treatment early being at extremely high risk for recurrence of opioid use disorder (OUD). Autonomic nervous system dysregulation and inflammation may mediate risk for dropout and/or return to use during MOUD in childhood trauma survivors, but mindfulness interventions may normalize psychological and physiological changes attributable to early childhood stress. The proposed project will implement a research program to elucidate the interplay of biological and psychological risk and protective factors associated with treatment retention in individuals in MOUD to guide the development of clinical interventions, improve treatment adherence, and reduce the risks of OUD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project addresses a significant public health concern – intestinal hypersensitivity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The current project will evaluate a novel theory of how changes in ovarian hormones differentially exacerbate psychopathology across the menstrual cycle. We will examine links from hormones to behavioral mechanisms to symptoms in a sample of female individuals with borderline personality disorder symptoms. Results will have implications for development of pharmacologic and psychosocial treatments to reduce the impact of hormones on a broad range of costly symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE This study is relevant to public health in that it will test whether an intervention to eliminate structural racism and discrimination via academic tracking reduces substance use and other risky health behaviors during adolescence and the transition to adulthood. Adolescent substance use may have long-term impacts on brain development, in addition to associations with other risky health behaviors and future substance abuse disorders during the transition to adulthood. Academic tracking may directly affect adolescent and young adult social networks, substance use, other health behaviors, and long-term health and life trajectories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of the RB1 tumor suppressor results in the transcription of cell death genes, but not a corresponding increase in cell death proteins. We found that the translation of these cell death mRNAs is silenced by the Pumilio complex of RNA binding protein(s). We propose to utilize a unique Auxin-inducible degron-mediated protein degradation system to dissect the detailed mechanism(s) associated with Pumilio complex regulation of pRB-regulated cell death transcripts in model human cells, Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC) cells and a well- defined murine SCLC model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM) is a potentially life-threatening pediatric autoimmune disease that often first presents with cutaneous inflammation and variably progresses to severe organ involvement, disease chronicity and damage. Development of an improved understanding of molecular and cellular mechanisms of treatment response in JDM holds the potential to inform precision medicine approaches to diagnosis, monitoring and treatment for children with JDM. This project will characterize gene expression signatures of skin and inflammatory cells in JDM to identify treatment response biomarkers and to advance understanding of tissue- specific disease mechanisms, while providing training to the candidate in dermatologic immunology and systems biology analytic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Executive function is an important domain of cognition that develops rapidly during childhood, and executive dysfunction is associated with risk taking behaviors, a broad range of negative outcomes, and psychiatric illness. A greater understanding of individual variation in brain networks that support executive function may be critical for the development of personalized interventions in diverse conditions. These novel clinical interventions would benefit the public health by reducing disability and limiting the costs to society at large.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: NARRATIVE We aim to establish novel chemogenetic neuromodulation strategies in nonhuman primates (NHPs) that build upon the strengths of deep brain stimulation (DBS) but resolve many DBS limitations, and to translate these to clinical therapies in humans. Our research plan has a tool development (UG3) phase followed by a pre-clinical trial (UH3) phase. Success in this work will lead to significant improvement in the treatment of Parkinson’s Disease and other neurological/psychiatric disorders. It will also provide new tools for brain circuit dissection that will greatly benefit a more specific understanding of the way particular brain circuits contribute to behavior and cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  The pathogenic mechanisms of cocaine reward behaviors are unresolved, and there is no FDA-approved medication for reducing cocaine use or treating relapse. Our research has genetically linked an autophagy- related gene Becn2 to cocaine-induced locomotor stimulation, reward, taking and seeking behaviors. This proposed study will demonstrate for the first time the role and molecular mechanism of the ULK1-Vps34-Becn2 autophagy machinery in the regulation of dopamine 2 receptor metabolism and cocaine abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal seeks five years of de-novo support to enhance and improve an established predoctoral training program in Quantitative Biology and Physiology (QBP). The mission of the QBP Program is to train PhD research scientists who have: (1) a quantitatively based understanding of the principles underlying molecular biology, cell biology and physiology; (2) the capacity to synthesize modern and quantitatively driven experimental methods with biology and physiology; (3) the ability to synthesize mechanistically and structurally based modeling skills with biological and physical systems; and (4) the capacity to assess emergent properties and behavior via integration across multiple length scales of a biological or physiological system or process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A functioning, well-regulated immune system is essential for the health and wellbeing of each person individually, and collectively. The system is extraordinarily complex, but great advances are being made at an accelerated pace that have tremendous positive impact on people’s health now, through such interventions as vaccines and cancer therapies, as well as enormous promise for greater health gains in the future. Our goal in undertaking the training activities described in this grant proposal is to train the next generation of reseach immunologists in technical skill, scientific judgment, and responsible conduct to become leaders capable of fulfilling the promise of immunological research.
