IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: We desperately need new drugs against tuberculosis which is still a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. M. tuberculosis (Mtb) enzymes in central carbon metabolism are emerging as promising targets for drug development but have not been validated in animal models that recapitulate the diverse and heterogeneous environments Mtb encounters in humans. Here we propose to evaluate such drug targets by dissecting the carbon source requirements for Mtb in the model system that is most similar to human Mtb infection and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Current methods of assessing somatosensory function in preclinical animal models largely depend on withdrawal responses to uncomfortable or painful stimuli, which do not correspond well to clinical tests of touch and proprioception. In this Phase II STTR project, Vulintus, Inc., continues development of ‘SensiTrak,’ an automated, high-throughput operant behavioral system designed to finely measure somatosensory function in rodent models. SensiTrak systems will provide researchers with unprecedented capabilities to reliably measure tactile and proprioceptive function in early preclinical animal models, and will help to improve the rate of successful translation of promising therapies from preclinical investigations to clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral neuropathy is a common complication of diabetes, prediabetes, and obesity, with no effective therapy and unclear mechanisms. In this proposal, we aim to determine the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which lifestyle interventions, such as diet and exercise, can be used to improve peripheral neuropathy by using a high-fat diet mouse model of obesity and prediabetes along with advanced techniques to evaluate Schwann cell-axon metabolic cross talk and energy utilization, nerve-specific molecular contributions, and the effects of insulin and insulin resistance. Together, these studies will advance our understanding of the benefits of lifestyle interventions on metabolically-induced nerve injury, and ultimately unlock potential avenues of investigation for treating PN in diabetes, prediabetes, and obesity to improve the quality of life in affected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  We have shown that targeting TrmD, a conserved and essential tRNA methyl transferase in bacteria, reduces protein synthesis in general and biosynthesis of the Gram-negative double-membrane structure in particular, suggesting a dual-strategy to accelerate bactericidal action. While many small molecular compound libraries have been screened to target TrmD, isolated hits lack the cell-permeability necessary to exhibit an antibacterial effect. We propose to screen a large collection of microbial extracts and fractions to target TrmD, using a novel and HTS-ready Ec tolC+ cell-based assay, to identify NPs that are cell-permeable, resistant to efflux, and selective of targeting, which will serve as leads for the next generation of antibiotics with a novel mechanism of action distinct from those currently in clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This study is designed to improve our understanding of the changes in brain structure and function that underlie the elevated rates of social impairments now increasingly recognized in prematurely-born children. Using cutting- edge magnetic resonance imaging methods, we will investigate these relationships in a unique, longitudinally- studied cohort of very preterm and term-born children with high rates of psychosocial adversity now reaching age 14-15 years and previously studied using advanced neuroimaging and detailed assessments of neurodevelopment and psychiatric symptoms across childhood. The overarching goal is the development of new approaches for earlier, more accurate identification of children at risk for social impairments, enabling progress toward targeted interventions which improve outcomes by limiting risks for psychopathology associated with prematurity and psychosocial adversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative How our brain precisely senses and responds to changes from the body’s visceral organs remains a mystery. The research proposed here will determine the molecular, functional, and anatomical architecture of the vagus nerve, a major interoceptive system and a key body-brain axis using state-of-the-art molecular and genetic approaches. This planned study will vertically advance our understanding of interoception, the senses from inside the body, and may inspire the development of novel targets and strategies to improve human health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Mechanisms of chromosome motility during mammalian meiosis Narrative Meiosis is a form of cell division that gives rise to sperm and ova for reproduction, and errors in this process can lead to infertility, miscarriage, and congenital disorders. This project will dissect the molecular underpinnings of an essential step in meiosis orchestrated by the joint action of nuclear envelope-associated and dynein complexes in the cell and reveal how a mutation in this complex results in infertility. These studies will provide fundamental insights into dynein biology and meiosis and bear implications for infertility diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the most common cause of blindness among the elderly and without a cure for early disease, is initiated by retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) degeneration. Variation in the RPE degeneration is well recognized in early AMD, but how it causes AMD is unknown. This proposal will determine the extent that RPE heterogeneity causes the conversion from aging to early AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) affects the lives of an estimated 5 million patients each year, but it is notoriously difficult to treat due to great complexities in diagnosis and prognosis. We will leverage large-scale EHR data from 17 hospitals across two healthcare systems to train, deploy, and prospectively validate a cutting edge deep learning model that uses real-time discrete patient data and raw CT image volumes to predict patient risk for a set of key actionable TBI complications. By referring to the model’s interpretable predictions and how they change across time, frontline providers in emergency rooms, in-patient units, and neurosurgery units will make better decisions about treatment and withdrawal of care, meaning the threat of this ubiquitous and devastating condition will be minimized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Non-healing wounds in diabetic patients represent a challenging clinical problem that often results in amputation. The long-term goal of our research is to develop small molecule therapeutics to effectively promote healing of diabetic wounds. The objective of this work is to determine the ability of our novel small molecule CXCR4 agonists to correct the diabetic wound healing impairment in vivo, optimize the formulation and pharmacokinetics in vitro and in vivo using a medicinal chemistry approach, determine the mechanisms of action, and then extend these observations to the clinically relevant porcine model.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Increasingly the role of drug discovery and development of novel treatments for endometriosis are emerging from academic groups as pharma interest in common and morbid women’s health indications declines. The current effort addresses an NICHD mandate of the Gynecologic Health & Disease Branch to identify and develop novel non-hormonal therapeutic agents for treatment of gynecologic pain syndromes, and engages transdisciplinary participation of reproductive biologists, immunologists, medicinal chemists, pharmacologists, biomedical engineers and entrepreneurs. Our collective experience integrates early adoption of biomarker and therapeutic co-development strategies to bring novel drug-like inhibitors of Jun-N- terminal kinase to targeted patient populations of women seeking new alternatives to control endometriosis as stand-alone therapies, or as sequential treatment during the required hiatus following hormone antagonists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 21-42% of patients with diabetes mellitus (DM) do not adhere to their medications, incurring a staggering lost opportunity for health. The proposed research will evaluate the effectiveness of novel approaches incorporating mobile technology and patient activation interventions, to achieve sustainable medication adherence, with the goal of preventing cardiovascular disease and its outcomes in minority and low-income populations with DM. This project directly addresses the NIH Adherence Network PA-18-722 FOA call for studies of adherence- promoting intervention research that address patient adherence to treatment and prevention regimens to promote health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance of this Research to Public Health)  To address the huge challenge to capture and integrate heterogeneous vaccine knowledge in an efficient manner, this project will develop VIOLIN 2.0, a new generation comprehensive vaccine knowledgebase that will cover a wide range of knowledge covering the full vaccine life cycle. We will develop advanced informatics technologies, including literature mining and machine learning tools, web interfaces, databases, and knowledge graphs to build the knowledgebase. Our research will lead to ontology-based standardization and integration of vaccine information, and support deep mechanism analysis and rational vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Individuals share segments of their DNA identical by descent due to inheritance of the DNA from a shared ancestor such as a great-grandparent. These identity by descent (IBD) segments can be detected using genotype data, and they can then be used to improve our understanding of human biology and relationships between individuals and populations. We propose to develop three new IBD-based analyses that will enable improved understanding of the role of genetics in human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The long-term goal of this project is to define and identify circuit-specific cell types–cellular scale connectome– that are selectively vulnerable to loss of cell bodies or axonal connections or change of transcriptomic signatures of individual neurons during the progression of healthy aging and Alzheimer's disease (AD). The data from this project will provide novel insights on the types of neurons vulnerable to degeneration and/or alterations of molecular/signaling signature networks in a spatial and temporal fashion and the correlation with neuropathology and cognitive impairment. This approach is a major step toward establishing multiscale models that will help to fill the gap between the effects of genetic variants (e.g., APP, AOPE or TREM2) on brain topology with molecular networks in aging and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Female mosquitoes find their blood-meal hosts using highly specialized chemosensory appendages that are responsive to host-specific chemical cues, and mosquito behavior directly impacts disease transmission worldwide. The current proposal is designed to discover the function of an uncharacterized family of olfactory receptor genes that are likely to account for a critical portion of host odor recognition in Anopheline mosquitoes and are responsible for transmission of malaria and other diseases. Improving our understanding of mosquito chemosensory biology could ultimately provide novel ways to interfere with blood feeding and other mosquito- host interactions, potentially disrupting disease-transmission cycles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mobile health (mHealth) weight management interventions show significant promise as a scalable public health tool to drive population-level improvements in overweight/obesity. However, it is unclear whether mHealth interventions produce equitable outcomes across sociocultural contexts and for racial/ethnic minority populations who experience disproportionate social disadvantage. To address this gap, the proposed project will involve a systematic review and meta-analysis of the availability and efficacy mHealth weight management interventions for racial/ethnic minorities, secondary analyses of the moderating effect of social disadvantage on mHealth weight management intervention success, and qualitative interviews of racial/ethnic minority participants to understand the perceived barriers and facilitators to mHealth weight management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative In response to virus infections, the human immune system produces interferons, a family of proteins that prevent virus replication. We have found that ADAM9, a protein expressed on the surface of human and mouse cells, is required to produce interferons after infection with a virus that causes encephalitis (inflammation in the brain) and myocarditis (inflammation in the heart). In this grant, we will determine how ADAM9 functions during virus infection to support interferon production; this understanding may lead to new ways to treat and prevent viral illnesses including coronavirus infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite years of effort, ethnic disparities in access to live donor kidney transplants – the optimal treatment option for individuals living with chronic and end-stage kidney disease, persist and Black patients continue to have the lowest rates of living donor transplants. This application proposes to explore the instrumental, relational and affective communication occurring between Black and Caucasian patients and their transplant providers during transplant evaluation consultations and assess relationships between these communicative elements and patient and provider factors, patient-reported outcomes and living donor transplant outcomes - living donor referrals, evaluations, and transplants. We will use these findings to inform the development of a communication skills training for transplant providers and test the impact of the training on providers’ communication about live donor kidney transplants with Black and Caucasian patients and living donor transplant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to utilize personalized artificial intelligence techniques and objective data (collected from smartphones and wearable devices) to create individualized digital biomarkers of rapid changes in major depressive disorder symptoms. This is important because, if we were to uncover personalized patterns between objectively measured physiology and behavioral changes and understand their resulting impact on rapid fluctuations in major depressive disorder symptoms, we would be able to define new, person-specific maintenance patterns that underlie the wide-ranging heterogeneity that is currently seen in patients suffering from major depressive disorder. Moreover, these advancements will provide a crucial step forward towards developing personalized, scalable, technology-based interventions that will be able to be delivered immediately (and, ideally, before rapid symptom changes) among those persons with major depressive disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Cancer incidence is significantly increasing in Ghana, a country that has a nidus of cancer researchers, but requires a larger cadre of researchers trained across multiple cancer disciplines to address the growing cancer problem. We propose a 5-year cancer research training program for Ghana, “Ghana IntegRative Approach to Cancer ResEarch Training: The GRACE Program,” that builds on existing research collaborations between the Moffitt Cancer Center and the Ghana health systems (i.e. University of Ghana Medical School, School of Public Health, Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital, and the College of Physicians and Surgeons), and leverages existing educational materials that will provide short-, medium, and long-term cancer research training to ~150 trainees, that can be sustained beyond the funding period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The behavior of the immune system governs the clinical course of people that are severely injured. We propose that severe injury disrupts immune system homeostasis making people more susceptible to life- threatening infections and complications caused by trauma and infections. This project will study how an immune cell type called regulatory T cells react to traumatic injuries and how they function to control immune responses to trauma and infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even when HIV replication is suppressed with ART, people infected with HIV present with a chronic inflammatory state that is thought to contribute to the development of neurologic and psychiatric co-morbid conditions. Here we have identified the sphingomyelin hydrolase neutral sphingomyelinase2 (nSMase2) generated ceramide as a critical regulator of the innate immune response to ART suppressed HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Allergies and immune system diseases are becoming increasingly common, especially in children. Treatment options are limited so research to identify both the roots of these disorders and possible treatments is critical. This Training Program seeks to recruit talented young MD pediatricians and PhD scientists committed to translational research and to prepare them for careers as productive investigators in the area of pediatric immunology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is increasingly appreciated that aberrations in lymphatic structure and function participate in the pathogenesis of a variety of pulmonary diseases including the abnormal respiratory mechanics of children with common congenital heart disease (CHD) associated with increased pulmonary blood flow (PBF). In this proposal we will comprehensively elucidate the role of the altered lymphatic mechanical forces and subsequent HIF-1 stabilization in the pathobiology of lymphatic dysfunction in this setting, and the potential therapeutic targets that may restore lymphatic function. The data from these integrated in vitro and in vivo studies may easily translate into novel treatment and prevention strategies for lymphatic abnormalities in the setting of CHD and other disease states, including pneumonectomy and other vascular abnormalities that result in increased PBF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Drug addiction, a chronic disease driven by neurobiological mechanisms and associated with predisposing behaviors including novelty-seeking and risk-taking, represents a tremendous legal, social, and public health burden both in the US and worldwide. There are limited treatment options and no pharmaceuticals for cocaine use disorder. By using and extending advanced mouse genetics resources and analysis techniques, we will discover biological mechanisms of addiction and related behaviors, which may ultimately result in novel predictive and therapeutic avenues for disorders of addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The sympathetic nervous system is a key regulator of whole body physiology. We recently showed that satellite glial cells, an often ignored cell type in the nervous system, are a key regulator of sympathetic neuron function. In this proposal, we will address how sympathetic neurons and satellite glial cells communicate with one another to influence the co-development of these two cell types. A better understanding of neuron-satellite glia interactions is critical for a fundamental knowledge of the normal sympathetic nervous system, and will guide new treatments for devastating disorders linked to sympathetic dysfunction such as chronic heart failure and hypertension.

PHR: Project Narrative Diabetic foot ulcers (DFU) are a common reason for hospitalization of diabetic patients and frequently it results in amputation of lower limbs and loss of lives. The proposed project is based on the study of DFU patients and aims to directly impact improvement of wound care such that wound closure includes restoration of skin function and is therefore less susceptible to recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Deficits in reward-related behavior are key features of depression, drug abuse, and obesity that are believed to stem from alterations in dopamine release in the striatum. Striatal dopamine systems are designed to integrate signals from the periphery to modulate reward-related behaviors, however the timescales over which these signals act, and their specific contributions to reward-related behaviors are unknown. Here, we propose to address this gap in our knowledge and uncover a new mechanism through which dopamine systems mediate adaptive behaviors that are disrupted in multiple diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Obesity is one of the most prevalent medical problems facing children and adolescents today, particularly among African American adolescents where the rate is alarmingly high. This study will test the effectiveness of FIT Families, a multicomponent family-based behavioral intervention that is culturally tailored to meet the unique needs of African American adolescents with obesity and their caregivers, against a credible attention control condition. This study has considerable public health relevance because it is delivered by Community Health Workers, maximizing the potential for the intervention to be sustained, and may reduce obesity-related health problems for a vulnerable population of adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Heart muscle is formed by protein filaments that slide past each other, pulled by miniature molecular motors that produce force and pump the blood. In healthy relaxed heart, the motors are switched off in an energy-saving mode, while genetic mutations can damage the motors, causing increased energy usage and heart disease. We will use powerful microscopes to observe the atomic structure of the motors, illuminating how they work normally, malfunction in disease, and are repaired by drugs that restore their function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Stroke is the leading cause of long-term disability. Most stroke survivors have some degree of spontaneous recovery, but this recovery is unpredictable and in many cases incomplete. The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand mechanisms brain repair after stroke. Enhancing these mechanisms may be key to designing therapies to improve recovery and attenuate disability after stroke. In this grant, we propose to study inhibitory parvalbumin interneurons, a subclass of neurons that are critical “gatekeepers” of brain plasticity. We will manipulate neuronal activity in parvalbumin interneurons to determine if brain repair mechanisms can be enhanced. Furthermore, we will examine the interaction of parvalbumin interneurons and the excitatory pyramidal neurons, to determine how these two classes of neurons interact to affect plasticity and brain repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The suicide death rate among Black male youth is increasing faster than any other racial/ethnic group, yet critical research gaps regarding the influence of racism-related stress exposures alone or combined with other proximal risks on suicidal thoughts and behaviors persist. This career development award will address these gaps by studying (1) whether racism-related stressors, such as discrimination, exacerbate suicide-related behavioral and cognitive processes for Black male youth; and (2) whether capturing these mechanisms in “real-time” can better enhance the early detection of suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Discovering unique, biologically-based pathways to problematic alcohol use (ALC) will help us tailor interventions for this condition. This proposal will examine patterns by which adolescent risk factors for ALC are inherited in families to identify new genetically-based traits; these traits could lead us to discover novel individualized treatment targets for ALC. Testing sex differences in these new genetically-based traits and their relation to ALC will shed light on whether differing treatments are needed for males and females.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In mammals, including humans, successful pregnancy requires that the newly formed embryo create its own placenta for the mother to accept and later utilize. At the same time, the embryo must also reserve some cells to become the fetus – a process that is less well understood. Using mouse as a model for mammalian development, our team will apply new methods to discover where, when, and how, the fetus is first established to enable healthy pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The morbidity, mortality, and costs attributable to critical illness are enormous and rising. This postdoctoral program integrates clinical experience, health services research training, policy analysis, and leadership and career development opportunities for physicians trained in adult or pediatric critical care medicine. These trainees form a cadre of physician leaders capable of improving the efficiency of critical care delivery at the bedside, across populations, and alongside policymakers.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Critical Care Health Policy Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) are the mainstay therapies for various malignancies; however, several common TKIs are associated with vascular toxicity. In this proposal, we will investigate the underlying mechanisms of TKI-induced vascular toxicity (TKI-VT) by employing iPSC technologies, tissue engineering, multi-omics, CRISPR genome screening, and animal models. The knowledge we gain here will provide novel insights into the pathogenesis of TKI-VT and enable the identification of druggable therapeutics to prevent or treat TKI-VT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of Americans living with serious illness, and particularly those with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias, experience burdensome care that is misaligned with their goals and preferences. Palliative care improves patient- and family-centered, clinical, and economic outcomes, but many never receive such care. This pragmatic trial will test a simple intervention embedded within the electronic health record that gently nudges clinicians to provide palliative care themselves or engage experts for hospitalized patients with serious illness, and will identify factors that affect clinicians' decisions regarding palliative care delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cell reprogramming represents a major advancement in biology, and has wide applications in regenerative medicine, disease modeling and drug screening. Our multidisciplinary team will integrate state-of-art technologies and innovative approaches to elucidate how biophysically-induced nuclear deformation regulates 3D chromatin remodeling, epigenetic changes, the efficiency of induced neuronal reprogramming and CRISPR-mediated gene editing efficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Diabetes is associated with significant impairments in wound healing which can be attributed in part to alterations in the “cellular ecology” of local cell populations; however, the role of external mechanical forces in modulating these cell population dynamics within the wound environment remains poorly understood. Our fundamental hypothesis is that local tissue mechanical forces contribute to the disruption of cellular ecology in diabetic wound healing and that mitigation of these forces can improve healing. This proposal focuses on identifying the mechanisms leading to altered subpopulations in diabetic human and mouse wound healing, and using real world data (RWD) to translate these findings to develop clinical strategies to treat non-healing diabetic wounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The incidence of premature birth (delivery more than three weeks early) is increasing worldwide. Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) and other respiratory problems are major long-term consequences of very premature birth resulting in lifelong breathing problems, including wheezing and bronchoconstriction, with immense socioeconomic costs. These data will contribute to our understanding of BPD breathing problems, ways to treat those problems, and potentially prevent or decrease the severity of BPD itself; improving thousands of lives annually.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is thought to involve an overactive complement system in the posterior pole of the eye. We have developed and validated a targeted AP inhibitor as a possible therapeutic agent for the treatment of AMD using AAV vector therapy, and an antibody to monitor complement activation in vivo. Here we will further develop and extend our two approaches to testing in human iPSC-RPE cultures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because cholangiopathies, which often affect extrahepatic bile ducts, are poorly understood and, therefore, have no effective treatment options. This project will unveil cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying extrahepatic bile duct responses to injury and inform potential strategies for treatment of cholangiopathies and prevention of their complications. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission that pertains to improvement of people’s health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromatin regulatory proteins are a major class of gene products for which sequence variants are associated with autism spectrum disorders and intellectual disability; however, the functional consequences of these mutations for brain development remain poorly understood. This proposal will take advantage of both mouse in vivo and human neuronal culture models to identify molecular mechanisms that underlie intellectual disability associated with frameshift mutations in the linker histone H1.4. These data will advance understanding of how mutations in chromatin regulatory proteins lead to neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address persistent disparities in combusted tobacco product use, novel communication approaches through digital channels are needed. Using an innovative combination of qualitative, eye tracking, and quantitative (discrete choice experiment, randomized clinical trial) studies, we will develop and test messages to reach low- SES smokers. Results will will help eliminate tobacco-related disparities and increase the effectiveness of tobacco educational messages among the population for whom anti-tobacco messages have not been optimally effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Freezing of gait (FOG) is one of the most debilitating features of Parkinson’s disease (PD) and occurs most often during self-initiated (uncued) transitions in movement (e.g. standing to walking, straight-line walking to turning), but can be overcome (and transition performance improved) with the provision of an external sensory cue. This study will use a variety of neurophysiological techniques to investigate the role that three neural systems (vestibular, cortical, and basal ganglia) play in the pathogenesis of impaired transitions from standing-to-walking in people with PD, and how external cues affect the dynamics of these systems to improve movement performance. This project will provide unique insight into the alterations in brain activity associated with FOG and cueing, which may then be translated into treatments to prevent FOG and improve quality of life in people with PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Noise is an environmental stressor that changes the physiology of the body and also damages the cochlea. Stress elicits an integrated response in the ear that involves the central nervous system, the sympathetic nervous system, cochlear circuitry, and the immune system. Understanding how central and peripheral stress response neurons impact cochlear function and resilience is important for finding ways to limit the effects of noise and other sources of stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Peanut and tree nut allergy is increasing in prevalence and poses a significant public health risk, as patients can develop life-threatening reactions. Antibodies that can bind to allergens underlie both clinical reactions to food allergens and tolerance after treatment. Our project focuses on understanding how these allergens are recognized by antibodies in similar ways by many allergic patients to contribute to our understanding of how food allergies begin and how we can develop new targeted therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a cross-disciplinary training program that brings together regeneration biologists, neurophysiologists, and clinician researchers to form mentorship teams within the largest medical research center in the world: The Texas Medical Center. This training program will foster a new generation of scientists who will in turn help build a new frontier of biology: neural control of organ degeneration and regeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This grant aims to utilize data from the National Health and Nutrition Survey (NHANES) linked Medicaid data to create a novel preconception cohort and study the role of preconception lifestyle factors on pregnancy outcomes. The proposed study will evaluate the role of preconception dietary factors, sleep and physical activity, and weight loss attempts and strategies on adverse pregnancy outcomes. The data obtained from this study will provide valuable insights into the role of preconception health factors improving pregnancy outcomes and can inform the development of evidence-based preconception care guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plants produce a plethora of medicinally important natural products that have significant potential to improve human health yet are often produced in low amounts, in complex mixtures, and/or cannot be produced in a sustainable or economic manner. Omics technologies enable the discovery of the biosynthetic genes of plant natural products which can then be employed in commercial production of medically relevant compounds. In this project, we will use state-of-the-art omics technologies to efficiently discover genes responsible for the biosynthesis of eight pharmacologically relevant compounds and utilize this knowledge to revitalize an old technology, plant cell culture, to enable robust, sustainable production of these products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE As one of the fastest growing health problems, OA affects 54 million people in the United States and more than 300 million people globally, however, there are currently no interventions to restore degraded articular cartilage or prevent OA progression. This proposal provides new mechanistic insights towards understanding the role of TGFβ/Nfia in regulation of articular chondrocyte lipid metabolism and homeostasis in the context of OA disease. We will define Nfia-mediated lipid metabolism as a novel target for the development of therapeutic approaches to treat OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to measure trunk function in those with physical disability using novel tests. The proposed tests are the Volume of Action Score and the Trunk Stability Score. They evaluate limits of stability and the ability to resist an outside force respectively. These test build upon current methods to create precise measures that give more robust information related to functional outcomes. We plan evaluate the relationships of these measures to other functional measures and related factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although tau is best known for its role in Alzheimer disease, it is a major driver of brain injury in hypoxic-ischemic injury and two of its early life sequelae – autism and epilepsy. Tau-targeted agents are already under development for Alzheimer disease and could be readily adapted to treat these devastating developmental problems, but it is unclear whether tau is necessary for normal development. Without this knowledge further development of this potentially highly promising therapeutic strategy is unlikely.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative and Public Health Relevance:  We propose to develop a research instrument that will allow stimulating biological cells with various chemical or biological compounds and then freezing these cells for subsequent analysis by high-resolution microscopy. This instrument will be useful in studying how cells respond to hormones, neurotransmitters, drugs, viruses, and many other agents relevant both to human physiology and disease. The project integrates a series of conceptual and methodological innovations that will result in a novel approach to nanoscale imaging of normal and aberrant cellular dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE  Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a lethal disease with limited treatment options. Pilot studies suggest that regulators of levels of the β-TrCP E3 ubiquitin ligase such as IGF2BP1 and PARP11 may contribute to CRC tumor growth, its control by anti-tumor immunity and responses to chemotherapy. Studies proposed here will determine the importance of IGF2BP1 and PARP11 in growth, progression, and metastasis of colorectal tumors and in their responses to therapy; these studies should reveal the IGF2BP1- and PARP11-dependent pathways as vulnerabilities that could be exploited for CRC treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project (Alzheimer's Prevention Initiative ADAD Colombia Program) is intended to clarify whether a clinically effective anti-amyloid antibody therapy reduces amyloid plaques and other biomarker evidence of disease progression in mildly impaired and unimpaired persons from the in the world's largest early onset, autosomal dominant Alzheimer's disease (ADAD) kindred to the same extent as it does in independent studies of late onset AD. The study will also characterize and compare the ability of continued antibody treatment, a potentially more accessible oral amyloid production inhibitor, a combination of these drugs or no drug to further decrease measurable plaques and other biological changes; it will provide a foundation to determine whether these treatments slow down, delay, or completely prevent the clinical onset of ADAD in the impaired and unimpaired mutation carriers; and it will provide an shared resource for the scientific community of trial data and samples from all study participants. The study capitalizes on an established late-onset AD-modifying drug and a promising new “gamma-secretase” modulator, and uses the clinical trial infrastructure that we established in Colombia and at Banner Alzheimer's Institute to advance the treatment, secondary prevention, primary prevention, and study of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative: Despite the major advancement in the development of new therapies for the treatment of human prostate cancer, prostate cancer remains the second leading cancer cause of death in north American men. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop new and more effective therapies for the treatment of human prostate cancer, particularly metastatic, castration-resistant prostate cancer. In this R01 award, we propose to develop orally active CBP/p300 degraders as a new class of therapy for the treatment of advanced, human prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative / Relevance Human pluripotent stem cells have the capacity to give rise to any other cell type found in the body, including blood forming stem cells and their derivative immune cell progeny. The goal of this proposal is to understand how these processes occur, and, if the blood cell types obtained are functionally distinct from donor-derived sources. This will allow for technology development to scalably generate each of these blood cell types from a patient’s own cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rural Appalachian region has a markedly high prevalence of cigarette smoking, contributing to disparities in lung and oral cancers. We propose to evaluate the effectiveness of a potentially reduced harm nicotine product, oral nicotine pouches, on reducing smoking in a large sample of rural Appalachian smokers. Results from this innovative investigation of oral nicotine pouches will inform whether they can be useful to reduce the burden of smoking in rural Appalachia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We still do not understand why variola, the cause of smallpox and one of the deadliest pathogens in human history, and its close orthopoxvirus relatives, such as monkeypox virus, are so dangerous. In this project we focus on the B22 family of proteins, a single version of which is made by nearly all orthopoxviruses. B22 proteins potently interfere with immune responses by the infected individual in a combination of ways that has not been previously described. Gaining an understanding of how B22 proteins operate could provide key insights into orthopoxvirus virulence and point to novel anti-viral strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The proposed project is relevant to public health because proton therapy has reduced dose to healthy tissue vs. photon therapy and hence improves health, lengthens life, and reduces illness and disability in patients receiving external beam radiation therapy. Despite the fundamental dosimetric advantage of proton therapy, there are only 44 proton therapy centers in the USA due to the larger size, larger cost, and smaller economy of scale. We will determine the feasibility of reducing the gantry size while minimizing the impact to clinical capability and not complicating the design with superconductors, eccentric rotation, or seated treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will assess acute air pollution mortality risk for individuals diagnosed with chronic respiratory diseases; a high-vulnerability group for environmental exposures. Using a patient data architecture built from clinical records, environmental conditions, and place-based characteristics of U.S. Veterans across a 20-year period, we will unpack the individual risk factors and neighborhood inequities that drive air pollution mortality risk in at-risk populations. Our findings will provide powerful insight into environmental risk for individuals with respiratory disease and inform regulatory policy and behavioral interventions to reduce health burdens in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic musculoskeletal pain, while a leading cause of disablement, is a neglected national health disparity issue in Black communities; as a matter of fact, only 11% (median) of participants in NIH-sponsored chronic pain research were identified as Black/African American. Specifically, chronic musculoskeletal pain is primarily driven by movement-evoked pain which contributes to pronounced mobility limitations and disability in Black/African American older adults. Disrupting persistent patterns of disparity in this population demands novel culturally congruent self-management interventions that will advance health equity and attenuate the adverse economic, functional, and mental health consequences associated with chronic musculoskeletal pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Laminin-2 related congenital muscular dystrophy (LAMA2-CMD) is a fatal neuromuscular disease for which there is no cure or approved treatments. This study will provide new mechanistic insights into the role laminin isoforms play in regulating muscle adhesion-signaling complexes, remodeling the extracellular matrix, restoring muscle repair and neuromuscular function. These studies will provide mechanistic insights into the role laminin isoforms play in skeletal muscle structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Surveillance for pre-cancerous dysplasia with colonoscopy is standard of care for patients with long standing inflammatory bowel disease. While guidelines for surveillance colonoscopy have typically included recommendations to obtain four untargeted random biopsies every 10 cm throughout the colon along with targeted biopsies of abnormal appearing lesions, the utility of this approach has been questioned. This pragmatic randomized clinical trial titled “Utility of Random Biopsies in Inflammatory Bowel Disease (URBI)” will test whether a limited biopsy strategy obtaining two random biopsies from two locations is non-inferior to obtaining four random biopsies every 10 cm to detect dysplasia and will support translational research exploring the molecular changes that evolve during the progression from inflammation to high-grade dysplasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Bipolar disorder typically begins in adolescence; recurrent mood symptoms during this period can have a devastating impact on a person's ability to achieve a high quality of life. Digital phenotyping, defined as the “moment-by-moment quantification of the human phenotype in situ” using data collected from smartphone sensors, may make it possible to better understand and predict the onset of mood symptoms with minimal burden to the individual. The goal of this K23 proposal is to characterize the digital phenotype of bipolar disorder in adolescents in order to prospectively predict mood symptoms, creating an opportunity to reduce the harmful effects of recurrent episodes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Insomnia places a significant burden on public health due to its high prevalence and negative impact on a wide range of health-related domains. However, we have limited understanding of how insomnia should be defined and whether there are different subtypes, which impairs our ability to prevent and treat this common sleep disorder. This study will conduct the most comprehensive re-evaluation to date of the classification of insomnia in order to guide future diagnosis, prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The inflammation and degeneration of the aortic artery can lead to life-threatening rupture and unfortunately, there is no medical therapy available to prevent this from happening. Our biologist/engineer/surgeon team will perform research to better understand the molecular and cellular underpinning of the disease and in parallel develop targeted drug delivery so that clinically viable therapies could result sooner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Over 3 million people in the United States suffer from epilepsy, which is a serious disease that in many cases cannot be effectively treated with medications or brain surgery. The goal of this project is to develop and test a powerful new processor and supporting software to analyze brain signals in a brain implantable neuromodulation device for epilepsy. We believe this project will result in both an improved understanding of epilepsy and improved therapy for epilepsy and is thus highly relevant to the NINDS mission to reduce the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Adaptation to high elevation environments protects against hypoxia-related pregnancy complications. Studying how these genetically-based adaptations influence placental responses to hypoxia offers an opportunity to improve our understanding of both the fundamentals of placental development and the origins of obstetric diseases in humans. With these broad goals in mind, the present proposal uses a model system for high- elevation adaptation, the deer mouse, to identify transcriptional variation that shapes placental development and protects fetal development under chronic hypoxia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While it is established that a subgroup of patients with idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (IIM) are diagnosed with contemporaneous cancer, the ability to predict cancer at the patient-level is imperfect. This proposal will develop and externally validate the first predictive tool to determine cancer risk and guide clinical decision- making in IIM patients (Aim 1). In Aim 2, the relationship between cancer emergence, cancer elimination, and IIM outcomes will be determined using novel liquid biopsy cancer detection technologies, providing insights into novel IIM treatment strategies and improvements in disease monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE. As demonstrated by the utilization of nanoparticles for vaccine delivery during the COVID-19 pandemic, nanomedicine has the potential to transform human health. However, nanomedicine is yet to reach its full potential in several diseases, partly due to our inability to tailor nanoparticle delivery to regions of interest and the potential toxicity associated with nanoparticle accumulation in off-target locations. To overcome these challenges, we propose to use artificial intelligence, mathematical modeling, and animal experiments to generate guidelines for rational design of nanoparticles for improved clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Traditional rehabilitation approaches are time and personnel intensive and costly, and leave ~75% of stroke survivors with residual disability. We propose a clinical trial to determine effects of forced aerobic exercise (FE; i.e., mechanically supplemented) in facilitating upper and lower extremity motor recovery post-stroke in an outpatient rehabilitation setting, to elucidate neural and biochemical substrates of FE-induced motor recovery, and to evaluate cost effectiveness of a FE-centered intervention compared to traditional stroke rehabilitation. The global effect of FE has the potential to enhance recovery in a growing population of stroke survivors in a cost-effective manner, thus accelerating its clinical acceptance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite recent advances in understanding the genomic landscape of bladder cancer, the median survival for advanced bladder cancer patients is only 14 months; therefore, there is an urgent need to develop new therapeutic approaches to improve clinical outcomes. A subset of bladder tumors harbor alterations in the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and peroxisome proliferator activated receptor gamma (PPARG) pathways, and we hypothesize that MAPK signaling drives a PPARG-mediated luminal-like, immune-excluded bladder cancer phenotype. Using genetically annotated patient-derived and immune-competent preclinical bladder cancer models, we will functionally dissect the molecular interplay between MAPK and PPARG signaling, define the role of MAPK pathway activity on the PPARG-mediated immune-excluded phenotype, and investigate the activity of co-targeting MAPK and immune checkpoint signaling in bladder cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a need to uncover the etiological mechanisms underlying the association between preterm birth and impaired neurodevelopment, both to improve the identification of the preterm infants who are at higher risk for impaired neurodevelopment and to inform efforts towards neurodevelopmental interventions. This project will provide much needed data to pave the way for novel opportunities for neurodevelopmental prevention and intervention efforts for preterm infants, and thus, decrease the incidence of neurodevelopmental disabilities and morbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Aging is the major risk factor for human pathologies that lead to disease, morbidity and mortality. Therefore, a better understanding of aging and the processes that affect lifespan at the molecular level remains an important problem in modern biology and medicine. The goals of this project are to better understand one of the potential drivers of aging.

PHR: Project narrative Radiotherapy for head and neck cancer commonly results in the irreversible and severe decrease of saliva secretion that impairs the quality of life of patients remarkably. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project narrative: One out of every two American adults aged 30 and over has periodontitis, which is an inflammatory bone lytic disease caused by poly-microbial infection around tooth. It is well documented that bone regeneration hardly ever occurs at the alveolar bone affected by periodontitis, even after the successful conventional periodontal treatment. Based on our preliminarily discovered finding, i.e., OC-STAMP molecule that specifically expressed by osteoclasts (bone resorbing cells) is engaged in not only bone resorption but also interruption of new bone regeneration, in the proposed RO1 project, we will gain more scientific insight into this finding for the development of novel non-invasive bone regenerative therapy for periodontitis and other bone lytic disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disordered eating has been linked to poor cardiometabolic health, and cardiovascular disease and metabolic disorders are top causes of death in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This project proposes to advance the opportunities for safe physical activity among people with Type 1 diabetes (T1D) by testing the efficacy three new promising approaches in a controlled setting—and then validating the resulting device in a real-world setting at home. The approaches will adjust insulin delivery in response to 1) real-time changes in insulin sensitivity, 2) the amount of “activity on board,” which acknowledges the influence of prior activity on future insulin needs, and 3) anticipated future physical activity based on past physical activity patterns. All of these will be tested as added modules in a fully- automated closed loop system (with resultant glycemia compared to the system without the modules) with a vision of providing the safe ability for physical activity in T1D without added user action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Recent results from human clinical trials utilizing administration of three different monoclonal antibodies targeting Aβ , aducanumab , and lecanemab, and donanemab have slowed mental decline by approximately 35 percent. Thus, there is increased interest in identifying the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the persistent adverse clinical brain blood vessel responses to passive anti-Ab immunotherapy. This R01 proposal will utilize a transgenic mouse model that deposits high levels of brain and vascular Aβ to investigate these immunotherapy-induced adverse events with a mouse monoclonal anti-Aβ antibody, where the human version, bapineuzumab, has previously been shown to have reduced Aβ plaque pathology in patients, as well as induced adverse clinical brain blood vessel responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Imbalances in lipid homeostasis can deleteriously impact health and therefore cells within the organism tightly regulate absorption, synthesis, and metabolism to accommodate energetic demands and ensure energetic reserves later in life. My laboratory has identified a mechanism by which cells sense intracellular lipid depletion and respond to metabolic demand. Activation and attenuation of this lipid surveillance response is regulated by the starvation-responsive nuclear hormone receptor, NHR-49, and a series of co-factors which mediate its vesicular release, nuclear import, intranuclear retention, and transcriptional activity followed by its phosphorylation, nuclear export and proteasomal degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Sex differences in vulnerability to alcohol suggest that alcohol drinking behaviors are influenced by different mechanisms in males and females. This project will use mouse models of alcohol consumption to investigate the contribution of X chromosome genes to drinking behaviors. Interactions with gonadal sex and alcohol exposure will also be explored. Understanding the neural mechanisms that drive differences in alcohol consumption will inform future therapies and treatments for Alcohol Use Disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Pediatric cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, including congenital heart diseases, lung disease of prematurity, and cystic fibrosis, require multiple imaging studies to evaluate the cardiovascular and pulmonary systems, but this is currently done in separate scans that are very long and labor intensive. This project aims to develop MRI methods for integrated cardiopulmonary evaluation in pediatrics, including advances in MRI hardware, data acquisition, and image reconstruction, that will provide anatomical and functional information in a single, rapid scan. This will improve the diagnosis, treatment selection, and monitoring of cardiopulmonary diseases in pediatrics, and also will improve our fundamental understanding of the interaction between the cardiovascular and pulmonary systems, all without the use of ionizing radiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to investigate the role of glycogen metabolism in the progression of Ewing's Sarcoma, a rare and aggressive form of bone and soft tissue cancer. By elucidating the molecular mechanisms governing glycogen metabolism in tumor cells, we seek to identify novel diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic targets. The outcomes of this research have the potential to significantly advance our understanding of Ewing's Sarcoma and contribute to the development of more effective treatment strategies for affected patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Texas Medical Center (TMC) Genomics Center for Infectious Disease (GCID) combines genomic sequencing technology, organoid cultures and clinical expertise to study host-mucosal pathogen interactions in human tissues, aiming to identify therapeutic and diagnostic targets. Four research projects will focus on Enterobacteriaceae colonization and translocation, norovirus and respiratory syncytial virus analysis and evolution from patient samples, the impact of Candida albicans strains on gut health, and the prevention of Cryptosporidium infection with novel metabolites. The ultimate goal is to gain a comprehensive understanding of genetic profiles and host responses to develop precise treatments for various infectious diseases covered in the TMC-GCID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will investigate how antimicrobial resistant bacteria move from the gastrointestinal tract into the bloodstream, which is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The project will utilize genome sequencing, organotypic culture models, machine learning, and transcriptional analysis to uncover key factors involved in the process. The findings will contribute to the development of vaccines and therapeutics to prevent and treat bacterial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The fungus Candida albicans causes significant morbidity and mortality, particularly among individuals with a debilitated immune system such as cancer patients receiving chemotherapy or transplant recipients. A common source of these life-threatening Candida infections is the gastrointestinal tract of the same patients. We will collect, sequence, and study a large set of C. albicans strains derived from the human intestine to establish the spectrum of interactions between intestinal mucosa and fungus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a serious public health problem, and early stages of AUD recovery are fragile such that significant proportion of individuals who seek treatment will relapse within the first few months after treatment. Stressful events can contribute to relapse and effective interventions during early stages of AUD recovery that can support stress reduction are critical. Implementing a cost-effective, and novel music-based intervention to support stress management and emotion regulation during recovery will reduce the burden associated with AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Although extended care promotes better weight loss maintenance (WLM) following initial weight management programs, conventional WLM interventions require significant effort and may fail to adequately support individuals' capacity to continue weight management efforts. By leveraging the multiphase optimization strategy framework and a factorial experimental design, this project includes an optimization trial to test four extended care intervention components designed to be “minimally disruptive” (i.e., effective treatments designed to limit burden): 1) reduced food variety, 2) home-based resistance training, 3) buddy training and support, and 4) acceptance and commitment therapy workshops. The goal is to develop an optimized intervention package that maximizes WLM and improves the public health impact of behavioral weight management interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental disorders are leading causes of the health-related burden globally, and in Rwanda the intergenerational mental health consequences of the 1994 Genocide against the Tutsi persist and are further compounded by poverty, such that recent studies have found 20% of the Rwandan population has one or more mental disorders. The proposed research will test the feasibility, acceptability and impact of a technology-enabled service delivery model using a digital tool that streamlines data collection, improves visibility of key program performance metrics, and serves as a resource for learning materials that can be used for continuous learning and training of a non-specialized workforce that is delivering an evidence-based intervention that improves caregiver mental health and family functioning. What we learn from technology-supported delivery of Sugira Muryango – an evidence-based, trauma-informed, family-based behavioral intervention in Rwanda – can be used to improve the efficiency, effectiveness, and scalability of evidence-based mental health services in Rwanda and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), the most common sleep disorder, is caused by repeated disruption of airflow (apneas) leading to decreased blood oxygenation, resulting in daytime sleepiness and impaired vigilance. This project uses novel imaging methodology to study the adverse effects of OSA on the brain along with measurement of airway obstruction. The results should provide new insight into the disorder and aid in designing improved forms of treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Tissue regeneration after spinal cord trauma is limited by additional biological events including inflammation, which induce an inhibitory local microenvironment leading to cellular death and functional deficits. lmmunotherapeutic nanoparticles with different physicochemical factors without using active pharmaceutical ingredients interact with circulating immune cells and reprogram their function to mitigate inflammation and modify the microenvironment in favor of regeneration. The proposed studies will identify crucial parameters of nanoparticles for the development of effective nanotherapeutics which will contribute to the development of potentially effective practical therapy for spinal cord trauma.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite two millennia of tonsillectomies and decades of research, we have failed to provide adequate pain relief and determine the optimal perioperative pain regimen for the 500,000 US children undergoing tonsillectomy annually. There is an urgent need to manage acute post-tonsillectomy pain both safely and effectively, particularly in an era when prescribing “take-home” opioids must be carefully considered due to the known risks of opioid-related harms in children and adolescents. In a single center randomized controlled clinical trial, we will identify the optimal age-specific, weight-based dose of intraoperative methadone, a long acting, cost-effective and widely available analgesic, to optimize pain management and reduce the need for postoperative opioids in children and adolescents undergoing tonsillectomy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Optic nerve damage and retinal ganglion cell loss is common to many eye diseases, including glaucoma and ischemic optic neuropathies. There are, however, no therapies that specifically promote retinal ganglion cell survival or axon regeneration in these diseases. A better understanding of the cellular mechanisms that impact neuroprotection and axonal regeneration may yield better therapeutic regimens, decreasing morbidity and potentially restoring vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiation exposure is a major concern for CT imaging. Photon counting detectors provide ample opportunity for reducing radiation exposure, but systems today have not capitalized on this opportunity because it requires redesign of existing CT scanner components. Our work will lay the theoretical foundation and provide experimental demonstration of new scanner components that will allow future photon counting CT scanners to reduce radiation exposure without reducing image quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Top-down contextual information modulates the processing of bottom-up auditory signals to improve hearing accuracy, but the neural mechanisms underlying this essential function remain unclear, especially at the earliest level of the central auditory system. Here we use modern in vitro and in vivo approaches in mice to examine the role of the massive top-down projection from the inferior colliculus to the dorsal cochlear nucleus and test the cellular and circuit mechanism that guide context-dependent filtering of bottom-up signals. This project may provide insight into ways to improve auditory perception when bottom-up signals are degraded due to hearing loss, as well as auditory processing disorders for which dysfunctional top-down modulation has been implicated.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Children with medical complexity (CMC) are an extremely vulnerable population with significant morbidity and mortality risk, and methods to identify CMC for research or enrollment in clinical programs often rely on diagnostic codes. This proposal is motivated by the premise that the accuracy of these methods warrant more rigorous evaluation, and furthermore due to differences in access to healthcare and diagnostic evaluations for various patient populations, diagnostic codes may reflect broader historical and societal biases and disparities (as preliminary data suggests). We propose to evaluate the accuracy and potential bias of these methods to promote the most effective and equitable care of CMC, and the methods and findings likely will be generalizable to all patient classification systems based on diagnosis codes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CCC EQUATE (Equitable Quantification And Task Evaluation)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular forces that modify chromosome structure are crucial for establishing gene activity that allow animals to learn and generate adaptive responses, yet the identity of these mechanisms remains obscure. Our data suggests that torsional stress generated during transcription propagates widely across the neuronal genome and could be a driving force for chromatin reconfiguration following neuronal stimulation. By mapping the distribution of torsional stress at high resolution, and studying how torsional stress impacts chromosome configuration in response to neuronal stimulation, this project will enhance fundamental knowledge of how DNA mechanics shapes genome function, and mismanagement of torsional stress could contribute to neurodevelopmental defects and various neurological diseases, including autism spectrum disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improving long-term kidney allograft survival remains a major unmet clinical need in kidney transplantation. Early detect and frequent monitoring of allograft injuries is critical to timely diagnosis and intervention for improved long-term outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary fibrosis is often a fatal condition that leads to progressive scarring of the lungs, but little is known about inducing matrix clearance and fibrosis resolution in humans. This application seeks to address the pivotal role of MMP-9 activation for matrix degradation via plasminogen/plasmin cascade in fibroblasts. The results of our studies should provide insight into the development of novel therapeutic strategies to induce fibrosis resolution that will improve the outcomes for patients with fibrotic lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Advancing the science of sustainability is important and urgent, as inequities in cancer and challenges to the sustainability of evidence-based programs persist and were exacerbated during the COVID-19 pandemic. This research seeks to help address gaps in understanding how to actively enhance the sustainability of evidence-based programs, particularly in lower- resource community settings. Specifically, the proposed study will help inform understanding of what strategies are effective in promoting the long-term delivery and impact of a program focused on improving racial inequities in cancer screening among Black women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Resistance to current AR-targeted therapies poses a significant hurdle in treating advanced prostate cancer (PCa), severely affecting clinical outcomes for patients battling this lethal disease. Our research has identified a prevalent ZNF397 deficiency, observed in 25-40% of PCa patients, which propels the transition of cancer cells from an AR-driven luminal lineage to a TET2-driven lineage plastic state, thereby fostering AR-targeted therapy resistance. This study aims to unravel the molecular mechanism behind ZNF397-deficiency-induced lineage plasticity and AR-targeted therapy resistance, with a goal to develop innovative therapeutic approaches to overcome resistance and benefit patients suffering from this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a potentially lethal disease that lacks pharmacological treatment, and aortic wall medial smooth muscle degeneration and adventitia remodeling are the determining factors for AAA progression and aortic rupture. In this application, a combination of molecular, cellular, and genetic approaches with gain-of- and loss-of-function studies will be used to establish novel mechanisms by which Smad2 hinders AAA progression by inhibiting vascular smooth muscle necroptosis while facilitating adventitia protective responses. The outcome of the project may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention or therapy of AAA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mechanisms driving spontaneous preterm birth remain incompletely understood, although premature cervical remodeling appears to be a common pathway leading to preterm birth. The proposed research aims to identify mechanisms through which polyamines, which are relatively abundant metabolites in the cervicovaginal space, affect cervical remodeling and risk of preterm birth. Of significant translational and public health importance, this work will provide the basis for potential development of polyamine-based preventative or therapeutic interventions to mitigate risk of spontaneous preterm birth, the leading cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vocal communication is hugely important to our social lives, but the brain circuits that allow humans and other animals to vocalize appropriately according to behavioral context remain poorly understood. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the brain circuits that underlie the flexible, context-dependent control of vocalization, which will inform our understanding of brain mechanisms that underlie differences in vocal communication in neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the era of precision oncology, more patients are living longer with advanced cancer, yet many of the new treatments cause unrelenting fatigue which interferes with daily life and may lead to non-adherence or discontinuation of these breakthrough therapies. Despite this, there are few effective, evidence-based treatments for fatigue in metastatic cancer. This study rigorously evaluates REVITALIZE--a well-piloted telehealth intervention designed to improve fatigue outcomes in patients with advanced ovarian cancer taking PARP inhibitors--in a fully-powered randomized trial in patients treated at both academic and community cancer clinics that serve diverse communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microbial infections are one of the leading causes of cancer worldwide. We will use functional proteomic methods to determine how infection-induced oxidative stress, which is a driving force in cancer development, promotes cancer signaling at the protein level. Our findings will increase understanding of infection-induced signaling pathways that contribute to cancer development and may lead to new strategies for inhibiting these pathways during infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a pragmatic Hybrid Type 2 effectiveness/implementation trial with national scope vital to understanding the effectiveness and implementation of behaviorally-informed COVID-19 and influenza text message reminders across parents with varied backgrounds and whose children are cared for in diverse practice settings. On a national scale, understanding the effectiveness and implementation of influenza and COVID-19 vaccine text message reminders among a diverse pediatric population will provide key information to clinicians, health systems, health departments and policymakers to bolster vaccine receipt and counter vaccine hesitancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related memory decline is one of the most salient cognitive deficits affecting older adults. Negative impacts of memory failures in older adults can range from emotional distress and embarrassment to potential life- threatening outcomes, especially in cases where individuals experience memory errors for important health and safety information. Identifying strategies to reduce these errors is critical to enhancing memory functioning and quality of life in healthy older adults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative ZFY is an essential and conserved Y chromosome encoded male fertility factor but how it imposes its important role has not been established. Using new mouse models that we developed, we will investigate the molecular function of mouse Zfy. Our findings will impact on understanding on genetic regulation of spermatogenesis and origin of male infertility, with consequences for advancing knowledge about these processes in humans.
