IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromothripsis describes a process in which chromosomes catastrophically shatter into fragments and reassemble to form rearranged chromosomes that can fuel cancer development. How these chromosomes undergo fragmentation remains a critical knowledge gap in our understanding of the etiology of chromothripsis. This proposal seeks to test the hypothesis that chromothripsis is caused by DNA replication defects that persist into mitosis, which subsequently activates a pathological DNA repair program that triggers extensive chromosome breakage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The cause of inguinal hernia is not well understood, though it is highly prevalent, occurring in 1 out of 4 elderly men. Hernia repair surgery is the only option for treating inguinal hernia; however, refractory hernias accompanied by long-term severe postoperative pain, infection, and high recurrence continue to challenge surgeons. We will investigate a novel mechanism underlying inguinal hernia formation that links progesterone hormone signaling with abdominal muscle fibrosis in a unique and clinically relevant mouse model and in human tissues, and propose to test the effect of treatments that block progesterone action to prevent or reverse hernias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Glaucoma, a leading cause of blindness in the United States, is characterized by injury to the axons of the retinal ganglion cells and extensive changes in the structure of the tissues of the optic nerve head that may affect their mechanical properties and deformation response to the intraocular pressure. This project seeks to understand: 1) whether the deformation and mechanical properties of the optic nerve head, measured by current state-of-the-art imaging, image analysis and modeling methods, can predict the risk of progression of optic nerve damage in open angle glaucoma, and 2) how the structure and material properties of the optic nerve head tissues change during glaucoma progression. The findings of the proposed project may lead to the development of new biomechanical markers for the reduction in susceptibility to glaucoma damage in human eyes, which would predict the outcome of glaucoma surgery to lower the intraocular pressure, provide more efficient outcome measures for initial human scleral neuroprotection trials, and for the development of new therapies that alter the mechanical behavior of the optic nerve head tissues to mitigate glaucoma damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will leverage our institutional experience in tumor profiling and molecular imaging to study the clinical significance of molecular heterogeneity in urothelial cancer, with a focus on the HER2 receptor tyrosine kinase. As a complement to tumor analyses, HER2 PET imaging will be used to study lesion-to-lesion differences in HER2 expression and to determine if patients with heterogeneous HER2 expression are less likely to benefit from treatment with HER2-targeted antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs). Given the promising clinical activity of HER2-targeted ADCs in patients with urothelial cancer, we predict that the studies proposed will accelerate the clinical development of HER2-targeted ADCs and establish a clinical role for HER2 PET imaging as a guide to patient selection. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations and reduced expression of IRBP are associated with retinitis pigmentosa (RP), childhood-onset retinal dystrophy with high-myopia (CRDHM), cornea curvature, or increased susceptibility to diabetic retinopathy (DR) with unclear mechanisms. Our recent studies in vitro & in a newly developed D1078N knock- in (KI) mouse model of RP revealed that both the CRDHM (E1152x)- & RP (D1080N)-associated mutations abolished the function of IRBP, thereby causing aberrant visual cycle, severe vision impairment, as well as progressive degeneration of rod & cone photoreceptors (PRs) in the KI model of RP. In this proposal, we will elucidate the mechanisms by which the mutations abolish the function of IRBP and explore pharmacological interventions to preserve IRBP function, PRs & vision in the mouse models of the diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative The proposal will analyze in detail 5'-human-HBV-3' RNAs transcribed from integrated HBV DNA independently of HBV genome replication and examine their (i) sequence features, (ii) accumulation and stability, (iii) ability to regulate the levels of HBV genome replication, and (iv) potential to alter the host genes' expression profile. Overall, the proposed study will advance our understanding of the natural 5'-human-HBV-3' RNAs' sequences organization, their biological functions and role in HBV life cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Monoclonal B-cell lymphocytosis (MBL) is a common condition that increases risk of cancers and infections. However, the causes, consequences, and clonal trajectories of MBL remain understudied due to the cost and requirement for fresh biospecimens to detect MBL. We propose to develop and validate a strategy to predict MBL status and clonal growth from SNP array data readily available to many large biobank and cohort studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Multiple sclerosis (MS) is one of the most frequent nontraumatic disabling neurologic disorders, affecting approximately 309 per 100,000 adults in the United States. There is a critical need to routinely image brain oxygen extraction fraction (OEF), a direct biomarker for tissue viability and functional activities, in MS patients for better understanding, diagnosing, and treating MS. The proposed research will develop a noninvasive, widely available imaging method for mapping OEF, which can be routinely used on all 3T magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scanners to study neurologic disorders, including MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because it will advance understanding of a progressive form of multiple sclerosis (MS), a debilitating neurological disease that damages the brain and spinal cord. Primary progressive MS patients experience worsening neurologic function and disability from disease onset, and symptoms such as problems with walking and bladder/bowel dysfunction significantly impact quality of life, yet few approved treatments are available, in part because we lack a complete understanding of the pathology underlying progression in the lower spinal cord. This project aims to evaluate the extent of lumbosacral spinal cord pathology and its role in driving clinical disability in primary progressive MS by applying structural, functional, and myelin-sensitive, quantitative MRI methods in this critical anatomy and identifying sensitive and specific imaging biomarkers of progressive disease that address the current gap in evaluating the full extent of spinal cord pathology in MS.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the impact of screen media use in early childhood is a major public health priority. Emerging research has suggested associations between child screen media use and child emotional and behavioral problems; however, the nature of these associations is still under debate given mixed findings, unclear mechanisms, and the lack of longitudinal research in this area. Therefore, the proposed research will examine longitudinal and transactional associations between characteristics of family media use and child emotional and behavioral functioning, and investigate caregiver-child interactions, parenting, and caregiver distress as key mechanisms of these associations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: More than 50 million people in the U.S. provide care for spinal cord injury patients each year. Here we propose to release anti-inflammatory cytokines locally after spinal cord injury, to reduce inflammation and secondary damage, resulting in an improvement of function below the level of injury. Even a limited amount of functional improvement can greatly increase the independence of spinal cord injury patients and enhance their quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have found that elevated emotional impulsivity (urgency) plays an important role in suicidal ideation and behavior (SIB) in schizophrenia spectrum disorder (SSD) and that activation in those with high vs. low levels of SIB was associated reduced fMRI activation in brain areas related to urgency. We propose to extend this work to another disorder with elevated risk for suicide (major depressive disorder). This cross-diagnostic work will allow us to identify the ideal regions to target using neuroscience-informed therapies, with the aim of reducing NU and ultimately, SIB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Cancer therapy increasingly depends on the use of two or more drugs to complement and strengthen each others action. The approved cancer drug Forodesine is highly effective in cancers that are genetically missing a second cancer target called SAMHD1. But most cancers have excess SAMHD1 and there are no approved drugs or clinical trials yet reported for SAMHD1. Transition state analysis, featured here, has a proven record of generating powerful enzymatic inhibitors that have success in clinical trials. SAMHD1 inhibitor development has the potential to open a powerful therapeutic window for leukemia and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Little is known about the impact of MPXV infection on pregnant people or developing fetuses. We will determine the rate and pathways of vertical transmission, define the association of mpox disease severity and adverse pregnancy outcomes, and determine whether antiviral treatment can improve pregnancy outcomes in a translational macaque model. This will fill critical knowledge gaps in the clinical care of pregnant persons that cannot be learned from epidemiological studies alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: FOXL1 positive telocytes in intestinal development and homeostasis Narrative Diseases of the gastrointestinal tract including inflammatory bowel disease and colon cancer represent serious health problems in the United States. Self-renewal of the gut lining throughout life is dependent on specialized niche cells that support the division of gut stem cells. Here, we will identify genes and pathways that control niche cell biology that might be targeted in the future for better treatment of diseases of the alimentary tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Despite the success of hemodialysis in supporting patients with kidney failure, patients who rely on dialysis remain extremely ill. It is thought that dialysis only removes some of the toxins that the kidney removes. In this project, we examine whether changing the shape of the dialyzer can better copy the toxin removal of a healthy kidney and reduce the tendency of these patients to form life-threatening blood clots.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to elucidate the role of Th1 cells in multiple system atrophy (MSA), a debilitating, fast- progressing neurodegenerative and demyelination movement disorder with no current treatment options. When IFNɣ was knocked down there was a significant reduction in overall neuroinflammation, and demyelination; however, the IFNɣ producing cell that is responsible for MSA pathology is unknown. Therefore, this proposal identifies if Th1 (CD4+ T cells that produce IFNɣ) are required for MSA pathology within the Olig001 mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Sudden cardiac arrest is a major public health issue in the United States. The purpose of this study is to determine the role of CD73 expressing lymphocytes in the protection against excessive inflammation and secondary heart and brain tissue damage after initial global ischemia and reperfusion injury. The anticipated data may lead to the development of novel immunotherapies to cure patients with cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE For the first time, the US Food and Drug Administration has authorized two brands of smokeless tobacco to make advertising claims that their products pose lower health risks to users than cigarette smoking. This study will use complementary and innovative research activities (including an online survey and experiment, an experimental auction, and an in-person product use lab study) to explore consumers’ exposure and reactions to authorized smokeless tobacco modified risk claims, and whether these claims influence smokeless tobacco demand and sensory evaluations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bipolar disorder is a lifelong illness with a significant and chronic disease burden made worse by severe and episodic disruptions in the regulatory control of emotion (emotion regulation). The development of rapid-acting treatment options that improve emotion regulation for individuals with bipolar disorder are needed to help achieve and sustain remission and improve long-term functioning. This study will use a rapid and robust form of neuromodulation (transcranial magnetic stimulation) to investigate the mechanisms related to impaired emotion regulation in bipolar disorder and the potential for this approach to improve emotion regulation, as an important first step towards validating this approach as a treatment option for individuals with bipolar disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although adults with blood cancers experience substantial symptom burden that worsens near the end of life, fewer than 25% enroll in hospice. Lack of access to palliative blood transfusions to manage symptoms of fatigue, dyspnea, and bleeding is a critical barrier to hospice use for this population; yet, there is a striking lack of research testing interventions that directly address this problem. This proposal seeks to test the efficacy of access to a novel model of care delivery that combines palliative home transfusions with core elements of hospice care, with the goal of improving hospice enrollment and end-of-life care for patients with blood cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Voice disorders affect approximately 7.5 million Americans. However, there are not enough individuals with the expertise and training to perform high-quality basic, translational, and clinical research that will result in successful treatments for these disorders. The University of Wisconsin-Madison Voice Research Training Program is training graduate students as well as individuals with PhDs and MDs to lead successful academic careers with a focus on research in voice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Narrative Osteosarcoma, a malignant primary tumor of bone, is a devastating disease with dismal outcomes for both adult and pediatric patients. There has been a significant lack of improvement in survival over the past three decades, and there remains high complication rates for limb salvage approaches. The goal of this project is to develop a novel image-guided histotripsy system for the complete, uniform, and non-invasive treatment of heterogenous osteosarcoma in adults and children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This program will leverage the Long-term Impact of Infection with Novel Coronavirus cohort (LIINC; NCT04362150) to determine the underlying biological mechanisms driving neurologic post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 infection (neuro-PASC). Our central hypothesis is that persistence of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in the post-acute phase drives ongoing dysregulation of fibrinogen pathways resulting in microclotting and reduced cerebral blood flow which together manifest as neuro-PASC symptoms. To test this model, we will (1) measure plasma SARS-CoV-2 antigen persistence, activity of fibrinogen pathways, and levels of inflammatory biomarkers using previously stored longitudinal biospecimens ranging from 5 days to 4 years post-COVID; (2) apply these methods to prospectively collected biospecimens (blood, cerebrospinal fluid, gut tissue) and clinical data (neurocognitive testing performance, multimodal magnetic resonance imaging); and (3) measure virus persistence, clotting and inflammation in specimens collected as part of a clinical trial of an anti-SARS-CoV-2 monoclonal antibody (AER002; NCT05877508).

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood obesity affects 17 percent of children and yet child obesity treatment may be less effective for those with social risk factors. This project will learn whether adding a community health worker to a child obesity treatment program can improve outcomes in families with social risk factors. This project will also learn more about the important factors that explain why some families do not benefit as much as others so we can improve the interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) affects up to 13% of women of reproductive age globally. The purpose of this study is to identify key central neuronal circuits that control fertility and determine whether disruptions in these circuits play a role in the development of PCOS. Importantly, identifying and understanding central defects in PCOS is crucial to establish effective treatments and preventative measures for patients with the syndrome.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our community engagement studies have shown that integrating 3 strengths-based intervention components, each with consistent evidence of effectiveness when studied individually in other clinical conditions (transitional care management, problem-solving rehabilitation, and caregiver support), could address unmet care needs of critical illness survivors and their caregivers when integrated. This proposal will conduct a randomized control trial to establish efficacy of the integrated intervention, Post-Intensive Care: Transitional care, Rehabilitation, and Family Support (PIC-TRFS), on survivor and caregiver outcomes including quality of life, function, survival, trauma symptoms, and healthcare utilization. Success would support PIC-TRFS as high-quality, affordable care via a scalable model of integrated service delivery that should be examined for effectiveness through broader implementation.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: PIC-TRFS: A Randomized Trial of a Multicomponent Intervention for ICU Survivors and Caregivers

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to develop drugs for treating various aspects of RASopathies, genetic disorders altering a fundamental biological process called RAS signaling. To do this, the investigators will use two approaches, one relying on an existing drug developed for cancer treatment and several chemically related ones, and the other being the development of a totally new class of drugs. For both, emphasis will be on understanding how these drugs work to overcome the problems associated with RASopathies using fruit fly, human cell and mouse models of disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE  Bronchodilator drugs targeting beta-adrenergic receptors on airways have been used as rescue and preventive medications for asthma. However, this class of drugs has come under scrutiny recently due to their ineffectiveness in controlling asthma symptoms, and due to multiple side effects including asthma-associated death. Studies proposed in this application will identify and characterize new compounds that enhance the efficacy of bronchodilators paving the way for the development of a novel and improved strategy for treating patients with asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Therapy related myeloid neoplasms (tMNs), including acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), are malignancies of the bone marrow that occur in patients who have received prior anti- cancer therapy. Additional studies have shown that PARP inhibitors, a recently developed class of drugs that extend relapse-free and overall survival when administered to ovarian cancer (OC) patients as maintenance therapy after initial chemotherapy and surgery, increase the already high rate of tMNs in OC patients. These tMNs typically have mutations in the TP53 gene that make them relatively insensitive to conventional anti- leukemic treatments. Building on preliminary studies showing that a class of targeted agents called replication checkpoint modulators is active against TP53-mutant AML, we now propose to i) study the underlying mechanism by which replication checkpoint modulators kill TP53-mutant AML and ii) assess the activity of replication checkpoint modulators against tMNs isolated from OC patients. Collectively, these studies will provide insight into the subset of tMNs that are most likely to respond to replication checkpoint modulators and position the team to test this new class of antineoplastic agent in OC survivors who develop tMNs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective control of advanced oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) remains a clinical challenge. The therapeutic efficacy of cetuximab (CTX)-based anti-epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) therapy is unsatisfactory in limiting OSCC, which can be significantly improved in combination with IACS-010759 (IACS), an orally bioavailable mitochondrial complex I inhibitor, by inducing pyroptosis-mediated anti-tumor immunity. Successful completion of this project will provide a comprehensive understanding of the molecular and immunological mechanisms of CTX/IACS combination, leading to an improved therapy that maximizes anti- tumor efficacy while minimizing toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging is the most important risk factor for many common afflictions and interventions to biological aging might prevent, delay, or even cure, chronic age-related diseases. This proposal will use a unique model well-suited to identify mechanisms by which cells can supersede normal species lifespan boundaries without undergoing senescence or malignant transformation, while redressing fundamental and longstanding biological concepts. Outcomes of the proposal will identify opportunities to decelerate or stop aging though therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Reelin signaling plays a pivotal role in memory formation and serves as a protective pathway against Alzheimer’s disease (AD). A crucial aspect of Reelin’s effectiveness in enhancing synaptic plasticity hinges on its cognate receptors, APOER2 and VLDLR, which are characterized by a high degree of alternative splicing. This proposal aims to understand the mechanisms underlying the impact of receptor splicing on ligand-receptor interactions and signaling, and how these dynamics affect neuronal function and susceptibility to AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NIAID is supporting the development of a new research Network comprised of a Coordinating and Data Sharing Center (CDSC) and Research Centers to collaboratively produce generalizable knowledge that enables rapid pandemic response to emerging viral pathogens. The overall goal of the RTI International-based CDSC is to establish and maintain an integrated Network to accelerate discovery and dissemination of novel vaccine and monoclonal antibody strategies to prepare for the next pandemic outbreak. This will be accomplished by leveraging RTI multidisciplinary experts and providing centralized administrative communication and operational support for Network-wide activities, while establishing data sharing and analysis standards and platforms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Asthma, accompanied by lung inflammation, bronchoconstriction, and airway hyperresponsiveness, is a significant public health burden. Although recent basic and clinical research has led to a better understanding of the immunological mechanisms of asthma, the neural mechanisms underlying asthma symptoms remain unclear. This proposal aims to investigate how vagal sensory neurons contribute to asthma symptom.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemotherapy-induced painful peripheral neuropathy (CIPPN) often leads to treatment failure and significantly reduces quality of life. The proposal will discover and validate whether peroxisome proliferator activated receptor gamma (PPARγ) and low-density lipoprotein receptor related protein 1 (LRP1) signaling limits Schwann cell dysfunction, and thereby alleviates aberrations in neuronal bioenergetics and hyperexcitability induced by chemotherapy. A deeper understanding of molecular mechanisms of Schwann cell function, neuroprotection and repair will help develop targeted therapies to treat CIPPN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity, the leading cause of global morbidity and mortality, is characterized by hypothalamic resistance to the anorexigenic hormone leptin. Since leptin therapy’s effectiveness against obesity is hindered by leptin resistance, it is crucial to understand the mechanisms behind this resistance. This study aims to elucidate how a high-fat diet induces leptin resistance through hypothalamic epigenetic modifications and explores intermittent fasting as a potential method to reverse these changes and restore leptin sensitivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The PRKACA gene encodes for the catalytic subunit of protein kinase A. Genetic sequencing identified mutations in the catalytic subunit of kinase A linked to adenoma-associated Cushing’s syndrome, cardiac myxomas, fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinomas, and intraductal oncocytic papillary neoplasms of the pancreas and bile ducts. We will identify the molecular mechanisms underlying these dysfunctional kinases, paving the way for alternative and innovative therapies.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infections due to antimicrobial resistant organisms (ARO) have long been a concern in the acute healthcare setting, but community rates have increased exponentially over the past decade. However little is understood about the prevalence and risk factors associated with community-associated ARO (CA-ARO) colonization and infection. The study goals are to: 1) characterize clinical risk factors associated with CA-ARO infections; 2) determine the prevalence and clinical risk factors associated with CA-ARO colonization in patients admitted to the acute care hospital setting; and 3) determine the prevalence and characteristics associated with CA-ARO colonization in asymptomatic community volunteers and their home environment to identify risk factors and reservoirs of CA-ARO colonization. Results of this study will directly impact clinical practice and improve patient health by providing key data to guide the use of infection prevention interventions for people at-risk for CA-ARO colonization or infection, environmental hygiene recommendations, and empiric antimicrobials.

PROJECT_TITLE: Combatting Community-Associated Antimicrobial Resistant Organisms Combat CA-ARO Study
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor (GLP-1R) is a promising new therapeutic target for the treatment of asthma; however, the mechanisms of action of GLP-1R agonists in asthma remain unknown. This proposal will determine the direct actions of GLP-1R signaling on immune cells in asthma with or without associated obesity. This is critically important for optimizing the use of GLP-1R agonists in asthma.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Stroke rehabilitation is primarily focused on reduction of stroke-related impairments, e.g., motor impairment, with the intention that impairment reduction will lead to improved ability to participate in everyday life activities, e.g., self-care, work. Despite substantial research to investigate the use of these impairment- reduction approaches in stroke, there is limited evidence to support that these approaches result in any meaningful impairment reduction that translates to improved ability to perform everyday life activities. This proposal seeks to evaluate if a stroke-rehabilitation self-management program, that targets management of chronic stroke symptoms rather than impairment reduction, can improve self-efficacy, activity performance, and quality of life in individuals with sub-acute stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aneurysms are dilations of blood vessels caused by weakening and progressive enlargement of the vessel wall which increases the risk of rupture and fatal hemorrhage. There is currently no directed medical therapy to treat aneurysms, emphasizing the need to better understand their pathogenesis in an effort to devise targeted therapeutic strategies. Using mouse models with cell- specific deletion of the enzyme lysyl oxidase, known to be a cause of aortic aneurysms in humans, the overall goal of this proposal is to understand how loss of lysyl oxidase changes the arterial wall and vascular cell behavior leading to aneurysmal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many variants of human proteins have been identified by sequencing, but the effects of the amino acid changes are often unknown. Annotation of these effects would be significantly aided by the results of biochemical activity assays for all the single amino acid variants of a given protein. We propose to develop a method that covalently links a unique RNA barcode to each variant, thereby allowing pooled activity assays, with the variants identified simply by sequencing of their barcodes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Disease-associated variation in the ABCA4 gene is the most prevalent cause of Mendelian retinal disease with extensive clinical heterogeneity including >40 clinical phenotypes, which reflect its equally vast genotypic profile with >2300 known disease-associated variants, together comprising ABCA4-associated retinopathy, ABCA4-RD, which is well-characterized in European population, but almost practically unknown for underserved minorities, especially for patients of African American (AA) descent. The proposed research program, based on large, comprehensively characterized cohort of AA patients with ABCA4-RD from 5 urban centers, is using integrated approaches of genetic analyses, quantified clinical data and functional analyses to determine the pathogenic variation in the ABCA4 locus and in the genome thereby generating a prediction matrix for ABCA4-RD for AA patients. The outcome of these studies will substantially improve diagnostic accuracy, prognostic counseling and will provide a platform for designing precise phenotype-specific treatment in clinical trials for ABCA4-RD in AA population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI) account for 40% of nosocomial infections globally, amounting to more than 1 million cases in the US alone, and costing nearly $2 billion annually. Current approaches to modify urinary catheters and materials to reduce microbial contamination have several drawbacks that limit their efficacy, and new catheter modifications that capitalize on the strengths of each approach are needed. In this project we will use 3D-printing to develop and test new 3D-bioprinted probiotic catheter devices that combine the strengths of “bacterial interference” at the catheter interface with the release of biocidal agents into the bladder and catheter lumen to preclude or disrupt CAUTI pathogenesis, while advancing our understanding of probiotic interactions with the host and uropathogenic bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to develop a new suite of MRI tools (including leading-edge hardware and software) that can be synergistically combined with the unique ultrahigh field of 10.5 Tesla and high-performance head gradients to enable rapid acquisition of high-quality functional MRI at unprecedented spatiotemporal resolutions, thereby increasing our ability to study human brain function in health and disease at the mesoscopic scale. Once such a suite of MRI tools has been developed, there will be a potential for opening new research horizons, particularly in RF coil design, parallel transmission, data acquisition, image reconstruction, functional brain mapping, and their application to study the human brain. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIBIB’s mission, which is to improve health by leading the development and accelerating the application of biomedical technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Synthetic biology has the potential to revolutionize the advancement of diagnostic and treatment approaches across a wide range of diseases. This project aims to engineer synthetic gene clocks that can slow cell aging. Key insights from this project will establish a general strategy for promoting longevity applicable to various organisms, setting the stage for clinical applications toward age-related human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a fatal form of interstitial lung disease and there is no effective therapeutics for the disease currently. In this proposal, we will test the hypothesis that the dysregulated signaling pathways in the pathogenically accumulating basal-like cells in IPF promote fibrogenesis by activation of the WNT signaling in the fibrotic niche, leading to impairment of AT2 renewal and fibroblast activation. This study will further aid us to understand the biology and pathology of basal cell-mediated fibrogenesis in IPF and help us to develop therapeutic strategies for patients with IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The spatial organization of DNA and RNA in our cells regulate important genomic functions such as gene expression and localized protein production in specific sub-cellular regions, and the spatial organization of DNA and RNA is regulated in turn by upstream regulatory mechanisms. Yet our understanding of what regulators control the spatial organization of DNA and RNA is far from complete, due to a lack of large-scale discovery technologies. This study will invent a new technology platform that will enable highly efficient discovery of upstream regulators of the DNA and RNA organization, which will help elucidate and engineer the spatial axis of molecular biology in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lymphatic malformations are congenital lesions of the lymphatic system that obstruct the airway, prevent oral feeding, interfere with visual development, and cause extreme pain and disfigurement. Efforts to cure LM patients with surgery, sclerotherapy, laser treatments, and immunosuppressive chemotherapy have been unsuccessful. This project utilizes a comparative multi-omics approach to develop microRNA-based therapeutics that target novel molecular pathways driving proliferation, infection, and local tissue invasion in lymphatic malformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Our proposed international ENIGMA Eating Disorders Initiative will compile, harmonize, and analyze a worldwide dataset of unprecedented scale, with the power and depth to identify robust prognostic markers and markers of recovery or relapse in anorexia nervosa – a crucial but under-studied psychiatric condition, with highly elevated suicide risk. This new international initiative is a coordinated data analysis platform to determine multimodal neuroimaging signatures of AN from 31 diverse datasets worldwide (including ~1,600 individuals with AN), to assist prognosis, and discover factors that influence relapse, suicidality, and recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Proper brain function depends on the precise number and type of neurons formed during development, with disturbances in genetic programs leading to severe neurological disorders. Our proposal uses Drosophila neural stem cells that are similar to human outer radial glia to unravel the mechanisms regulating neural diversity while training diverse next-generation neuroscientists. Given the high conservation of neural stem cells, genes, and behaviors we study, our work will provide novel insights into human brain development and disorders and advance our ability to harness stem cells to replace cells lost to injury or disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Access to contraceptive services for low-income women is central to reducing inequities in unintended pregnancy, a key health marker. Telemedicine (TM) has the potential to expand access to care, but widespread use of TM for contraceptive care was limited prior to the COVID19 pandemic. Our study uses health record data from Community Health Centers (2019-2025) that serve low-income women to examine inequities in the use of TM, identify unintended consequences, and explore patient preferences for TM versus face-to-face visits for contraceptive services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The successful outcome of this proposal is the development of much needed quantitative translational imaging biomarkers of neoadjuvant chemotherapeutic efficacy in muscle invasive bladder cancer that have been validated in clinically pertinent patient derived xenografts. The findings of this research project would pave the way for implementation of imaging markers to monitor response of muscle invasive bladder cancer to neoadjuvant chemotherapy to facilitate tailored application of toxic therapy for better tangible clinical outcomes. While this project focuses on neoadjuvant chemotherapy of cisplatin+gemcitabine combination in bladder cancer, the proposed quantitative metabolic imaging technique could ultimately benefit the clinical management of other cancers and drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uveitis is a significant cause of blindness globally and there are many challenges to diagnose infectious etiologies due to the insensitivity of diagnostic testing and limited sample volumes from the intraocular space. This proposal leverages international collaborators and recent technological advancements in deep sequencing and mass spectrometry to identify pathogens causing uveitis and characterize the host transcriptome in intraocular fluid and interrogate the tears for proteome and metabolite profiles. This study will provide a comprehensive molecular approach to improve the diagnosis of uveitis and deepen our understanding of the host response to improve the characterization of infectious uveitis syndromes through pathogen discovery and contribute to future risk stratification, individualized treatment, and biomarker identification in uveitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: This CDC/NIOSH renewal application, contains three components; an expanded Fundamental component, which in addition to integrating occupational health into other public health initiatives, also includes adult lead poisoning outreach and interventions activities; an Occupational Lung Disease Surveillance component and Fatality Assessment and Control Evaluation (NY FACE) component. For the expanded Fundamental component, data will be collected and incorporated into other public health tracking systems and will be used to identify high-risk industries and occupations, and other populations at high-risk, including adults at risk for lead poisoning. We will continue our work in preventing serious and fatal occupational injuries by conducting the NY FACE program and use data from the NYS Occupational Lung Disease Registry to continue and expand surveillance for occupational lung disease.

PROJECT_TITLE: Occupational Safety and Health Surveillance in New York State

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The World Trade Center Health Registry contributes to public health by identifying the long-term physical and mental health effects and health care needs of persons directly affected by the World Trade Center disaster. The Registry shares its health findings and recommendations with enrollees, the public, health care providers, scientists, policy makers, and the World Trade Center Health Program. The Registry also provides information about 9/11-related services and offers treatment referral and health promotion opportunities for enrollees.

PHR: Project Narrative The MSOH-IH program at the University of Toledo addresses a NIOSH "core discipline", a DHHS Healthy People 2020 Occupational Safety and Health initiative with a focus on prevention/mitigation of work-related human illnesses/ injuries via anticipation, recognition, evaluation, prevention, and control of applicable hazardous agents and factors. The requested funds for 5 years will be used to provide scholarships to graduate students majoring in Industrial Hygiene, who will be prepared for employment as highly qualified, appropriately educated, and trained occupational health and safety specialists in the Northwest Ohio region and elsewhere.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Cardiovascular disease and stroke claims more lives and costs more money than any other disease in the United States of America. Studies in our laboratory have identified the enzyme glutaminase-1, which metabolizes glutamine to glutamate and ammonia, as a critical regulator of vascular smooth muscle cell function. This project will investigate whether glutaminase-1 contributes to neointima formation following arterial injury, and if it mediates abnormal arterial remodeling, increased arterial stiffness, and hypertension in diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Salient experiences have a high probability of being remembered, yet how salience is incorporated into memories is not well understood. Our research will explore the functions of VTA dopaminergic neurons–a neuronal population critically implicated in encoding salience and learning–in the consolidation of salient memories during sleep. We will use powerful systems neuroscience tools to reveal what facets of experiences alter dopamine signaling during sleep, whether dopamine signaling during post-learning sleep contributes to long-term storage of memories and the nature of interactions between VTA dopamine neurons and hippocampal-dependent memory consolidation processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT) is the standard therapy for several haematological cancers and diseases with more than 30,000 procedures carried out annually worldwide, including in 40 per 100,000 Americans afflicted with life-threatening blood, bone marrow or lymph node cancer. Immune pathology called chronic graft versus host disease (cGVHD) develops in many HCT patients, leading to significant impact on morbidity and survival. Our current research will advance knowledge of cGVHD immune mechanisms in human HCT that will lead to improved treatments for cancer patients, and patients with autoimmune and blood disorders.

PHR: Narrative Inflammatory bowel disease affects millions of patients per year in the United States, and it imposes burdens on communities worldwide and drastically reduces patients’ quality of life. Patients with inflammatory bowel disease exhibit disruptions in their intestinal mucus and dysbiosis of the commensal gut microbiome. This proposal aims at demonstrating the function of β1-3-N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase 7 (B3GNT7) in maintaining intestinal mucus and a healthy gut microbiome.

PHR: Project Narrative The development of mature neural circuits requires a significant degree of circuit rewiring. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs

PHR: Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is a major cause of death and disability among both civilians and military personnel, with about 1.4 million TBI’s occurring each year in the U.S. For military personnel, between 14-20% of surviving casualties had a TBI. Studies proposed investigate chronic effects of different types of traumatic brain injury, including cognitive decline and early-onset dementia. This work may lead to a new strategy for improving chronic outcomes after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE A key challenge for psychiatry and clinical psychology is to discover, understand, and ultimately to treat the root causes of the most common and costly mental disorders. The proposed study will harness an innovative combination of state-of-the-art brain imaging techniques and longitudinal measures of symptom progression, function, and real-world experience to identify the neural and behavioral pathways that contribute to the development and recurrence of anxiety disorders and depression—mental illnesses that are common and challenging to treat. This work is a critical step toward the development of new, neurobiologically-grounded strategies for preventing or treating these debilitating emotional disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: L-asparaginase (ASNase) is a biological cancer drug with a unique mode of action, with broad potential use, although it currently is mostly limited to a childhood blood cancer called ALL because the side effects are exacerbated in adults. Our previous work designed and evaluated a new ASNase, predicted to be much better tolerated by adult cancer patients, thus creating multiple potential additional uses beyond ALL. We now also better understand which patients would respond to this drug, allowing us to employ personalized medicine to identify those cancer patients. In this application, we expand ASNase treatment from blood cancers to solid tumors, where we evaluate the efficacy of ASNase in liver cancer, including studies of factors that can lead to drug resistance. This combination of our new and safer ASNase (which will permit use by the adult VA patient population), with a screen that predicts which patients would benefit most from this treatment, will impact the treatment of Veterans with liver cancer and other solid tumor cancers such as gastric and AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intermittent fasting and caloric restriction are newly identified, effective means through to treat secondary cardiomyopathies. We identified trehalose-class compounds as pharmacological mimetics of the adaptive fasting response, which also attenuate the pathological growth, gene expression and cardiac dysfunction that is induced by chronic pressure overload. Using broad cardiomyopathic stimuli and detailed mouse genetic approaches in the current proposal, we will examine signaling mechanisms and clinical contexts in which hepatic glucose fasting responses can be leveraged against secondary cardiomyopathies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Insomnia is a common sleep disturbance in service members and veterans and is especially prevalent in individuals with a history of traumatic brain injury. Long-term untreated insomnia can lead to a wide range of negative health concerns such as mood and anxiety disorders, respiratory and neurologic conditions, chronic pain, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. Although cognitive behavioral therapy is the gold standard treatment for insomnia, not all individuals respond to the treatment. This research will examine the mechanisms associated with cognitive behavioral therapy effectiveness in military service members with insomnia and history of traumatic brain injuries. Improving sleep is the first critical step in optimizing and enhancing rehabilitation approaches in veterans, and our results could provide tractable solutions to strengthen existing rehabilitation or identify novel therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: This project aims to understand the long-term impacts of disasters on Hospital Systems Serving Health Disparities Populations (HSSHDPs), and in turn contribute insightful recommendations for improvements in disaster preparedness. HSSHDPs are embedded within their communities and understand the myriad challenges faced by the people they serve and play a pivotal role in reducing health disparities resulting from disasters. In the long-term, by implementing recommendations that address concerns of such hospital systems, the populations will be better served, thereby, positively impacting overall public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gender minority people of color face disparities in health and wellbeing, which have been attributed (at least in part) to the negative impact of minority stress on health, while perceived social support has been shown to be protective. This study will examine the social support networks of gender minority people of color both qualitatively and quantitatively, and identify strengths and weaknesses in social connectedness that moderate the relationship between minority stress, health and wellbeing. Findings will inform the future development of interventions to reduce social isolation, promote resilience, and improve health and healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE The rapid recruitment of white blood cells to sites of tissue injury or infection is a vital determinant of health and its deregulation can lead to chronic disease. This proposal aims at understanding how chemotactic signals are packaged and propagated between neighboring neutrophils, a type of white blood cell critical to innate immunity responses, as they are being recruited to sites of injury or infection. We propose to identify the mechanisms by which exosomes, which are small membrane-bound elements with a key role in signal propagation, are being generated intracellularly from multivesicular bodies using cell biological, biochemical and genetic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asian American, Native Hawaiian, and Pacific Islander (AANHPI) sexual and gender minority youth face substantial health disparities; however, misconceptions and insufficient information contribute to disparities and unmet needs. This mixed methods study using an intersectionality framework is directly responsive to calls for research to identify drivers of health disparities in AANHPI youth that link individuals to multiple types of stressors and supports (peers, family, community). This project will use rigorous quantitative and qualitative approaches to challenge misconceptions, fill key research gaps, and offer concrete intervention recommendations to improve community-centered health and wellness for AANHPI youth in intersecting marginalized social positions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE Fear and anxiety disorders imposes a staggering burden on public health and the global economy and existing treatments are far from curative, underscoring the urgency of developing a deeper understanding of the underlying neurobiology. This study will harness an innovative combination of approaches—including brain imaging, state-of-the-art computational techniques, and smartphone digital phenotyping—to understand the architecture of the brain circuits underlying fear and anxiety and determine their relevance to real-world distress, setting the stage for developing more effective brain-based intervention strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optimal mitochondrial function is central to human health and disease. We propose to develop tools to study the rich mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) information in HuBMAP and other single-cell datasets. We will obtain new biological insights into how cell/organ type, aging, gender, race, and other factors impact mtDNA integrity and how mtDNA variants affect cellular gene expression and function.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is linked to chronic mental health problems including post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in veterans. In many veterans symptoms persist or progress. TBI is also a risk factor for later development of neurodegenerative diseases. Fear learning has been extensively studied in rodents for its relevance to the pathobiology of human PTSD. These studies will examine the molecular basis for why blast exposure affects fear responses using a rat model designed to mimic human mild TBI or subclinical blast exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Despite a long history of groundbreaking discoveries, the number of funded surgeon-scientists continues to drop precipitously. Evidence supports a two-year research experience as part of general surgery residency to increase the likelihood that surgeons will pursue academic careers, and the integration of PhD-scientists into Departments of Surgery as a means of promoting surgical research productivity. Utilizing these two approaches, the University of Wisconsin Surgical Oncology Research Training (UW-SORT) Program aims to train post-doctoral fellows who will pursue multidisciplinary, translational surgical oncology research and ensure our continued advancement in the care of patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative: Improper drainage of extravasated protein-rich fluid from the thoracic tissues causes it to accumulate, resulting in chylothorax. It is the most common lymphatic anomaly and frequently involves defective lymphatic development in newborn children. Our exciting findings reveal a novel function of common oncogenic mutation during thoracic lymphatic development. The set of experiments outlined in this proposal will reveal critical molecular mechanisms underlying lymphatic development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative High throughput sequencing of the rearranged T cell receptor genes (HTS) is an approach that profiles T cells in the tissue and has enhanced the ability to diagnose and manage patients with cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL). However, the formalin used to preserve skin biopsy specimens damages DNA and affects readings in a way that could lead to errors in patient diagnosis and care. We seek to identify new fixatives and tissue handling procedures that enable multiple different analyses to be accurately carried out on small skin biopsies obtained in CTCL clinical trials, including HTS readings, histologic studies and measures of gene expression.
